(Code 2008, § 130.160; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016; Ord. No. 2016-3608, 6-8-2016) 
Sec. 130.170. - Quorum. 
    A quorum for conducting business at meetings of the downtown committee shall consist of four members. All decisions or actions of the downtown committee shall be made by a majority vote of those members present and voting at any meeting where a quorum exists. 
(Code 2008, § 130.170; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016) 
Sec. 130.180. - Recommendations. 
    The board of aldermen shall from time to time solicit the recommendations of the downtown committee with regard to the redevelopment and preservation of the city's downtown area. 
(Code 2008, § 130.180; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016) 
Sec. 130.190. - Officers. 
    Officers shall consist of a chairperson and a vice-chairperson elected by the downtown committee who shall each serve a term of one year and shall be eligible for re-election; but no member shall serve as chairperson for more than two consecutive years. The chairperson shall preside over meetings. In the absence of the chairperson, the vice-chairperson shall perform the duties of the chairperson. If both are absent, a temporary chairperson shall be elected by those present. The secretary of the downtown committee shall be appointed by the department of economic development and shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Take minutes of each downtown committee meeting; 
(2)  Be responsible for publication and distribution of copies of the minutes, reports, and decisions to the members of the downtown committee; 
(3)  Give notice as provided herein by law for all public hearings conducted by the downtown committee; 
(4)  Advise the mayor of vacancies on the downtown committee and expiring terms of members; and 
(5)  Prepare to submit to the board of aldermen a complete record of the proceedings before the downtown committee on any matter requiring board of aldermen consideration. 
(Code 2008, § 130.190; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016) 
Sec. 130.200. - Meetings. 
(a)  Meetings shall be held at regularly scheduled times to be established by resolution of the downtown committee at the beginning of each calendar year or at any time upon the call of the chairperson, but no less than once each quarter. Public notice of all meetings shall be posted in conformance with standard city policy and RSMo 610.020 . All meetings of the downtown committee shall be open to the public, except as allowed by state law. 
(b)  No member of the downtown committee shall vote on any matter that may materially or apparently affect the property, income, or business interest of that member. 
(c)  No action shall be taken by the downtown committee that could in any manner deprive or restrict the owner of property in its use, modification, maintenance, disposition, or demolition, until such owner shall first have had the opportunity to be heard at public meeting of the downtown committee. 
(d)  The chairperson, and in his absence, lawing chairperson, may administer oaths and require the attendance of witnesses. 
(e)  The downtown committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be public record. 
(f)  All downtown committee rules of procedure, designation criteria, design guidelines and forms shall be available to the public at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 2008, § 130.200; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016) 
Sec. 130.210. - Funding. 
    The board of aldermen shall annually appropriate funds, within the budget limitations, for the operation of the downtown committee. The downtown committee may, with the consent of the board of aldermen, apply for, receive, or expend any federal, state or private grant, grant-in-aid, gift or bequest in furtherance of the general purposes of this article and this Code. 
(Code 2008, § 130.210; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016) 
Sec. 130.220. - Powers and duties. 
    The downtown committee shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To adopt its own by-laws and procedural regulations, provided that such regulations are consistent with this chapter and city and state law; 
(2)  To advise and make recommendations to the board of aldermen as to transforming downtown Wentzville into a community destination point while striving to protect, enhance, and revitalize the city's historical heritage; 
(3)  To conduct an ongoing survey for the identification of historically, archaeologically and architecturally significant properties, structures, sites and areas that exemplify the cultural, social, economic, political, or architectural history of the nation, state or city; and to maintain the research information in an inventory accessible to the public (except for archaeological site locations, which shall be restricted); 
(4)  To investigate and recommend to the planning and zoning commission and to the board of aldermen the adoption of ordinances designating for the protection of properties or structures having special cultural, historic, archaeological, community or architectural value as landmarks; 
(5)  To investigate and recommend to the planning and zoning commission and the board of aldermen the adoption of ordinances designating for the protection of areas as having special cultural, historic, archaeological, community or architectural value as historic districts; 
(6)  To keep a register of all properties and structures which have been designated as landmarks or historic districts, including all information required for each designation; 
(7)  To confer recognition upon the owners of landmarks and property or structures within historic districts by means of certificates, plaques, or markers; and to make recommendations for the design and implementation of specific markings of the streets and routes leading from one landmark or historic district to another; 
(8)  To advise and assist owners of landmarks and property or structures within historic districts on physical and financial aspects of preservation, renovation, rehabilitation, and reuse, and on procedures for inclusion on the national register of historic places; 
(9)  To nominate landmarks and historic districts for addition to the state and national historic registries and to review and comment on any nominations to the national register of historic places; 
(10)  To inform and educate the citizens of the city concerning the historic, archaeological and architectural heritage of the city through publication or sponsorship of maps, newsletters, brochures, pamphlets, programs and seminars by the city, the downtown committee, or other appropriate parties; 
(11)  To hold public hearings and to review applications for construction, alteration, removal or demolition affecting proposed or designated landmarks or structures within historic districts and issue or deny certificates of appropriateness for such actions. Applicants may be required to submit plans, drawings, elevations, specifications, and other information as may be necessary to make decisions; 
(12)  To hold public hearings on each proposed nomination of a landmark and of a historic district and on the guidelines developed for each nomination; 
(13)  To request the community development department to issue stop work orders for any construction, alteration, removal or demolition undertaken without a certificate of appropriateness or to stop work that violates the conditions of a certificate; 
(14)  To review all applications for demolition permits within the corporate limits of the city to determine the impact to significant cultural resources, including those not yet nominated as landmarks or as contributing properties within a historic district; 
(15)  To consider applications for certificates of economic hardship that would allow the performance of work for which a certificate of appropriateness has been denied; 
(16)  To develop specific design guidelines based on the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation for the alteration, construction, or removal of landmarks or property and structures within historic districts; 
(17)  To review proposed zoning amendments, applications for conditional use permits, or applications for zoning variances that affect proposed or designated landmarks or historic districts; 
(18)  To administer on behalf of the city any property of historical significance or full or partial interest in real property, including easements, that the city may have or accept as a gift or otherwise, upon approval by the board of aldermen; 
(19)  To accept and administer on behalf of the city, upon approval of the board of aldermen, such gifts, grants, and money as may be appropriate for the purposes of this article and this Code. Such money may be expended for publishing maps and brochures, or for hiring staff persons or consultants, or performing other functions for carrying out the duties and powers of the downtown committee and the purposes of this article and this Code; 
(20)  To call upon available city staff members as well as other experts for technical advice; 
(21)  To retain such specialists or consultants or to appoint such citizen advisory committees as may be required from time to time; 
(22)  To testify before all boards and commissions, including the planning and zoning commission and the board of adjustment, on any matter affecting historically, archaeologically, culturally and architecturally significant property, structures, sites and areas; 
(23)  To make recommendations to the board of aldermen concerning budgetary appropriations to further the general purposes of this article and this Code; 
(24)  To develop a preservation component in the comprehensive plan of the city and to recommend it to the planning and zoning commission and to the board of aldermen; 
(25)  To periodically review the city zoning and subdivision regulations and to recommend to the planning and zoning commission and the board of aldermen any amendments appropriate for the protection and continued use of landmarks or property, sites and structures within historic districts; 
(26)  To advise and make recommendations to the board of aldermen as to transforming downtown Wentzville into a community destination point while striving to protect, enhance and revitalize the city's historical heritage; and 
(27)  To undertake any other action or activity necessary or appropriate to the implementation of its powers and duties or to implementation of the purpose of this article and this Code. 
(Code 2008, § 130.220; Ord. No. 3579, § 2, 3-9-2016) 
CHAPTER 135. - PERSONNEL POLICY 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 135.010. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish uniform personnel policies and procedures for city employees. 
(Code 2006, § 135.010; Code 2008, § 135.010; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.010), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.020. - Applicability. 
    These policies and procedures shall apply to all employees of the city, including elected officials. 
(Code 2006, § 135.020; Code 2008, § 135.020; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.020), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.030. - Administration. 
    The policies and procedures as approved by the board of aldermen shall be administered by the city administrator or his/her designee. All departmental policies and procedures must be on file in the city. 
(Code 2006, § 135.030; Code 2008, § 135.030; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.030), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.040. - Employee manual. 
(a)  The city administrator may supplement the policies and procedures that constitute this chapter in writing through the adoption and periodic amendment of an employee manual concerning all aspects of city employment, duties, personnel regulations, etc. Copies of the employee manual and amendments to the employee manual shall be forwarded to or made available in printed or electronic form to all employees of the city. 
(b)  In the event of a conflict between sections of this chapter and provisions of the employee manual, this chapter shall apply. 
(Code 2006, § 135.040; Code 2008, § 135.040; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.040), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.050. - Revision. 
    This chapter shall be subject to revisions adopted by the board of aldermen at any time by ordinance. Any and all revisions shall be forwarded to all employees. 
(Code 2006, § 135.050; Code 2008, § 135.050; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.050), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.060. - Violation of provisions. 
    Any employee violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including suspension and/or dismissal, in addition to any penalty which may be levied for the violation of the same. 
(Code 2006, § 135.060; Code 2008, § 135.060; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.060), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.070. - Equal employment opportunity. 
(a)  It is the policy of the city to employ qualified persons without discrimination against any employee or applicant for employment because of age, race, color, national origin, ancestry, religion, sex, pregnancy (including childbirth, lactation and related medical conditions), physical or mental disability, genetic information (including testing and characteristics), veteran status, uniformed service member status, or any other status protected by federal, state, or local laws. The city affirms and emphasizes that this policy applies throughout the city. In implementing and administering this policy, the city will provide that: 
(1)  The city will recruit, hire, train and promote qualified persons in all job titles without regard to age, race, color, national origin, ancestry, religion, sex, pregnancy (including childbirth, lactation and related medical conditions), physical or mental disability, genetic information (including testing and characteristics), veteran status, uniformed service member status, or any other status protected by federal, state, or local laws. 
(2)  The city will base decisions on employment so as to further the principles of equal employment opportunity. 
(3)  The city will ensure that promotion decisions are in accord with the principles of equal employment opportunity by imposing only valid requirements for promotional opportunities. 
(4)  The city will ensure that all personnel actions such as compensation, benefits, transfers, layoffs, return from layoff, city-sponsored training, education, tuition assistance, social and recreational programs will be administered without regard to age, race, color, national origin, ancestry, religion, sex, pregnancy (including childbirth, lactation and related medical conditions), physical or mental disability, genetic information (including testing and characteristics), veteran status, uniformed service member status, or any other status protected by federal, state, or local laws. 
(b)  The city will comply with all applicable state and federal laws with respect to providing equal employment opportunity. 
(Code 2006, § 135.070; Code 2008, § 135.070; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.070), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.080. - Americans With Disabilities Act policy. 
(a)  The city will comply with all applicable state and federal laws with respect to ensuring that the city does not discriminate against qualified employees and applicants with regard to any terms or conditions of employment because of such individual's disability or perceived disability so long as the individual can perform the essential functions of the job. 
(b)  Consistent with this policy of nondiscrimination, the city will provide reasonable accommodations to a qualified individual with a disability, as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Missouri Human Rights Act (MHRA), who has made the city aware of his or her disability, provided that such accommodation does not constitute an undue hardship on the city. 
(c)  Procedures for ensuring that qualified employees with a disability receive reasonable accommodations will be addressed in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.080; Code 2008, § 135.080; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.080), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.090. - Anti-harassment policy. 
(a)  The city prohibits workplace harassment based on an employees protected classifications, including sexual harassment, racial harassment and other forms of workplace harassment as prohibited by applicable state and federal laws. 
(b)  A more detailed statement of the city's anti-harassment policy, the procedures for reporting suspected workplace harassment and the procedures for investigation of workplace harassment complaints shall be addressed in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.090; Code 2008, § 135.090; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.090), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.100. - Alcohol and drug-free workplace. 
(a)  The city is an alcohol-free and drug-free workplace. The city will provide safe, dependable and economical services to its citizens and provide safe working conditions for its employees. The city will comply with the requirements of federal law and regulations related to the Drug Free Work Place Act of 1988 and the Omnibus Transportation Employee Testing Act of 1991. The city is committed to providing a healthy, satisfying, working environment for its employees. The city will adopt procedures and follow proper practices to ensure that its employees are not impaired in their ability to perform assigned duties in a safe, productive and healthy manner; to create a workplace environment free from the adverse effects of alcohol and controlled substance abuse or misuse; to prohibit the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensing, possession or use of alcohol and controlled substances; to provide for alcohol and controlled substance testing of employees in accordance with applicable laws; and to encourage employees to seek professional assistance when personal problems, including alcohol and controlled substance dependency, adversely affect their ability to perform assigned duties. 
(b)  A more detailed statement of the city's alcohol and drug-free workplace policy, the procedures for reporting suspected violation of the policy, and the procedures for conducting alcohol and controlled substance testing of employees shall be addressed in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.100; Code 2008, § 135.100; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.100), 12-13-2017) 
Secs. 135.110, 135.120. - Reserved. 
Sec. 135.130. - Employment at will. 
    The city seeks to employ people who will work together as a team on an ongoing basis. However, both the employee and the city have the right to terminate employment and compensation at any time, for any reason, provided such reason is not a reason prohibited by law, or for no reason, with or without notice. Nothing said or done by any city employee or stated in the employee manual should be considered or construed as a contract (express or implied), or a guarantee of employment or compensation, or of a particular position with the city. No one other than the board of aldermen has the authority to enter into any agreement regarding employment. Any agreement must be in writing and signed by both the employee and the mayor or city administrator. Furthermore, by establishing policies or practices on employee conduct, the city in no way intends to be obligated to follow such procedures in every case. 
(Code 2006, § 135.130; Code 2008, § 135.130; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.130), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.140. - Criminal background checks. 
(a)  This section is enacted pursuant to RSMo 43.535 , to provide for the criminal history record review associated with the hiring of municipal employees. 
(b)  Any applicant or employee seeking to provide services to the city shall submit a set of his/her fingerprints to the Missouri State Highway Patrol. 
(c)  The city will be billed for each fingerprint transaction submitted to the Missouri State Highway Patrol. The Missouri State Highway Patrol will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a comparison with nationwide records. The results of the Federal Bureau of Investigation check will be returned to the Missouri State Highway Patrol, which will disseminate the state and national results to the city. 
(d)  The city shall render a fitness determination based upon the results of the criminal background check. In rendering a fitness determination, the city will decide whether the record subject has been convicted of or is under pending indictment for a crime which bears upon his/her ability or fitness to serve in the capacity for which he/she has applied. 
(e)  An applicant or employee may request and receive a copy of his/her criminal history record information from the city. Should the applicant or employee need to amend or correct his/her record, he/she must contact the Missouri State Highway Patrol for a Missouri State record or the Federal Bureau of Investigation for records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(Code 2008, § 135.145; Ord. No. 2899, §§ 1-5, 7-9-2008; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.140), 12-13-2017) 
ARTICLE II. - POSITION CLASSIFICATION AND COMPENSATION PLAN 

Sec. 135.200. - Preparation, adoption and amendment. 
    A position classification and compensation plan shall be prepared by the city administrator and submitted to the board of aldermen for adoption in conjunction with the annual budget. The classification and compensation plan shall include the proposed classifications and a pay grade for each classification. 
(Code 2006, § 135.290; Code 2008, § 135.290; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.200), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.210. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the position classification and compensation plan is to assemble positions into classes of employees whose duties and responsibilities are sufficiently alike to be grouped under the same descriptive job title, to be accorded the same pay grade and to require similar qualifications for employment. 
(Code 2006, § 135.150; Code 2008, § 135.150; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.210), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.220. - Use of classification plan. 
    The classification plan is to be used: 
(1)  As a guide in recruiting and examining candidates for employment; 
(2)  In determining lines of promotion and in developing employee-training programs; 
(3)  In determining compensation to be paid for various types of work; 
(4)  In providing uniform job terminology understandable by all city officials and employees and by the general public. 
(Code 2006, § 135.160; Code 2008, § 135.160; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.220), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.230. - Class. 
    The position classification plan shall include titles and written specifications for the various classes of positions. Each class shall include all positions in the classified service, which are sufficiently similar with respect to duties, responsibilities and authority so that the same descriptive title may be used to designate each position allocated to the class. Specifications shall show minimum requirements for education, experience, general and specialized knowledge, skill, physical conditions and other qualifications necessary for the proper performance of the positions. Specifications will be descriptive and explanatory of the kind of work required in a given classification but are not inclusive of all the duties to be performed. The specifications shall be used for the purposes of recruiting, testing and selection. Reasonable accommodations shall be made on an individual basis. 
(Code 2006, § 135.170; Code 2008, § 135.170; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.230), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.240. - Administration of the plan. 
    The approved position classification plan shall be maintained by human resources. A request for reclassification of an existing position or the classification of a proposed position may be filed by a department director and submitted to the city administrator. 
(Code 2006, § 135.180; Code 2008, § 135.180; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.240), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.250. - Salary administration guidelines. 
(a)  Salary changes. A salary change is defined as any change in an employee's base wage rate. Changes will only be processed in accordance with the following guidelines. 
(b)  Pay raises. Pay raises, or advancement through the city pay plan, are based on the annual budget allocation as approved by the board of aldermen and individual annual performance scores. The city may also make individual pay raises based on merit or due to a change of job position. 
(c)  Salary structure. The salary structure has established pay grades for all positions within the city based on the level of difficulty of the job, job responsibility, and qualifications required. Each pay grade has 15 steps (numbered 1 through 15). Employees who have written employment agreements ("contracted employees") are excluded from the step and grade salary structure. All other positions are assigned to one of the following pay grades: 
PAY GRADES 
General (non-contractual) Employees A-P Law Enforcement P-1 through P-6 Seasonal SEAS0-SEAS4  
(d)  Step increases. Within-pay-grade step increases are based on an acceptable level of performance. Employees receiving a composite score of 2.5 or higher on their annual performance evaluation will be eligible for the annual step increase. It typically takes 15 years to advance from Step 1 to Step 15 within a single pay grade if an employee remains in that single pay grade. However, employees with outstanding (or equivalent) performance ratings may be considered for additional, quality step increases (maximum of one per year), which must be approved by the city administrator. 
(e)  Salary structure adjustments. 
(1)  Purpose. The city salary structure may be adjusted annually to ensure that it remains competitive with markets from which it attracts talented employees. 
(2)  Salary structure adjustment procedures. On an annual basis, human resources will review the salary structures in consideration of changing economic and competitive factors as determined by city-approved published salary surveys and other data sources. When deemed necessary, human resources will recommend an appropriate salary structure adjustment to the city administrator. Salary structures will be adjusted as approved by the board of aldermen. Any employee whose salary is below the minimum of the assigned updated salary range will receive a pay adjustment at least equal to the difference between actual salary and the salary range minimum. 
(f)  Determining pay for promotions and demotions. A promotion occurs when an employee moves to a job in a higher pay grade or range. Reclassification to a higher pay grade does not constitute a promotion. A transfer occurs when an employee transfers to another position in the same pay grade as the position previously occupied. In such cases, the employee shall not be eligible for a pay increase at the time of such transfer. Employees may be eligible for a raise with city administrator approval. A demotion occurs when an employee's position is reassessed to a lower pay grade or when an employee is transferred to a position in a lower pay grade typically due to reorganization. A demotion also occurs when an employee voluntarily accepts a position in a lower pay grade than the position occupied. 
(1)  Determining pay for promotion procedures. City employees may advance to higher pay grades by promotion. In this case, the employee will be placed on a step at the new grade at a rate that exceeds the current salary. The new rate will be determined by the department director and approved by the city administrator. Human resources will provide salary pay grades, individual pay information and promotion adjustment guidelines to each department director upon the promotion of an employee. The department director will determine the promotional increase step according to the pay adjustment guidelines. Promotion-based salary adjustments are in addition to general increases if the promotion is made at the time of the annual wage adjustment. 
(2)  Determining pay for demotion procedures. In the case of a demotion resulting from poor performance, re-classification of a position or employee choice, the employee will be placed in the lower salary grade between steps 1-7. In no case shall the newly established salary exceed the previous rate of pay. 
(g)  Determining pay for temporary promotions. Employees, who are given a temporary assignment to a higher classification, will receive a pay differential to recognize the increased responsibility during the temporary assignment. An employee working a minimum of 20 consecutive work days in that position will receive, retroactively, a temporary increase to the minimum of the new pay grade. If the employee who is temporarily assigned to a new position is currently being paid at a rate that is above the minimum of the pay range for the position that he/she is temporarily filling, the employee will be placed on a step at the new grade at a rate that exceeds the employee's current salary. The new rate will be determined by the department director and approved by the city administrator. At the conclusion of the temporary assignment, the employee will return to the employee's previous pay rate. Non-exempt employees temporarily assigned to exempt positions will remain non-exempt and eligible for overtime payments if applicable, exceptions may be granted by the city administrator. 
(h)  Requested review of a job's pay grade assignment. A job reassignment occurs when a job is moved to a different pay grade because the essential job functions have significantly changed. Department directors and employees may request a review of the evaluation of their job during a specified time frame each year. Specific requests to human resources must be approved by the employee's department director and routed through human resources and the city administrator. The following procedures will be followed for reassignment of an existing position. 
(1)  Except in unusual circumstances, requests for reassessment may be made annually in concert with budget preparation. Each year, human resources will notify departments of the period within which any position reassessments must be considered. A review of a position's classification is warranted when there has been a material, significant and permanent change in job duties. The direct supervisor or department director is responsible for recognizing such job changes. Additionally, an employee who believes his or her job is not properly evaluated may request of his or her supervisor a reassessment. 
(2)  When the supervisor and department director conclude that a material, significant, and permanent change in job duties has occurred, a job analysis questionnaire (JAQ) should be completed by the employee, reviewed by the supervisor and sent through the department director to human resources. 
(3)  Upon receipt of a newly completed JAQ, human resources will perform an assessment of the duties and responsibilities of the position using a review of relative internal worth and a review of published salary surveys. This process may include an interview with the employee and/or supervisor. Following this evaluation, human resources will determine if the job should remain as presently assigned or if a new assignment is appropriate. The department director will be notified in writing of the results. 
(4)  If upon the evaluation of a job, human resources determines that a job is still within the same pay grade, no salary adjustment will be made. In the instance where an employee's job is reassigned to a lower pay grade, the employee will be moved to the step that is equal to or immediately above the employee's current salary in the new pay grade; however, the reclassified pay grade maximum will define the limit of future pay increases. In the instance where an employee's job is reassigned to a higher pay grade, generally the employee's pay shall be adjusted in an amount equal to at least two steps at the pay grade immediately before the reclassification to the higher pay grade. Where such a change has a neutral budget impact, such change may be approved by the city administrator. Where such a change impacts a department's budget, such change must be approved by the board of aldermen. 
(5)  When there is disagreement regarding the reassessment of a position, an appeal may be made in writing to the director of human resources. 
(i)  Establishing initial pay for new hires. It is the goal of the city to offer wages that attract the best possible employees. It is also the goal of the city to ensure pay fairness among employees within similar job titles. Therefore, a new employee's initial pay should be set in consideration of the candidate's qualifications as defined by required knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs), the pay of other similarly employed individuals, the pay and pay scales of supervised employees and external market factors. The following procedures will be followed for establishing initial pay for newly hired employees. 
(1)  New hires must be offered at least the minimum of the salary range of the position. The department director will carefully review the applicant's qualifications in relation to the job's KSAs, external market factors and the current wages of individuals employed in similar titles. It is typical that human resources will provide guidance to the department director regarding market pay for the position. It is anticipated that most salary offers will be between Steps 1-7 of the pay grade. 
(2)  The department director will recommend to human resources a beginning salary that is attractive to the prospective employee, addresses market pay influences and is fair to existing employees. Beginning salaries for new employees should not be set at a rate greater than the salaries of existing employees with equivalent qualifications within the same job title in order to reduce the possibility of compression issues. 
(3)  Salary offers will be prepared by the hiring manager and forwarded to the department director, city administrator and HR for approval. The hiring manager may then communicate the offer to the prospective employee or defer to HR. 
(4)  A new city employee is usually hired at step one of the applicable pay grade. However, in special circumstances, the city administrator may authorize a higher step rate for a newly appointed employee based on experience of the prospective employee, or in unusual circumstances, where market conditions prohibit hiring within the authorized hiring pay grade and/or the current pay. Current city employees who move to a new position and are not considered newly appointed may have pay set above step one based only on a previous rate of pay. 
(5)  No internal equity adjustments will be made based upon a new hire's rate of pay. Any new hires above minimum required written justification to be included on the initial personnel action form/wage adjustment form. 
(j)  Assignment of a new job to a pay grade. Human resources is responsible for the assessment of proposed new positions and subsequent assignment to a pay grade. All jobs will be assessed according to the city's compensation plan based on published salary data and internal comparable value. This plan establishes a consistent basis for measuring and ranking the relative market worth of each job. The following procedures will be followed for assignment of new positions to a pay grade. 
(1)  Following approval to create a new position, the department director, or a designee, completes a job analysis questionnaire (JAQ) or drafts a job description describing the duties to be assigned to the position. 
(2)  The department director submits the JAQ/job description to human resources for assessment. 
(3)  All new and existing jobs are to be assigned to a pay grade based on their relative worth either determined by city-approved published salary survey data or the city's determination of relative internal worth. The first step is to determine if market pay information exists for the job in city-approved published salary surveys. Human resources will compare job duties and responsibilities noted on the JAQ/job description to the definitions found in published salary surveys. The job will be assigned to the appropriate pay grade by comparing the salary survey data to the current salary structure. 
(4)  If the job does not sufficiently match a salary survey definition it is compared to other jobs within the department. This is accomplished by evaluating and ranking the position based upon its relative worth. Human resources conducts this assessment of the duties and responsibilities of the position and in consultation with the department director, confirms the position title and assigns a pay grade. 
(5)  The department director is notified in writing of the position title and pay grade assignment after which recruitment for the vacancy may begin. The assigned pay grade provides a spread from a minimum to a maximum rate. New employee compensation within any pay grade is based on such factors as KSAs and external market factors. All new positions must be approved by the board of aldermen. 
(6)  When there is disagreement regarding a position assessment, an appeal may be made to the city administrator. The decision of the city administrator will be final. 
(k)  Market-based pay adjustments. 
(1)  Competitive levels. The city strives to pay at levels that are competitive with the market. Salary adjustments may be made to employee salaries to address significant discrepancies between the city's level of pay and market pay levels for jobs. Actual adjustment amounts will be based on the city's capability to pay. 
(2)  Market-based pay adjustment procedures. Human resources will periodically perform market compatibility evaluations. A market compatibility evaluation may be performed during the first half of each calendar year. The evaluation will be based upon comparable salary and benefit packages of competitor employers in the region. Market adjustments to pay up to 100 percent of the average market rate of pay for critical or essential positions may be recommended by department directors with concurrence by the director of human resources for consideration by the city administrator. All market adjustments must be approved by the board of aldermen. 
(l)  Pay above grade maximum. The compensation system is a tool used by the city to provide a rational basis for pay decisions. It helps to ensure that positions are not underpaid or overpaid based on job responsibilities and the competitive labor markets from which employees are recruited. The pay grade assigned to each position indicates the value of the position within the city. For any employee whose pay is at or above the maximum for his or her pay grade, a temporary increase will be added to the employee's base pay for the fiscal year, not to exceed 2.5 percent. 
(Code 2006, § 135.190; Code 2008, § 135.190; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.250), 12-13-2017) 
ARTICLE III. - COMPENSATION 

Sec. 135.300. - Compensation policy; salary exemption. 
    Non-exempt employees shall be paid for the actual hours that they work in accordance with applicable state and federal laws. Employees who are exempt from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act and thus are paid on a salary basis shall be paid their salary for weeks in which they perform work. A more detailed statement of the city's compensation policies and procedures can be found in the employee manual. 
(Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.300), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.310. - Mandatory and authorized payroll deductions. 
(a)  The following deductions from an employee's gross pay are mandatory: 
(1)  Federal income tax. 
(2)  State income tax. 
(3)  Social security. 
(4)  Medicare. 
(5)  Court-ordered deductions. 
(b)  In addition to mandatory payroll deductions, employees may authorize deductions from their gross pay for participation in certain employee benefit plans. 
(c)  No payroll deductions from an employee's pay, other than deductions required by law or as authorized for participation in certain employee benefit plans, shall be made without prior approval of the city administrator and request of the employee. 
(Code 2006, § 135.680; Code 2008, § 135.680; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.310), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.320. - Overtime and compensatory time. 
(a)  Employees other than commissioned law enforcement personnel and corrections officers who are not exempt from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will be paid at time and one-half the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of 40 hours during the standard workweek. Except in cases of an emergency, prior approval of the department director, or the employee's supervisor or the city administrator is required before working overtime. 
(b)  Commissioned law enforcement personnel and corrections officers who are not exempt from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will be paid at time and one-half their regular rate of pay for hours worked in excess of 851/2 in a 14-consecutive-day period. Hours worked over 851/2 in a 14-consecutive-day period will be paid at time and one-half as overtime or compensatory time, as requested by the employee. If a corrections employee is near 40 hours of his/her maximum accrued comp time and if a commissioned employee is near 100 hours of his/her maximum accrued comp time and then works more than 851/2 hours in a 14-consecutive-day period and such hours will put him/her over the maximum amount of comp time accrued, then such hours will be paid as overtime. Except in cases of an emergency, prior approval of the chief of police, or the employee's supervisor or the city administrator is required before working overtime. 
(c)  As required under state law, employees in amusement or recreational facilities shall receive 11/2 times their regular rate of pay for hours worked in excess of 52 in a single workweek. This may apply to the aquatic, camp and concessions staff. 
(d)  For full-time employees, upon the request of the employee and the approval of the department director or his/her designee, overtime hours may be paid as overtime pay or compensatory time, as requested by the employee. The maximum compensatory time accruals are 40 hours for general employees, dispatch and corrections, and 100 hours for commissioned employees. The city administrator may approve exceptions to these maximum accrual amounts. If an employee is near his/her maximum accrued compensatory time and then works more than 40 hours in a workweek (or 851/2 hours in a 14-day pay period applicable to commissioned employees) and such hours would put the employee over the maximum amount of compensatory time allowed, the hours will be paid as overtime. Part-time employees are not eligible for compensatory time. 
(e)  For purposes of calculating overtime hours: 
(1)  General employees. The phrase "hours worked," as used in this section, includes actual hours worked, vacation time, floating holiday, safety day, employee of the quarter, employee of the year and holidays used in the workweek. 
(2)  Commissioned law enforcement employees. The phrase "hours worked," as used in this section, includes actual hours worked, vacation time, floating holiday, safety day, employee of the quarter, and employee of the year used in the pay period. 
(3)  Exemption. As allowed under the section 7(K) exemption of the FLSA (for commissioned officers and correction technicians), any combination of the above hours, not including holiday hours, exceeding 85.50 hours in a two-week pay period, will generate overtime. 
(f)  When an employee is required to work additional hours during a workweek in response to an unscheduled designated health/life/safety urgent event, the hours used to calculate overtime hours for such workweek shall include all hours actually worked during the workweek as well as any approved leave time taken during the workweek, including vacation time, floating holiday, safety day, day off for employee of the quarter, day off for employee of the year, holiday, sick time, jury duty, compensatory time taken and any safety day taken. These events may include significant weather events, water main breaks, flooding, etc. Official designation of each event shall be made by the department director and approved by the city administrator based on the individual circumstances per departmental procedures. 
(g)  Distribution of overtime. Overtime opportunities will be distributed as equitably as possible to employees working in the appropriate classification within a department as determined by the department director or his/her designee. 
(h)  Mandatory overtime. Employees may be required to work overtime as and when determined by the department director or his/her designee. 
(i)  Notice for mandatory overtime. Employees required to work overtime will be given as much advance notice as is reasonably possible under the circumstances. 
(j)  All overtime/compensatory time will be entered on an employee's time card. 
(Code 2006, §§ 135.300, 135.310; Code 2008, §§ 135.300 135.310; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.320), 12-13-2017; Ord. No. 2018-3858, § 1, 4-25-2018; Ord. No. 3878, § 1, 6-27-2018) 
Sec. 135.330. - Working on holidays. 
    A full-time non-exempt employee working on a holiday shall be paid at 11/2 times his/her regular rate of pay for the hours worked, plus such employee will receive holiday pay for such holiday. Note: Employees are not allowed to trade working a holiday for another day off. However, if the employee and supervisor agree this time may be transferred to compensatory time at the rate of 11/2 times the hours worked. 
(Code 2006, § 135.310; Code 2008, § 135.310; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.330), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.340. - Call back to work. 
(a)  If an employee is called back to work after the end of his/her regular shift, he/she shall be paid a minimum of two hours at the rate of 11/2 times the regular rate. Non-exempt clerical personnel who are required to attend and take minutes for meetings of the board of aldermen, planning and zoning and park board or other city boards or commissions that occur at times other than the employee's regularly scheduled shift shall be paid a minimum of two hours at a rate of 11/2 times the regular rate of pay for scheduled meetings. 
(b)  Call back to work does not apply if responding after hours is a regular part of an employee's job and the employee is not physically called back to work. See the mobile device policy in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.310; Code 2008, § 135.310; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.340), 12-13-2017; Ord. No. 3878, § 2, 6-27-2018) 
Sec. 135.350. - Workweeks, pay periods and paychecks. 
(a)  The workweek for all employees other than commissioned law enforcement personnel and corrections officers is from 12:01 a.m. Sunday to 12:00 midnight of the following Saturday. 
(b)  Biweekly pay periods are from 12:01 a.m. Sunday to 12:00 midnight of the second following Saturday. 
(c)  The city will issue biweekly paychecks by 2:00 p.m. on the Friday following the close of the pay period. Direct deposit is mandatory for all city employees. 
(d)  Along with the employee's paycheck, the city will submit an electronic check stub indicating gross pay, net pay, total regular hours paid, total of overtime hours paid and all other standard deductions the employee has authorized, as well as social security and income tax information (both federal and state). 
(Code 2006, § 135.340; Code 2008, § 135.340; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.350), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.360. - Payroll advances. 
    Under no conditions will the city make payroll advances. 
(Code 2006, § 135.300; Code 2008, § 135.300; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.360), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.370. - Separation pay. 
    Upon separation from city employment, an employee will be paid for regular and overtime hours worked, unused accrued vacation and unused accrued compensatory time. Following the required notice of resignation, sick leave, floating holiday and safety day may not be used in the last two weeks of employment. Note: Only employees with more than six months of continuous service will receive payment of unused accrued vacation upon separation from employment. 
(Code 2006, § 135.300; Code 2008, § 135.300; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.370), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.380. - Standby-duty pay. 
(a)  The city recognizes that due to the requirement to provide 24/7 service and be responsive to time-sensitive demands beyond regularly scheduled work hours in some business areas, some non-exempt employees may be required to be on standby-duty. Non-exempt employees assigned to standby-duty shall receive $1.50 per hour of standby-duty pay in addition to call-back pay for actual hours worked. 
(1)  If an employee is called back into work, the "call back to work" policy as outlined in section 135.340 will apply. 
(2)  Hours accrued while assigned to standby-duty status are not considered time worked and are not considered for calculating overtime. 
(3).  Employees must report any substantive time spent working offsite to the supervisor upon return to the worksite. Failure to report substantive hours worked may result in disciplinary action. 
(b)  A more detailed statement of the city's standby-duty policy and the procedures can be found in the employee manual. 
(Ord. No. 2018-3858, § 2, 4-25-2018) 
ARTICLE IV. - RECRUITMENT AND APPOINTMENT 

Sec. 135.400. - Notification of vacancy. 
    Notification shall be published by posting announcements on official bulletin boards and in such other places and through such media as human resources shall determine. The announcement shall specify the title, pay grade and job description of the position, the minimum qualifications, time, place and manner of making application, closing dates for receiving applications and other pertinent information. 
(Code 2006, § 135.200; Code 2008, § 135.200; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.400), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.410. - Eligibility. 
(a)  The primary considerations in the recruitment of personnel will be on the basis of the technical competence, including ability, training and experience, and the personal integrity of the applicant. 
(b)  Candidates will be recruited from a geographical area as wide as is necessary to ensure obtaining a pool of well-qualified applicants. 
(c)  In order to ensure proper response time in case of an emergency, commissioned police officers must live within 45 minutes' drive time of the city's law enforcement center. 
(d)  No city employee or applicant for employment shall be either favored or discriminated against in appointment, promotions or disciplinary actions because of age, race, color, national origin, ancestry, religion, sex, pregnancy (including childbirth, lactation and related medical conditions), physical or mental disability, genetic information (including testing and characteristics), veteran status, uniformed service member status, or any other status protected by federal, state, or local laws. 
(Code 2006, § 135.230; Code 2008, § 135.230; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.410), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.420. - Appointments. 
    Appointments to positions with the city shall be made on the basis of ability, training and experience, with provision being made for reasonable accommodations when necessary. The hiring of new employees and filling of vacant positions shall be accomplished as follows: 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in chapter 120 regarding appointment of officers, the board of aldermen shall be responsible for appointing department director positions. 
(2)  The city administrator shall be responsible for hiring all uncontracted positions within the guidelines of this chapter. 
(Code 2006, § 135.240; Code 2008, § 135.240; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.420), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.430. - Examinations. 
(a)  Any applicant offered a position is required to take and pass a pre-employment physical examination and drug screening at city expense. Additional examinations may be required. A more detailed statement of the city's policies and procedures regarding the use of pre-employment physical examinations and drug screenings of applicants for employment can be found in the employee manual. 
(b)  Any applicant for a position may be required to take a written, oral or psychological examination. Examinations may include an evaluation of trade or professional skills, oral interviews and a background investigation. 
(Code 2006, § 135.210; Code 2008, § 135.210; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.430), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.440. - Disqualification. 
(a)  Applications may be disqualified if the applicant: 
(1)  Is physically or mentally unfit for the performance (after reasonable accommodations have been made) of the duties of the position for which he/she seeks appointment; 
(2)  Tests positive for drugs in his/her examination; 
(3)  Has made any false statement of any material fact; or 
(4)  Practiced or attempted to practice any deception or fraud in his/her application. 
(b)  Conviction of crime may also be cause for disqualification. An applicant who has been disqualified for employment will not be reconsidered for employment for 180 days from the date of disqualification. 
(Code 2006, § 135.220; Code 2008, § 135.220; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.440), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.450. - Nepotism. 
(a)  Within the constraints of article VII, section 6, of the state constitution, it is the city's policy to hire the best-qualified employees available for all positions. In addition to the prohibitions set forth in article VII, section 6, of the state constitution, two members of an immediate family shall not be employed under the same supervisor; nor shall two members of an immediate family be employed at the same time, regardless of the department, if such employment would result in an employee supervising a member of such employee's immediate family. This policy applies to hiring of new employees, promotions, demotions, transfers, and reinstatements. Present employees who become married to other present employees will be permitted to continue employment, but not in a direct supervisor/subordinate relationship. Should the situation arise, one employee will be required to transfer to another department/shift or resign employment immediately. 
(b)  Seasonal/part-time positions may be granted exemption by the city administrator. 
(c)  For the purpose of this policy, the following definitions apply: 
    Department means any unit separately defined as such or as designated by the city administrator. 
    Immediate family means spouse, father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, first cousin, nephew, niece, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, grandmother, grandfather, stepfather, stepmother, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half-brother and half-sister, stepchildren or stepgrandparents. 
    Position means any employment situation, either salaried or contractual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.280; Code 2008, § 135.280; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.450), 12-13-2017) 
ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE PERFORMANCE AND CONDUCT 

Sec. 135.500. - Employee relations. 
    The city's goal is to create and maintain an environment in which employees at all levels deal openly and directly with issues and concerns. When all employees collectively commit to an open and direct approach to address issues and concerns, the city has a greater opportunity to maintain an excellent work environment, clear communications and positive attitudes within its workforce. The city will demonstrate its commitment to employees by ensuring that the city administrator, department directors and other supervisors carefully listen and effectively respond to employee concerns. 
(Code 2006, § 135.410; Code 2008, § 135.410; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.500), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.510. - Grievance policy. 
    The city shall maintain an open door grievance policy for all city employees to discuss any city-related concerns. A more detailed statement of the city's grievance policy, the procedures for reporting a grievance and the procedures for responding to employee grievances shall be addressed in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.420; Code 2008, § 135.420; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.510), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.520. - Performance evaluation report. 
    All supervisors shall submit employee performance evaluations on every employee per the performance evaluation policy in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.430; Code 2008, § 135.430; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.520), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.530. - Secondary employment. 
    Employees may not perform work for other employers ("secondary employment") which conflicts with or in any way negatively affects their ability to satisfactorily perform the job-related requirements of their city employment. The department director shall be notified using the secondary employment form and the employee must receive written approval from the department director prior to performing any secondary employment. The secondary employment form shall be included in the employee personnel file. 
(Code 2006, § 135.450; Code 2008, § 135.450; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.530), 12-13-2017) 
ARTICLE VI. - DISCIPLINARY ACTION 

Sec. 135.600. - Discipline. 
(a)  All employees are expected to meet the city's standards of employee performance. Employee performance encompasses many factors, including attendance, punctuality, personal conduct, job proficiency, conduct on or off duty (if it brings discredit to the city) and general compliance with the this Municipal Code, policies and procedures including those policies and procedures as outlined in the city employee manual. 
(b)  If an employee does not meet these standards, the supervisor will initiate progressive discipline. The progressive disciplinary process may result in a verbal or written reprimand, disciplinary probation, suspension, demotion or dismissal. In certain instances where an employee's conduct or omission is egregious, such conduct or omission may result in immediate discharge or other discipline that does not strictly follow the progressive discipline process. 
(c)  The city administrator must approve a disciplinary probation, suspension, demotion or dismissal of a general employee. 
(d)  A more detailed statement of the city's disciplinary action policy and the applicable procedures, including a listing of improper conduct and the progressive disciplinary process shall be addressed in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.540; Code 2008, § 135.540; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.600), 12-13-2017) 
ARTICLE VII. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 

Sec. 135.700. - Employee benefit plans established. 
(a)  The city has established a variety of employee benefit plans designed to assist employees. The city reserves the right to amend, modify or terminate, in whole or in part, any or all of the provisions of the benefit plans described in this chapter or in the employee manual. Further, the city reserves the exclusive right in its sole and absolute discretion to administer, apply and interpret the benefit plans described in this chapter and to decide all matters arising in connection with the operation or administration of such plans. 
(b)  Any change in employee benefit plans will be announced and described to employees by memo, letter, employee meeting or other appropriate communication method. 
(Code 2006, § 135.670; Code 2008, § 135.670; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.700), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.710. - Holidays. 
(a)  Regular paid holidays for all full-time city employees shall be as established by the board of aldermen. Such holidays shall include two floating holidays for each such employee. The floating holiday shall be of the employee's choice with the approval of the supervisor. City Hall shall be closed on the following named holidays, except the floating holiday. If any of the holidays listed below fall on Saturday, the holiday will be recognized the Friday prior to the holiday. If any such holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday will be recognized as a paid holiday. For commissioned and noncommissioned police personnel (i.e., dispatch and corrections assigned to shift work0, holiday pay will be based upon the legal holiday. However, in the event the legal holiday falls on the weekend and the police employee is assigned to work on both the legal holiday and the city-observed holiday, such police employee will receive holiday pay for only the legal holiday and not for both days. Records division employees within the police department will observe the holiday on the city-observed holiday. 
(b)  To be eligible for holiday pay, an employee must work the entire workdays preceding and following the paid holiday, unless the employee is on vacation leave or another approved paid absence. 
(c)  The following are paid holidays for full-time city employees: 
New Year's Day (January 1) Martin Luther King Jr. Day Federal President's Day Good Friday Federal Memorial Day Independence Day (July 4) Labor Day Federal Veterans Day Thanksgiving Day after Thanksgiving Christmas Eve Christmas Day (December 25) Two floating holidays  
(d)  The floating holidays must be used within the calendar year. These holidays will not be carried over and the employee will not receive payment if not used within the calendar year. Upon separation from employment, an employee will not receive or be compensated for any unused floating holiday pay, and the floating holidays cannot be used in the last two weeks of employment. 
(e)  Employees who receive the employee of the quarter award by peer nomination shall receive four hours of paid leave. This leave must be used within three months of receipt. 
(f)  Employees who receive the employee of the year award by peer nomination shall receive eight hours of paid leave. This leave must be used within three months of receipt. 
(g)  Employees who receive a safety day award shall receive eight hours of paid leave. This leave time must be used the calendar year in which it was received. This time will not be carried over, and the employee will not receive payment for unused hours. Upon separation employees will not be compensated for unused time, and this time may not be used during the last two weeks of employment. 
(h)  The board of aldermen is authorized to approve employee incentive programs that authorize additional leave days which shall only be approved on a proactive basis. 
(i)  Part-time employees with benefits (those working 1,500 hours or more per year) will receive prorated holiday pay based on the average number of hours worked during the previous month. 
(j)  Police personnel may be scheduled to work on some or all of the above holidays. All Police personnel shall receive eight hours of holiday pay in the pay period in which the holiday occurs. 
(k)  Employees working the day of the holiday will be paid at 11/2 their regular hourly rate for the hours actually worked on such holiday. 
(l)  Any employee that is normally scheduled to work Monday through Friday and who is required to work on the day that the city recognizes a holiday will be paid at a rate of time and one-half times the employee's regular hourly rate for the hours actually worked plus his/her holiday pay. 
(Code 2006, § 135.700; Code 2008, § 135.700; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.710), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.715. - Vacation leave. 
(a)  Full-time employees will accrue vacation on a monthly basis from their initial employment date according to the following schedule: 
Consecutive Length of Service Accrual 6 months 6.67 hours monthly/40 hours in 6 months 1 year 6.67 hours monthly/40 hours in 6 months 2 years, but less than 6 years 6.67 hours monthly/80 hours annually 6 years, but less than 11 years 10 hours monthly/120 hours annually 11 years, but less than 20 years 13.33 hours monthly/160 hours annually 20 years or more 16.67 hours monthly/200 hours annually  
(b)  Employees are not authorized to use the accumulated vacation leave until they have completed six months of continuous service, unless otherwise authorized by the department director and the city administrator. After six months of continuous service, an employee may use vacation time as it accrues. Vacation leave must be earned before it is used. 
(c)  Vacation leave may not be taken in increments of less than one-quarter hour. 
(d)  Part-time employees with benefits (those working 1,500 or more hours in a year) will receive prorated vacation based on average hours worked during the previous year. 
(e)  It is in the best interest of each employee's welfare that vacation leave be used on an annual basis. If an employee does not use all of his/her vacation leave in a calendar year, such unused accrued vacation leave may roll-over to the following year, subject to the maximum accruals stated below. Vacation accruals must be in compliance with the scale below as of December 31 of each year. 
Annual Accrual Maximum Accrual 80 hours 120 hours 120 hours 180 hours 160 hours 240 hours 200 or more hours 300 hours  
(f)  On January 1 of each year, vacation hours in excess of the maximum accrual amounts will be surrendered to the city without pay to the employee. 
(g)  For the purposes of recruitment and appointment, the city administrator has discretion to negotiate additional vacation time for all general employees. 
(Code 2006, § 135.710; Code 2008, § 135.710; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.715), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.720. - Insurance. 
(a)  Full-time city employees are eligible to receive health, dental, vision, long term disability and life insurance benefits to the extent that such employee benefits are provided by the board of aldermen. All insurance questions should be directed to human resources. 
(b)  Insurance becomes effective on the first day of employment. 
(1)  Medical insurance. Full-time employees are covered under a medical plan. The premium is shared between the employee and the city. Dependent coverage is available at an additional cost. Part-time employees who work more than 1,500 hours annually are eligible for health insurance for the employee only. 
(2)  Dental insurance. Full-time employees are covered under a dental plan. The premium is shared between the employee and the city. Dependent coverage is available at an additional cost. Part-time employees who work more than 1,500 hours annually are eligible for dental insurance for employee only. 
(3)  Vision care insurance. Full-time employees are covered under a vision plan with the full cost of the premium paid by the city. Dependent coverage is available at an additional cost. Part-time employees who work more than 1,500 hours annually are eligible for vision care insurance for employee only. 
(4)  Life insurance. Full-time employees are insured for one times their annual base salary. The full cost of the premium is paid by the city. Voluntary coverage for the employee and dependents is available for an additional cost. 
(5)  Long term disability. Full-time employees only are currently covered under a long-term disability plan. The full cost of the premium is paid by the city. 
(Code 2006, § 135.720; Code 2008, § 135.720; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2016-3650, 9-28-2016; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.720), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.725. - Retirement. 
(a)  Employees who work more than 1,500 hours per year qualify for the city's retirement program. 
(b)  LAGERS was created and is governed by the state to provide retirement, survivors and disability benefits to the state's local government employees in the most efficient and economical manner possible. As such, LAGERS is a nonprofit entity which has the responsibility of administering the law in accordance with the expressed intent of the General Assembly. 
(c)  An employee who retires at age 62 may be kept in the group dental and medical insurance program at the retired employee's expense. An employee who has attained the age of 55 years (50 for commissioned police personnel) and has 30 years' of service with the city may retire with full group medical and dental insurance benefits through the city's group plans at the retired employee's expense until they become eligible for Medicare. Employees electing this coverage will be required to pay the monthly premium for selected plans equal to the COBRA rate. This benefit applies to the employee only. 
(Code 2006, § 135.730; Code 2008, § 135.730; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.725), 12-13-2017; Ord. No. 2018-3858, § 3, 4-25-2018) 
Sec. 135.730. - Sick leave. 
(a)  It is important that every employee be on the job regularly. For this reason, careful attention is given to absence record and overall dependability. The city recognizes, however, that an employee, employee's spouse, children, parents or parents-in-law may occasionally be suffer from an injury or illness that requires the employee to be absent. As a result, the city's sick leave policy is designed to provide protection to employees against loss of income during unavoidable illness or injury. 
(b)  Full-time employees will be credited with eight hours of sick leave for each full month worked. Part-time employees who work 1,500 or more hours annually will be credited with prorated sick leave hours based upon the total number of hours worked each month. For the protection of employees in the event of a long-term illness, sick leave may be accumulated up to 1,200 hours. A more detailed statement of the city's sick leave policy, the procedures for accumulating and requesting to use paid sick and the city's annual wellness benefits can be found in the employee manual. 
(c)  An active employee who qualifies for retirement under the city's retirement plan (LAGERS), and who applies for retirement and immediately retires from active service, is eligible to receive payment for up to 720 hours of accrued and unused sick leave. In the event of an employee's death, the designated beneficiary is eligible to receive payment for up to 720 hours of accrued and unused sick leave. 
(Code 2006, § 135.740; Code 2008, § 135.740; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.730), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.735. - Personal days, using accumulated sick leave. 
(a)  After working for six consecutive months, and accumulating at least 40 hours of sick leave, full-time employees are eligible to take up to 24 hours of personal time off using accrued sick leave. 
(b)  These hours may be used, for example, as vacation days. An employee does, however, need to have advance approval from his/her supervisor before using accrued time. 
(c)  Use of these personal days will be deducted from an employee's regular sick leave accrual. A maximum of 24 hours can be used by an employee as personal time in a calendar year. Personal days using accrued sick leave may not be carried over to the next calendar year. If an employee has not used any days by participating in this program, accrued but unused days will carry over as regular sick days. Personal sick leave may not be used during the last two weeks of employment. 
(d)  When employees have accumulated 240 hours of sick leave, they are eligible for an additional personal day (eight hours) using sick leave accrual (total of 32 personal hours annually). 
(e)  Part-time employees with benefits (part-time employees who work more than 1,500 hours annually) may also participate in this program on a pro-rated basis in accordance with hours regularly worked during the previous months. 
(Code 2006, § 135.750; Code 2008, § 135.750; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.735), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.740. - Funeral leave. 
(a)  In the event of a death in an employee's immediate family, he/she shall be granted up to three work days off with pay. For this purpose, the term "immediate family" is defined as: 
(1)  Spouse; 
(2)  Child or stepchild; 
(3)  Parent or stepparent; 
(4)  Sibling, stepsibling; 
(5)  Grandparent or stepgrandparent; 
(6)  Grandchild; and 
(7)  Members of the employee's spouse's immediate family. 
(b)  In the event of a death in an employee's relative who is not an immediate family member as defined above, the employee shall be granted up to one paid day of funeral leave. 
(c)  In extenuating circumstances, the city administrator may approve additional unpaid leave. 
(d)  If additional time off is required because the employee's absence from the family would create a hardship, the department director may grant the use of sick leave or vacation leave. 
(e)  In the event of a current or former employee's death, employees who wish to do so will be granted time off to attend the local funeral. 
(Code 2006, § 135.760; Code 2008, § 135.760; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.740), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.745. - Injury leave. 
    Through workers' compensation benefits and the city's injury leave policy, employees, regardless of their employment status, will be granted leave with pay in the event of an injury on the job which renders them incapable of performing their normal duties, unless it can be shown that the injury occurred as a result of a willful or negligent act by the injured employee. A more detailed statement of the city's injury leave and workers' compensation policies, and the procedures for reporting workplace injuries can be found in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.770; Code 2008, § 135.770; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.745), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.750. - Jury duty leave. 
    An employee may be granted leave with pay when required to be absent from work for jury duty or as a trial witness. To qualify for jury pay the employee must present a copy of the voucher received from the circuit clerk's office to the payroll clerk's office. The employee must also release any payments received from the court by endorsing the checks and submitting to payroll. If not reimbursed after 90 days, the amount of any stipend for serving on a jury will be deducted from the employee's next paycheck. The city does not reimburse mileage for employees serving on a jury or as a witness at a trial, unless expressly related to the employee's job duties. 
(Code 2006, § 135.790; Code 2008, § 135.790; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.750), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.755. - Family and medical leave. 
(a)  The city will comply with all applicable provisions of the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). 
(b)  Eligible employees may be entitled to leave under the FMLA for specified family and medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA benefits, an employee must have been employed by the city for at least 12 months and have worked for at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the start of the leave. 
(c)  The city will grant FMLA leave to eligible employees for the following reasons: 
(1)  The employee's serious health condition; 
(2)  The birth and care of the employee's child; 
(3)  Placement with the employee of a child for adoption or foster care; 
(4)  Care of the employee's spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition; 
(5)  Because of a "qualifying exigency" relating to the active-duty status or call to active-duty in the armed forces of a spouse, son, daughter, or parent of the employee, including those contingencies set forth in the applicable regulations, summarized as follows: 
a.  Short-notice deployment; 
b.  Military events and related activities; 
c.  To arrange for childcare, or provide childcare on an urgent basis, or for school activities; 
d.  To make financial or legal arrangements; 
e.  To attend counseling; 
f.  To spend time with the service member while on short-term leave; 
g.  For post-deployment activities; and 
h.  For other activities in accordance with the regulations; 
(6)  Because care is required for a family member or next of kin who is a member of the armed forces, including a member of the National Guard or Reserves, who is undergoing medical treatment, recuperation, or therapy, or is otherwise in outpatient status on the temporary disability retired list, for a serious injury or illness. 
(d)  Leave for the birth and care, or placement and care of a child must conclude within 12 months of the birth or placement of the child. FMLA applies equally to male and female employees. 
(e)  A more detailed statement of the city's family and medical leave policy, and the procedures for seeking such leave can be found in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.800; Code 2008, § 135.800; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.755), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.760. - Training leave. 
    Upon request by the supervisor and approval by the city administrator, an employee may be granted leave with pay to attend training programs or professional conferences. A more detailed statement of the city's training leave policy, and the procedures for seeking such leave can be found in the employee manual. 
(Code 2006, § 135.810; Code 2008, § 135.810; Ord. No. 2481, § 1, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2017-3808, § 1(135.760), 12-13-2017) 
Sec. 135.765. - Military leave. 
(a)  Compliance with applicable laws. The city will comply with the Uniform Services Employment and Re-Employment Rights Act (USERRA) and applicable state laws concerning employees who participate in the National Guard and Reserves. The benefits outlined in the section are based on the federal fiscal year of October 1 through September 30. 
(b)  Annual service requirement. Pursuant to USERRA, employees who are members of the reserve components of any branch of the United States military service or National Guard shall be granted up to 15 calendar days of leave with pay for the purpose of participating in required annual active duty for training. Participants must notify their supervisor at least 30 days in advance, unless advance notice is excused under applicable federal or state law. A copy of their orders must be submitted to human resources. 
(c)  National Guard and Reserve service.
