No portion of any billboard may fluctuate in light intensity or use intermittent strobe or moving light or light that changes in intensity in sudden transitory bursts, streams, zoom, twinkles, sparkles or that in any manner creates the illusion of movement. 
(vi)  Conversion. All conversions of existing static billboard (traditional) to an EMC billboard must comply with current code requirements for off-premises advertising in reference to sign size and height. 
(vii)  Spacing. No EMC billboard shall be located within 500 feet of an existing freestanding on-premises electronic message sign. 
(viii)  Audio speakers. Audio speakers are prohibited in association with any electronic message center billboard. 
(ix)  Text size requirements. Every line of copy and graphics displayed on an electronic billboard shall be at least 12 inches in height on a road with a speed limit of 45 miles per hour or greater and 54 miles per hour or less, and at least 15 inches in height on a road with a speed limit of 55 miles per hour or greater. 
(x)  Malfunction and noncompliance. Electronic billboards shall be designed and equipped to freeze the device in one position if a malfunction occurs. The electronic billboards shall be equipped with a means to immediately discontinue the display if it malfunctions, and the sign owner shall immediately stop the dynamic display when notified by the city that it is not complying with standards of this Code. 
(xi)  Provision of community and public service messaging. The owner of an electronic billboard shall enter into an agreement with the city to provide the city no less than five hours (1,800 ten-second spots) per month per electronic billboard in the city for community and public service messages at such times as shall be determined by the city. 
(xii)  Number of faces. The maximum number of sign faces or surfaces permitted on the electronic billboard shall not exceed two. 
2.  Static billboards (traditional); lighting. 
(i)  No revolving or rotating beam or beacon of light that simulates any emergency light or device shall be permitted as part of any sign. No flashing, intermittent or moving light or lights will be permitted except scoreboards and other illuminated signs designating public service information, such as time, date or temperature or similar information, will be allowed. 
(ii)  External lighting such as floodlights, thin line and gooseneck reflectors are permitted, provided the light source is directed upon the face of the sign and is effectively shielded so as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed into any portion of the main traveled way of the interstate or federal-aid primary highway and lights are not of such intensity so as to cause glare, impair the vision of the driver of a motor vehicle, or otherwise interfere with a driver's operation of a motor vehicle. 
(iii)  No sign shall be so illuminated that glare interferes with the effectiveness of, or obscures, an official traffic sign, device or signal, nor shall the illumination be directed toward any residential area, whereby producing glare. 
(iv)  The maximum average lighting intensity level for such sign shall be 20 footcandles. 
b.  Size of signs. 
1.  The maximum area for any one sign shall be 672 square feet with a maximum height of 20 feet and a maximum length of 50 feet, inclusive of border and trim but excluding the base or apron, supports, other structural members and excluding cut-out sign features not exceeding ten square feet. 
2.  The maximum size limitations shall apply to each side of a sign structure, and signs may be placed back to back, double faced or in V-type construction. 
c.  Spacing of signs. 
1.  Interstate highways and freeways on federal-aid primary system. No off-premises billboard shall be hereafter erected within one mile of an existing sign on the same side of the highway. 
2.  Non-freeway federal-aid primary highways. No off-premises sign structure shall be erected within 2,000 feet of an existing sign on the same side of the highway. 
3.  Signs not to interfere with traffic signs, signals, etc. No sign shall be located in such a manner as to obstruct or otherwise physically interfere with the effectiveness of any official traffic sign, signal, or device or obstruct or physically interfere with a motor vehicle operator's view of approaching, merging or intersecting traffic. 
4.  Measurement. The measurement in this subsection (c)(3)c shall be minimum distances between outdoor advertising sign structures measured along the nearest edge of the pavement between points directly opposite the signs along each side of the highway and shall apply only to outdoor advertising sign structures located on the same side of the highway involved. 
5.  Conversion of static billboard (traditional) to an EMC billboard. Conversion of a static (traditional) billboard to an EMC billboard shall only be permitted if the proposed EMC billboard is at least 10,560 feet (two miles) from any existing EMC billboard on the same side of the highway for a non-freeway federal-aid primary highway or 10,560 feet (two miles) from any existing EMC billboard on the same side of highway for interstate highways and freeways on federal-aid system. 
d.  Setbacks, safety clearances and height. In order to provide a safety zone to prevent injury or property damage from collapse of billboard caused by acts of God or other causes, each off-premises billboard shall have minimum setbacks of the following: 
1.  Each off-premises sign structure shall be built within the first 100 feet adjacent to the right-of-way of any interstate or primary highway; 
2.  At least ten feet from all property lines; and 
3.  At least 90 feet from all roofed structures from all points of the off-premises billboard. 
In order to further provide a safety zone to prevent injury or property damage from collapse of billboards caused by acts of God or other causes, each off-premises billboard shall have a maximum height of 45 feet. In addition, the applicant for permit shall present documentation to the reasonable satisfaction of the community development director that the applicant has secured the legally enforceable right to prevent the erection of structures within the setback zones. No city building permit shall be issued for construction of any building within the setback/clearance zone for any off-premises billboard. 
e.  Setbacks at highway interchanges. No off-premises billboard shall be located adjacent to or within 1,000 feet of any interchange existing or approved for construction by the state highway and transportation department, intersection at grade or safety rest area. The 1,000 feet shall be measured from the beginning or ending of the pavement widening at the exit from or entrance to the main traveled way. 
f.  Setbacks from residential and public activity areas. No off-premises billboard or conversion of a static billboard (traditional) to an EMC billboard shall be located within 1,000 feet of land zoned for residential or public activity purposes. 
g.  Landscaping, lighting and fencing. Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall receive approval for a plan for landscaping, billboard lighting and fencing around the proposed off-premises billboard to ensure that the structure will be aesthetically compatible with its surroundings and the aesthetic standard of the community and neighboring property, insofar as may be practicable, as well as safe and secure from trespassers or vandals. Such plans shall be reviewed and approved by the planning and zoning commission. In determining whether the landscaping plan is reasonably suitable, the planning and zoning commission shall take into consideration the nature of the location, the impact on surrounding properties, the safety and security of the proposed off-premises billboard, and the relative cost of the landscaping, lighting and fencing to the applicant in relationship to the overall impact upon the property values in the immediate area which would be caused by a lack of such landscaping, lighting and fencing for the proposed off-premises billboard. 
h.  Nuisances. Any off-premises billboard which, because of lack of maintenance, upkeep, vandalism, accumulation of litter, refuse or debris, or the deterioration of landscaping, lighting or fencing, becomes unsightly or unsafe is hereby declared to be a nuisance and shall be subject to abatement by the city in the same manner as all other nuisances on private property. 
i.  Service drives. Direct access to off-premises billboards from curb cuts along a state highway or service road shall be prohibited, unless approved by MoDOT. Direct access shall be gained through paved roads and drives that are private and internal to a lot or parcel. All vehicles, equipment and people used to build, service, maintain and repair such signs must confine their activity so as not to interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic on public roads. 
j.  Underground utilities. All on-site electric service shall be installed underground, except those overhead distribution feeder lines in locations as approved by the city, under the standards in section 410.340. 
k.  Permits. 
1.  The city shall not issue a permit for any new off-premises billboards without a permit having first been issued by the highway and transportation department. 
2.  The city shall charge an initial permit fee of $500.00 for initial inspection to ensure compliance with the city wind load and electrical requirements when the sign is first erected. 
3.  Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall submit the following certification for the appropriate licensed professional regarding the following: certification from a licensed engineer that the soil and subsoil surface is capable of accepting the projected loads; certification from an electrical engineer as to the electrical portion of the sign; certification from a structural engineer as to the structural strength of the sign and certified outboundary survey of the site and its setback/clearance zone. 
4.  Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall submit a sign survey to indicate the relative vertical and horizontal distances between the proposed sign and all other pole-mounted signs within 2,000 feet. If by reason of height, size or spacing the proposed sign creates a significant disharmony with pole-mounted signs within 2,000 feet or unreasonably detracts from the visibility of other neighboring signs or properties, the community development director may require reasonable modifications of the sign's dimensions to cure such deficiencies as a condition to granting a permit. 
l.  Annual inspection. All billboards shall have an annual inspection to verify compliance with all applicable city land use standards. 
(d)  Annual inspection. Owners of all signs erected shall be required to submit an inspection report from a state licensed engineer as to the sign's structural integrity. Such certification shall be done on or before June 1 of each year. Failure to submit a report shall result in the immediate revocation of the sign's permit. 
(Code 2006, § 405.635; Code 2008, § 405.630; Ord. No. 1761, § 1, 5-23-2001; Ord. No. 1843, § 7, 3-27-2002; Ord. No. 2484, § 4, 3-22-2006; Ord. No. 2950, § 3, 11-19-2008; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011; Ord. No. 3298, § 1, 5-22-2013; Ord. No. 3848, §§ 1-3, 4-25-2018) 
CHAPTER 410. - SUBDIVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 410.010. - Purpose. 
(a)  Land subdivision is the first step in the process of community development. Once land has been divided into streets, blocks, lots and open spaces, a pattern has been established which usually determines how well the community needs for residence, business and industry will be met. It also determines to a great extent how well the community will be able to handle its traffic circulation problems, how well it will be able to provide the main services demanded of it. 
(b)  After land has been subdivided and publicly recorded, it is very difficult and costly to correct defects and deficiencies in the subdivision layout and in the facilities provided. In addition, a subdivided area sooner or later becomes a public responsibility in that roads and streets must be maintained and various public services customary to urban areas must be provided. The welfare of the entire community is thereby affected in many important respects. The guidance of land development in harmony with community objectives is, therefore, a matter of serious public concern, and it is in the interest of the public, the developer and the future owners that subdivisions be conceived, designed and developed in accordance with sound rules and proper minimum standards. 
(c)  The purpose of these regulations, then, is to control the division of land within the city in order to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the city by regulating the division and redivision of land in order to lessen congestion in the streets and highways; to further the orderly development and appropriate use of land; to establish accurate records of land subdivisions; to protect land title; to implement the various chapters and components of the comprehensive plan; to secure safety from fire and other dangers; to facilitate adequate and coordinated provision for transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, playgrounds and other public requirements; to facilitate the further division of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land; to preserve natural features such as stands of trees, streams, significant rock formations, historical landmarks; and, in general, to facilitate the orderly, coordinated, efficient and economic development of the city. 
(Code 2008, § 410.020; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.020. - Authorization and jurisdiction. 
(a)  These subdivision regulations are adopted pursuant to the authority granted by the city's authority to regulate the public health, welfare and safety and the authority granted by, among other places, RSMo chs. 89 and 445. The city planning and zoning commission, which was established in accordance with RSMo ch. 89 , has fulfilled the requirement set forth in the applicable sections of the revised statutes as necessary for the adoption of such regulations by the board of aldermen. These regulations provide a procedure and minimum standards of design and construction by which the city planning and zoning commission and board of aldermen can equitably appraise all proposed plats for land subdivision, plat preparation, review and approval requirements. 
(b)  The subdivision and resubdivision of land within the city shall be upon a plat and submitted to the city planning and zoning commission for its approval or disapproval. With the exception of parcels divided under certain special procedures in article VII of this chapter, the lot split procedure, all record plats shall receive a recommendation by the planning and zoning commission and with the planning commission's approval or disapproval endorsed thereon shall be submitted to the board of aldermen for its consideration and approval or disapproval. No plat shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds, except as provided for in these regulations. No lot subject to these regulations shall be sold unless first established by provisions of these regulations. No building permit shall be issued for construction on a parcel or lot created in violation of these regulations. 
(Code 2008, § 410.030; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.030. - Conflicts with other ordinances. 
    Wherever there is a discrepancy between the minimum standards set forth in or adopted pursuant to these regulations and those of any other lawfully adopted rules, regulations, ordinances or resolutions, the most restrictive or highest standards shall apply. Moreover, nothing in these regulations shall prohibit the subdivider from placing self-imposed restrictions or imposing higher standards than required by these regulations, but not in violation of these regulations, on the development. Such restrictions shall be indicated or attached to the plat for processing by the city and filing with the recorder of deeds. 
(Code 2008, § 410.040; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.040. - Separability. 
    The invalidity of any provision of these regulations shall not invalidate any other part thereof that is not itself invalid. Failure by the city or any officer or employee thereof to comply with the requirements of these subdivision regulations shall not invalidate any action taken by the city hereunder. 
(Code 2008, § 410.050; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.050. - Definitions. 
(a)  In this chapter, the term "used" or "occupied" includes the term "intended," "designed" or "arranged to be used or occupied"; the term "lot" includes the term "plot" or "parcel"; the term "structure" includes the term "building"; and the terms "building" and "structure" include any part thereof. 
(b)  Words used herein but not defined in this chapter but defined in the engineering design manual (found on the city website at www.wentzvillemo.org or the zoning regulations shall have the meaning ascribed to it by the engineering design criteria or engineering design manual or zoning regulations or, if not defined therein, shall be assigned the meaning ascribed via Webster's Dictionary or the American Planning Association Planners Advisory Report. 
(c)  In addition, the following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a secondary means of ingress or egress serving more than one tract of land and used primarily for vehicular service and which may be used for public utility purposes. 
    Amenities. See Subdivision amenities. 
    Approved public water supply means a system approved by the city or other governmental agency that provides water via piping or other constructed conveyance to the public for human consumption. 
    As-built plans means engineering plans of public facilities and roads prepared after construction to show the exact location and dimensions of the facilities and roads as actually installed. 
    Bench mark. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Block means an area of land surrounded by public highways, streets, streams, railroad rights-of-way, parks, rural land, drainage channels or other similar areas or facilities. 
    Bond means any form of security including a cash deposit, surety bond, collateral, property or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to the board of aldermen. 
    Building means any structure that is affixed to the land, has one or more floors, one or more external walls and is built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals or movable property of any kind. 
    Building line means a line or lines on a plat designating the area outside of which buildings and certain structures may not be erected. 
    City means the incorporated area of the city as it existed at the time of the adoption of these regulations and including any future revisions thereto. 
    City engineer means the engineer for the city, including the division inspectors and other individuals working under the direct supervision of the city engineer or those designated to act on behalf of the city engineer. 
    Commission means the planning and zoning commission of the city. 
    Common land/ground means the land set aside for open space including stormwater structures, retention lakes, ponding or recreational use for the owners of residential lots in a subdivision. This land is conveyed by the developer in fee simple absolute title by a deed to the homeowners' association. The trust indenture for common land shall provide that it be used for the sole benefit, use and enjoyment of the lot owners present and future and shall be the maintenance responsibility of the homeowners' association of the subdivision. No lot owner shall have the right to convey his interest in common land except as an incident of his ownership of a regularly platted lot. 
    Community development director means the community development director for the city or his designee. 
    Comprehensive plan means a plan, or portion thereof, adopted by the planning and zoning commission of the city showing the general location and extent of present and proposed physical facilities including housing, commercial and industrial uses, major streets, utilities, parks, schools and other major community facilities. This plan also establishes the goals, objectives and policies of the community. 
    Condominium means a form of property ownership under the Condominium Property Act, RSMo ch. 448 , where portions of the real estate are designated for separate ownership and the remainder of that is designated for common ownership solely by the owners of those portions. Real estate is not a condominium unless the undivided interests in the common elements are vested in the unit owners and a plat prepared in accordance with the provisions of RSMo ch. 448 . 
    Construction plans means complete construction drawings of a facility or improvement, including, but not limited to, road plans and profiles, drainage plans and utility plans. See subsection (b) of this section. 
    Detention means the temporary storage of stormwater runoff in ponds, parking lots, depressed grassy areas or buried underground tanks for future release. Used to delay and attenuate flow. 
    Developer means that person by whom a tract will be subdivided and improved pursuant to the requirements of these regulations. 
    Director of public works means the public works director of the city. 
    Easement, permanent utility, means a grant by a property owner to a public or private utility company for installation, improvement and maintenance of public or private utilities. 
    Easement, private roadway, means a designated vehicular access way for the servicing of individual lots within a subdivision. 
    Easement, public pedestrian trail, means right-of-way dedicated to the city for the construction and maintenance of a public trail. 
    Easement, road improvement, maintenance and utility. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Easement, stormwater control. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Easement, stormwater control access. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Engineer means a professional engineer registered in this state. 
    Escrow means an agreement between the developer and the city whereby the developer establishes funds to cover the cost of completion of required on-site improvements as depicted upon approved construction improvement plans or upon a final development plan or preliminary plat. 
    FEMA means the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
    Floodplain means that area within the city subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. This area is designated on the FEMA flood boundary and floodway maps. 
    Footcandle means one lumen per square foot unit of luminance. One footcandle equals approximately 0.1 (0.093) lux. 
    Frontage means the edge of a lot bordering a public or private street, including internal primary drive isles within subdivision developments. 
    Glare means the sensation produced by a bright source within the visual field that is sufficiently brighter than the level to which the eyes are adapted to cause annoyance, discomfort or loss of visual performance and visibility. 
    Grade means the inclination from the horizontal of a road, unimproved land, etc., and is expressed by stating the vertical rise or fall as a percent of the horizontal distance. 
    High pressure pipeline. See zoning regulations, section 405.050. 
    Highway. See Street. 
    Homeowners' association means an association or organization, whether or not incorporated, which operates under and pursuant to recorded covenants, deed restrictions or declarations, through which each owner of a portion of a subdivision, be it a lot, parcel, site, unit plot, condominium or any other interest, is automatically a member as a condition of ownership and each such member is subject to a charge or assessment for a prorated share of expenses of the association which may become a lien against the lot, parcel, unit, condominium or other interest of the member. 
    Improvements or subdivision improvements means street pavement, turning lanes, traffic signals, bridges and culverts, sidewalk pavement, pedestrian way pavement, utilities, subdivision amenities, water mains, fire hydrants, storm sewers and roadside drainage ditches, erosion and siltation control, sanitary sewers, signs, monuments, landscaping, street lights and other similar items. 
    Intersection means the junction of two public roads. 
    Joint ownership means joint ownership among persons shall be construed as the same owner for imposing subdivision regulations. 
    Land surveyor means a professional land surveyor registered in this state. 
    Lot means a parcel of land created under the provisions of these regulations intended to be separately owned, developed or otherwise used as a unit. 
    Lot area means the total horizontal surface area within the boundaries of a lot exclusive of any area designated for street right-of-way purposes. 
    Lot, corner, means a lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. 
    Lot depth means the horizontal distance between the front and rear property lines of a lot measured perpendicular to the right-of-way. 
    Lot, flag, means a lot containing two parts: 
(1)  The "flag" shall include that portion of the lot used for primary and accessory buildings; and 
(2)  The "pole" shall be the portion of the lot considered for access between the site and the adjacent ground. 
The flag shall maintain compliance with minimum zoning district requirements not fronting or abutting a public roadway and the pole accessing the public roadway is limited to a private right-of-way. 
    Lot improvement means any building, structure, place, work of art, public facility or other improvement of the land on which they are situated constituting a physical betterment of real property or any such betterment. Certain lot improvements shall be properly bounded as provided in these regulations. 
    Lot of record means a lot that is part of a subdivision recorded in the office of the county recorder, or a lot or parcel described by metes and bounds, the description of which has also been recorded. 
    Lot split means any minor subdivision wherein the division or redivision of land meets the criteria set forth in section 410.410. 
    Lot, through, means an interior lot having frontage on two non-intersecting streets, as distinguished from a corner lot. 
    Lot width means the distance between the two side property lines of a lot measured tangent to the building setback line as established by the zoning regulations for the applicable district. 
    Lumen means unit of luminance flux used to measure the amount of light emitted by lamps. 
    Lux means one lumen per square meter unit of luminance. One lux equals approximately ten (10.8) footcandles. 
    MoDOT means the state department of transportation. 
    Monument means a permanent marker to be made of materials and placed by a land surveyor or at locations specified in section 410.330 of these regulations or as directed by the city engineer. 
    Parking bay means a paved vehicle storage area directly adjacent to the access street or privately controlled pavement. 
    Pedestrian way means an easement or right-of-way designated to facilitate pedestrian access to adjacent streets and properties. 
    Plat means a map or layout of a subdivision indicating the location and boundaries of individual properties. 
    Preliminary plat means preliminary drawings and supporting supplementary material indicating the proposed layout of the subdivision is to be submitted to the planning and zoning commission for its consideration and recommendation to the board of aldermen. 
    Record plat means a map of land subdivision prepared in form suitable for filing of record with necessary affidavits, dedications and acceptances, and with complete bearing and dimensions of all lines defining lots and blocks, streets and alleys, public areas and other dimensions of land, signed by the city clerk and recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds. 
    Sketch plat means a concept sketch indicating the subdivider's general objectives and desires regarding the future development of his land presented to the public works department for consideration and further processing. 
    Plat, boundary adjustment, means a plat which depicts a change in a recorded subdivision that affects any lot line, provided that no new lot or illegal zoning lot is created. 
    Plat, resubdivision, means a record plat which depicts a change in a recorded record subdivision plat that affects any street layout, easement of access, right-of-way, design concept or creates a new lot, provided that no illegal zoning lot is created. 
    Public improvement. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Retention. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Right-of-way means land reserved or acquired by dedication, prescription, condemnation, gift, purchase, eminent domain or any other legal means occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, sidewalk, railroad, city utility, sewer or other similar use. 
    Road, roadway. See Street. 
    Setback. See Building line. 
    Siltation control means the installation of such devices as sediment ponds, bales of straw, fencing, siltation webbing, sodding, seeding and mulching or other devices to prevent silting of abutting properties and roadways during the period of construction and up to and including such time as permanent ground cover is attained. 
    Site development means altering terrain or vegetation and constructing improvements. 
    Site plan means a drawing or plan illustrating a proposed development and prepared to scale, showing land uses, parking and structures proposed for a parcel of land in accordance with regulations outlined in the various sections of the land use code in chapter 405 of this title, with special reference to article VII of that chapter. 
    Slope means the rate of deviation of the ground surface from the horizontal as expressed in percentages. 
    Street. See engineering design criteria, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Street, arterial, means a major street as identified upon the city transportation master plan or comprehensive plan thoroughfare plan or otherwise directed by the public works director and utilized primarily for heavy volumes of traffic on a continuous route or for high vehicular speeds with intersections at grade. 
    Street, collector, means a secondary land service street that moves traffic from the major streets, which distribute traffic regionally, to minor streets, which distribute the traffic to individual lots, parcels, and uses within the subdivision, area or neighborhood. Collector streets also may serve individual lots, parcels and uses as a secondary or additional function. 
    Street, cul-de-sac, means a short, independent, minor street terminating in a circular turnaround. 
    Street, frontage or service, means a secondary street generally parallel to and adjacent to arterial streets and highways, which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic by way of controlled access points along arterial streets or highways. 
    Street, loop, means a short, independent street which usually terminates along the same collector street of its origin. 
    Street, major (arterial). See Street, arterial. 
    Streets, minor, means streets are that exclusively land service facilities for access to abutting properties. These serve the local neighborhood and may be in the form of a cul-de-sac or loop street; provided, however, that any combination of loop and cul-de-sac streets may be utilized without the streets being designated as collector streets, provided that such an arrangement serves the same function and also that the maximum fronting lots do not exceed the total which would be allowed within the provisions of the street specifications matrix. 
    Street, multiple-family access, means a private way or driveway which affords a means of vehicular access to parking areas and bays and to abutting buildings in a multiple dwelling unit subdivision. 
    Street, private, means a private way not owned or maintained by the city which affords the principal means of vehicular access limited to abutting property. 
    Structure. See engineering design criteria definition, subsection (b) of this section. 
    Subdivision means a division of a tract of land resulting in more than one parcel for any land use. 
    Subdivision amenities means subdivision improvements typically within residential, but may be within commercial or industrial projects, including, but not limited to, playgrounds, tot lots, parking areas, swimming pools, bike/pedestrian trails, clubhouses, community centers, recreational facilities, sport courts, playing fields, improved green or open space (subdivision passive parks) or other attributes of a subdivision, constructed as a part of the development for the use and enjoyment of the residents, tenants, patrons, lot owners or guests. 
    Title company means a corporation qualified and acting under the state title insurance law or a corporation that is an issuing agency for an insurance company insuring land titles. 
    Thoroughfare plan means a plan depicting the general alignment and nature of road improvements for existing and future classified roads on the arterial and collector road systems and listing of classification, minimum future pavement width and minimum right-of-way requirements for all classified roads. 
    Tract means an area or parcel of land which the developer intends to subdivide and improve, or to cause to be subdivided and improved, pursuant to applicable city ordinances, the requirements of these regulations and the associated engineering design criteria. 
    Trust indenture means any recordable instrument by which common ground is held or maintained or assessments in a subdivision are levied for the administration of specific maintenance obligations or both. For purposes of these subdivision regulations, the term "trust indenture" also includes a declaration or any other instrument, however denominated, which creates a condominium and allocates common element interests and common expense liabilities pursuant to section 448.2-107 of the Uniform Condominium Act. 
    Trustees means the duly established governing body whether acting in trust or as appointed or elected officers of a homeowners' association. 
    Utilities, public, means utilities that are subject to city acceptance by the city or other political subdivision for operation and maintenance. For purposes of this chapter, public utilities include public streets, water lines, sanitary sewer lines, storm sewer lines and their associated pump stations, appurtenances and any component parts thereof. 
    Zoning regulations means the city zoning regulations as set forth in this Code. 
(Code 2008, § 410.060, 410.070; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.060. - Authority. 
    The planning and zoning commission's authority and responsibilities are stated as follows: 
(1)  No person or his agent shall subdivide any land before securing the approval of the planning and zoning commission of a resubdivision plat or receiving a vote by the planning and zoning commission and approval by the board of aldermen of a plat designating the areas to be subdivided, and no plat of a subdivision of land within the city shall be recorded by the county recorder until the plat has been considered by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the board of aldermen and the approval entered thereon in writing by the chairperson, secretary or other duly authorized officer of the commission. 
(2)  No person owning land composing a subdivision, or his agent, shall transfer or sell or agree to sell any lot or parcel of land located within a subdivision by reference to, or by exhibition, or by any other use of a plat of such subdivision, before such plat has received a vote by the planning and zoning commission and approval by the board of aldermen and has been recorded within the office of the county recorder. Any such instrument of transfer, sale or contract shall be void and shall not be subject to being recorded, but all rights of such purchaser to damages are hereby preserved. The description of such lot or parcel by metes and bounds in any contract or instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring same shall not exempt the person attempting to transfer from penalties provided or deprive the purchaser of any right or remedies he may otherwise have. 
(3)  New subdivisions reviewed under the requirements of this chapter are also subject to, and shall conform to, design and construction specifications within the engineering design criteria and standard specification and construction details documents. 
(Code 2008, § 410.080; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.070. - Instances when plats will not be required. 
    The provisions of these regulations do not apply and no plat is required in any of the following instances: 
(1)  Boundary adjustments subject to the procedures in section 410.430. 
(2)  The conveyance of parcels of land for use as right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities and pipelines which do not involve any new public streets or easements of access. 
(3)  Conveyances made to correct a description of a prior conveyance. 
(4)  Conveyances to the city for right-of-way or utility purposes. 
(5)  Any court ordered division of a tract of land resulting from condemnation proceedings. 
(6)  Conveyances to the city or the county for use as a government communications tower. For purposes of this section, the term "government communications tower" means a tower constructed by a city or county entity on city or county owned property that is necessary to and part of a public safety communications system constructed and controlled by the city or county, or by a governmental entity subject to a lease agreement with the city for such tower. 
(Code 2008, § 410.085; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3298, § 8, 5-22-2013) 
Sec. 410.080. - General application and approval. 
    Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, before any recording of deeds, and before any permit for building or other improvement would be issued for any subdivision, the owner or his authorized agent shall apply for and secure approval of such proposed subdivision in accordance with the pre-application meeting procedure and preliminary plat procedure within this article. 
(Code 2008, § 410.090; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 2011-3129, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
Sec. 410.090. - Review of plats by other agencies. 
    At the option of the community development director or the planning and zoning commission, proposed plats may be submitted to various agencies for review and comment. The planning department shall endeavor to provide the applicant or their representative notice of any comments prior to the meeting. 
(Code 2008, § 410.095; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
ARTICLE II. - SUBMISSION AND REVIEW OF SUBDIVISION PLATS 

Sec. 410.100. - Pre-application meeting procedure. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of the pre-application meeting is to provide the subdivider an opportunity to consult early and informally with the planning and zoning commission staff before the preparation of a preliminary or final plat or submission of a formal application to the planning and zoning commission. The intent of this procedure is to assist the subdivider in preparing a plan which will meet the goals and objectives of the comprehensive plan, highlight ordinance regulations and stipulations, access regulations, public improvements and Code sections applicable to the plat. The pre-application meeting procedure is intended to decrease costs to the developer and eliminate inadequate design in the early stages of the subdivision development process. Subdividers and developers unfamiliar with the current city ordinances, regulations and processes, or those with unique or complex issues pertaining to their proposed development, are strongly encouraged to avail themselves of the pre-application meeting process. 
(b)  Pre-application meeting requirements and processing. 
(1)  Prior to submitting a preliminary plat for the subdivision of land within the city, a developer may contact the city's community development department to schedule a meeting and submit to the community development director six copies of a plat for the tract that includes the following information: 
a.  North arrow and scale (engineering scale required: 1" = 100' or 1" = 50'). 
b.  Applicant's name, address, phone/fax number. 
c.  Name, address, phone/fax of design professional preparing plat/plan. 
d.  Identifiable location; show site and adjacent parcels. 
e.  Vicinity map and distance to nearest existing street intersection. 
f.  Label adjacent zoning and land uses. 
g.  Residential density and net density calculation and number of lots proposed. 
h.  All existing buildings. 
i.  Existing and proposed streets, lot sizes and setbacks. 
j.  Existing and proposed open space/landscaping/wooded areas. 
k.  Existing and proposed zoning. 
l.  Show drainage arrows/outfall and retention areas. 
m.  Show location and height of site walls, including retaining walls or retention basins. 
n.  Submit any drainage studies prepared for the site. 
o.  Site access and existing topography. 
p.  A title clearly indicating if building's divided units are to be sold as separate lots (villas, condominiums or other similar subdivision of land). 
(2)  The community development director shall consult with appropriate review staff to determine the merits and feasibility of the improvements contemplated by the plat. If the plat is satisfactory for continued processing under these regulations, the applicant shall file formal application to the planning and zoning commission for preliminary plat review. 
(Code 2008, § 410.110; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 2011-3129, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
Sec. 410.110. - Preliminary plat procedure. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of the preliminary plat is to provide the planning and zoning commission with a detailed graphic statement of the proposed improvements to the subject tract of land. The preliminary plat is preliminary only in the sense that the planning and zoning commission may make changes or request comments from other qualified individuals or agencies towards improving the design or improvement standards presented by the subdivider. Upon the planning and zoning commission's vote and approval of the preliminary plat by the board of aldermen, the subdivider is authorized to proceed with improvement plans for all public facilities in preparation for development. 
(b)  Application requirements and processing. 
(1)  The developer shall prepare and submit to the community development director seven copies of a preliminary plat of the tract and a reduced copy of the plat measuring 11 inches by 17 inches. The submittal shall be made in compliance with the submission schedule of deadlines established by the community development director. All preliminary plats shall be prepared by a state registered professional land surveyor or a state registered professional engineer and bear their signature and seal. The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 
a.  All information required in section 410.100. 
b.  A key map showing the tract and its relation to the surrounding area and a key map or legend depicting any symbol used on the plat. 
c.  A north arrow, graphic scale and plat drawn at an engineer's scale of 1" = 100' or 1" = 50'. 
d.  The name proposed for the tract or such part thereof as is proposed to be subdivided, that shall be original and not a duplication of the name of any previously recorded subdivision or development in the county. 
e.  The date of plan submission to the city and the following names and addresses: 
1.  The record owner or owners of the tract. 
2.  The party who prepared the plat. 
3.  The party for whom the plat was prepared. 
4.  The engineer and land surveyor who will design improvements for and survey the tract or such part thereof as is proposed to be subdivided. 
f.  The approximate area of the tract and common ground acreage to nearest one-tenth of an acre, that shall include all land within the plat that is subject to pipelines of record under the jurisdiction of the federal department of transportation, if the plat is within an "R1-A," "R-1B," "R1-C," "R1-D" and "R-1E" Single-Family Residential District, "R-2" Two-Family Residential District, "R-3B" Multi-Family Residential District or an "MHD" Mobile Home Development District. No such plat shall be approved if it fails to include the pipeline within platted common ground imposed by section 405.440. 
g.  Sufficient existing and proposed contour data to indicate the slope and drainage of the tract and the high and low points thereof. Contour data shall extend 50 feet beyond the limits of the subdivision boundaries. USGS data is required or city GIS data may be utilized as available depicting two-foot contour intervals. 
h.  The location of existing and proposed property lines, sink holes, wetlands, areas within the tract subject to inundation by stormwater, railroads, bridges, culverts, storm sewers, easement of record for high pressure pipelines, overhead electric lines and other utilities, existing buildings including use or other identified improvements that are to remain and significant natural features such as wooded areas and rock formations. The plat shall show the approximate limits of the tract's natural watercourses and riparian buffers, delineated based upon pre-development topographical data and shall indicate compliance with applicable criteria established in these regulations. 
i.  The location, width and names of existing and proposed streets including right-of-way and additional right-of-way along existing streets as required in section 410.190(b)(2). 
j.  Indicate compliance with section 410.260 related to tree preservation requirements and indicate compliance with required street trees in section 410.320 as applicable via a development note or landscaping depiction on the preliminary plat. 
k.  The zoning district, including delineation of floodplain district, if any, and the township, range, section and U.S. Survey, school district, fire district, water company, and other utility service districts, or special districts in which the tract is located. 
l.  Depict existing floodway fringe (floodplain), floodway boundaries and provide base flood elevation data upon the plat as shown on the federal insurance rate maps (FIRM) and any proposed alteration, adjustment or change in the elevation or topography of any area in a floodplain district as shown on the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) mapping. 
m.  Approximate area in square feet of minimum and maximum size of lots, including typical lot dimensions if less than one acre in area and in acres and tenths of acres if one acre or more in area, into which the tract is proposed to be subdivided. 
n.  Pavement, roads (existing and planned), right-of-way for planned roadway expansions as depicted within the transportation master plan or corridor preservation plans, existing and proposed sidewalks and pedestrian ways and public pedestrian trail easements as indicated upon the trail master plan or comprehensive plan, building lines and setback lines, parks or other features of the site's development. 
o.  Names of adjacent owners or subdivisions, including existing property lines and lot numbers of adjacent subdivisions within 100 feet showing existing streets and highways, etc. 
p.  Designation of public water and sewer facilities to access the development and the general layout indicating distribution within the project. 
q.  If the developer intends to subdivide any portion of the parcel into a multiple-dwelling unit subdivision or a subdivision being developed under planned development section of the zoning regulations, then the preliminary plat shall, in addition, include the following data: 
1.  Gross area of the tract. 
2.  Area in streets. 
3.  Net area of the tract. 
4.  Maximum number of units allowed. 
5.  Maximum number of units proposed. 
6.  Parking ratio (parking spaces to dwelling units). 
7.  Distance between structures. 
r.  A certification by the registered land surveyor or engineer who prepared the plat that the plat is a correct representation of all existing and proposed land divisions. 
s.  All approximate gradients of streets and centerline curve radius on streets. 
t.  Location and labeling of wet or dry detention basin within common ground and labeling of the required permanent access at a width of 20 feet for vehicular access and maintenance for inspection and enforcement of applicable regulations by the city. 
u.  The arrangement, access to, location, and number of all centralized box units (CBU) shall be reflected on the preliminary plat. The arrangement, access to, location and number of all CBUs will be reviewed by the city based on the following criteria as part of the preliminary plat approval process: 
1.  Location of the CBU shall provide for public convenience, access and safety, and shall be located appropriately in relation to adjacent residences and in a manner that complies with United States Postal Service requirements. 
2.  CBU location and specifications shall require United States Postal Service agency written approval. 
3.  All CBUs shall be located upon property that is protected by an easement to the homeowners association or located within recorded common ground areas. The responsibility for maintenance of the CBU shall be expressly declared as an obligation of the homeowners association in the indenture (section 410.160(a)). 
4.  CBU locations and required parking locations in public right-of-way shall be reviewed and approved by the Public Works Director prior to installation. 
5.  Off-street parking spaces shall be provided to comply with section 405.580(a). 
6.  No CBU shall not be located within a cul-de-sac portion of the street absent express written USPS agency approval; 
7.  No CBU or accessory parking area shall be closer than 100 feet to a street intersection, unless there are no other appropriate alternatives. 
8.  Lighting shall be provided to illuminate the CBU area. 
9.  The CBU shall not be located within a utility easement. 
v.  The city will request comments from the Wentzville Fire Protection District prior to preliminary plat approval for developments that have a single ingress and egress, and where variances are requested for pavement width reduction, maximum cul-de-sac length and number of units or lots served on a cul-de-sac. 
w.  Development of parcels within a floodplain shall require approval of a floodplain study. 
x.  A copy of the preliminary plat shall be distributed to the city engineer for his review and comments. 
y.  A filing fee as established by the city fee schedule. 
(2)  The community development director shall review the preliminary plat with regard to requirements described in these regulations upon receipt of a complete application and provide any comments for revision to the applicant, directing the applicant to provide 25 copies and an electronic copy suitable to formats accepted by the city. Format to the planning division for inclusion upon the planning and zoning commission agenda for review and recommendation to the board of aldermen, and the community development director shall provide a report to the planning and zoning commission at their next regularly scheduled meeting including comments from divisions public works departments, as applicable, and other agencies to whom the plat was referred to for review. If, after city staff review, the plat application is satisfactory under the requirements of this chapter, the community development director shall submit the plat to the planning and zoning commission at their next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(c)  Commission action. Within 60 days after submission of the plat to the planning and zoning commission as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, the commission shall take action on the plat; otherwise the plat is deemed approved by the commission, except that the commission, with the consent of the applicant for approval, may extend the 60-day period. Unless postponed as set forth herein, the commission shall recommend that the board of aldermen take one of the following actions: 
(1)  General approval. Approve the preliminary plat as submitted. Approval shall be valid for one year, and extensions of approval may be granted by the board of aldermen. In the case of subdivisions being developed by sections, extensions of approval shall be automatic for all sections so long as construction is in progress in any section. 
(2)  Conditional approval. Approve the preliminary plat conditionally. The city may accept a plan addressing conditions of approval but shall not accept any submission from the applicant attempting to change, amend or otherwise modify the application or plan under review, unless the proposed changes are responsive to a condition or stipulation made by the planning and zoning commission in its recommendation for approval of the plat. 
(3)  Disapproval. The planning and zoning commission may disapprove the preliminary plat if the plat fails to comply with applicable requirements of the city's zoning regulations referencing reasons for disapproval. 
(4)  Postponement. The planning and zoning commission may postpone its decision pending further study of the plat, or for other good cause, but in no event shall its decision be postponed more than 60 days after submission of the original plat, except that the commission, with the consent of the applicant for approval, may extend the 60-day period. 
(d)  Date of submission. For the purposes of this chapter, the date of submission of the plat to the commission is the date of the planning and zoning commission meeting on which the plat first appeared on the agenda for commission action. 
(e)  Final acceptance of approval. Action on the preliminary plat by the planning and zoning commission does not constitute a final acceptance of approval of the proposed subdivision. 
(f)  Board action. The planning and zoning commission's recommendation shall be forwarded to the board of aldermen for review. Unless postponed, the board may take any action on the plat that is available to the commission in subsection (c) of this section. Board of aldermen approval of the preliminary plat is an authorization to proceed with the preparation of project improvement plans for land disturbance and construction of required public facilities to the city engineer for review and conformance with engineering design criteria and standard specifications and construction details documents and the preparation of the final (record) plat. 
(g)  Period of validity. If a time extension is not granted by the board of aldermen in subsection (c)(1) of this section, the approval of the preliminary plat granted by the city shall lapse unless a final (record) plat for either the entire subject property, or a portion of the property (if the property is to be developed in sections), is submitted within two years from the date of such approval. In the case of subdivisions being developed by sections, extensions of the period of validity shall be automatic for all sections so long as construction is in progress in any section. 
(h)  Amendment of preliminary plat. If, after the approval of a preliminary plat, the subdivider desires to make a change in the number of lots, alignment of streets or use of previously dedicated property, an amended preliminary plat shall be filed for review following the procedures herein set forth as if it were an original application. Minor adjustments in street alignment, removal of lots from a plat or the addition of one lot, compliant with the applicable zoning district standards, will not require a new application if the alignment of streets or the use or approval of the project and of the property have not substantially changed from the approved plan. Amendments may require new approval by the engineering department and other city departments as applicable. 
(Code 2008, § 410.120; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3122, § 1, 1-26-2011; Ord. No. 3130, § 3, 2-9-2011; Ord. No. 3167, § 3, 8-24-2011; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011; Ord. No. 2017-3774, § 5, 9-27-2017) 
Sec. 410.120. - Improvement plans. 
(a)  Approval. After the preliminary plat is approved, improvement plans prepared by an engineer for the subdivision of all or any part of the tract shall be submitted to the city engineer for review and approval. If significant changes are made after the improvement plans have been approved, the city engineer shall require that revised improvement plans be submitted. 
(b)  Content. Improvement plans and all required accompanying reports and calculations shall be prepared in conformance with the requirements of the city engineering design criteria and standard specifications and construction details. 
(c)  Other requirements. 
(1)  Commencement of construction activities. 
a.  Land disturbance; clearing, grubbing and grading. No type of clearing, grubbing or grading activity shall be performed until the required grading/erosion control plans have been reviewed and approved by the city engineer, an erosion protection guarantee deposit pursuant to section 410.140 is established and the grading permit has been issued. 
b.  Improvement installation. No installation of any kind of improvement shall be performed until the required improvement plans have been reviewed and approved by the city engineer, a deposit agreement pursuant to section 410.140 guaranteeing the installation of the proposed improvements is established and the construction permit has been issued. 
(2)  Approval by other agencies. The improvement plans shall not be approved until plans have been submitted and approved by the state department of natural resources and county and state highway departments, as required. 
(3)  Registered engineer required. The submitted improvement plans detailing the construction and types of materials to be used in conjunction with development of the proposed subdivision shall be prepared by a professional engineer registered in this state, whose name, seal and registration number shall appear upon the plan. 
(d)  Riparian buffers. All improvement plans shall clearly show the boundaries of any riparian buffer on the subject property and provide a note on the plan to reference any riparian buffer stating: "There shall be no clearing, grading, construction or disturbance of vegetation except as permitted by section 410.490." 
(e)  Submittal fee. A submittal fee in the amount of $150.00 shall be required for the submission of improvement plans or for submission of revised plans after the improvement plans have been approved as required under subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 2008, § 410.130; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.130. - Reserved. 
Sec. 410.140. - Improvements installed or guaranteed. 
(a)  Improvement guarantee required. Once the improvement plans have been approved by the director of public works and all associated fees have been paid, the developer must complete the installation of all improvements as shown on the approved plans. This work must be done in accordance with city standards under the observation/inspection of a city representative, prior to approval of the subdivision record plat or issuance of building permits. If approval of the subdivision record plat is desired prior to completion of all improvements, a guarantee must be established to ensure that the required improvements are constructed, installed, and completed in a manner that is timely and satisfactory to the city. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the developer shall proceed according to one of the options listed below: 
(1)  Complete all improvements as described on the approved improvement plans, establish a maintenance deposit, and a water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee deposit prior to approval of the subdivision record plat, improvement dedication, and issuance of building permits; or 
(2)  At the time of subdivision record plat approval establish a construction deposit and a stormwater post-construction deposit, under deposit agreements, with the director of public works or other designated official establishing a two-year completion period during which all improvements must be completed. This deposit shall guarantee the construction, installation, completion, and operation of all subdivision improvements including subdivision amenities, as defined in section 410.050, and any incidental work associated with the improvements. Upon completion of all improvements and prior to dedication of such improvements to the city a maintenance deposit must be established. 
(b)  Exceptions. The director of public works may require any specific improvement to be installed prior to approval of the record plat where the failure to install such improvement prior to further development could result in damage to the site or other surrounding properties. 
(c)  Deposit options. All deposits required in this section shall be submitted in conjunction with a city deposit agreement and may be in the form of cash or an irrevocable letter of credit, and in some limited circumstances, a surety bond as follows: 
(1)  Cash escrow. Cash deposited with the director of public works to be held in an interest bearing account dedicated for that purpose, with all interest accruing to the city to offset administrative and other costs of maintaining the cash deposits. 
(2)  Letter of credit. An irrevocable letter of credit drawn on a local financial institution in the city's approved format. The letter of credit shall provide that the issuing institution will pay to the city such amounts necessary, up to the maximum available limit, to complete the improvements as described herein. The letter of credit shall be irrevocable for a period of at least three years and may be reduced in writing as deemed appropriate by the director of public works. 
(3)  Surety bond. In certain circumstances, for good cause shown, the city may accept a bond issued by a bond company licensed in the state so long as the bond adheres to the city's approved format. 
(d)  Types and amounts of deposits. The types and amounts of the deposits required by this section shall be calculated as follows: 
(1)  Construction deposit. The deposit required of a developer shall be in the amount of 110 percent of the engineer's approved construction cost estimate for completion of the required improvements. Where the developer elects to complete portions of the improvements prior to plat approval, the gross deposit shall be reduced by the engineer's approved cost estimate for such completed improvements. 
(2)  Maintenance deposit. A developer shall be required to establish a maintenance deposit in the amount of five percent of the engineer's approved construction cost estimate to guarantee that continuing maintenance and or repair obligations are fulfilled after improvements have been accepted for dedication by the city. 
(3)  Individual lot deposit. If a builder other than the developer who established the maintenance escrow holder wishes to build on a lot within the city, the builder shall be required to establish a deposit in the amount of $1,000.00 per lot or $10,000.00 citywide prior to issuance of any building permits. This deposit will guarantee the correction of any damages to public improvements or grading resulting from home construction by the lot builder or their contractors. This deposit will only be accepted as a cash deposit as defined in subsection (c) of this section pertaining to deposit options. 
(4)  Grading/sediment erosion protection deposit. A developer shall be required to provide an erosion protection guarantee in the amounts and manner set forth in section 515.020(c). 
(5)  Water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee deposit. As a guarantee that future water quality improvements will be installed and maintained until final acceptance, the developer shall establish a deposit in the amount of 100 percent of the engineer's approved cost estimate for water quality improvements. 
(6)  Site plan performance guarantee. In addition to the guarantees described above, where a site plan is approved in conjunction with the subdivision record plat approval, a site plan performance guarantee shall be established pursuant to section 405.900. 
(e)  Construction deposit agreement; extension of completion period. 
(1)  The developer and the city shall enter into a fully executed deposit agreement ("deposit agreement"), in a form unaltered from the city's standard document (approved and authorized by subsection (m) of this section), which shall require the developer to fulfill the obligations imposed in this section. The deposit agreement authorizes the director of public works to release or reduce deposits held as permitted herein. Reductions may only occur upon approval by the director of public works once all required improvements within a category have been completed, inspected, and all deficiencies addressed. Full releases will be made only upon the completion of all categories of improvements. 
(2)  If at the end of the two-year completion period as established in the deposit agreement (the "completion period"), all improvements as shown on the approved improvement plans have not been completed, the developer may request that the director of public works amend the deposit agreement to grant an extension of such completion period. Upon this request the director of public works, if it is deemed necessary, may grant an extension of no more than one year to facilitate the completion of all improvements as shown on the approved improvement plans. Prior to granting the extension all applicable guarantees must be extended and approved by the director of public works. The director of public works may also require, as part of an amended deposit agreement, recalculation of deposit amounts, the satisfaction of any amended or new code requirements, or other reasonable conditions as may be necessary to ensure that the extended deposit agreement fully complies with the terms of this section. 
(f)  (1)  Improvement completion by category. For the purposes of this section, improvements shall be deemed "complete" only when the city certifies that: 
a.  The developer has notified the director of public works in writing that all improvements within a category have been installed according to the improvement plans for the entire subdivision or a specified phase of such subdivision, all necessary or requested documentation including all required as-built plans have been provided, and an inspection has been requested; 
b.  Through the inspection process the city has determined that all components within a category or categories of improvements have been constructed and installed with no deficiencies in the subdivision or specified phase; 
c.  The developer is not in default or in breach of any obligation to the city under this section including but not limited to the director of public works' request for maintenance or the deposit of additional funds; and 
d.  The results of the above mentioned process including the inspection and document review have been approved in writing by the director of public works. 
Releases of the improvement warranty deposit, maintenance deposit, grading/sediment erosion protection deposit, water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee deposit and the site plan performance guarantee shall be as provided elsewhere. 
(2)  Inspection. The city will perform an inspection within 20 business days of the public works department receiving a written request for inspection from the developer. The written inspection request must be in a form acceptable to the department and shall reference the category or categories of improvements reflected in the deposit agreement that are to be included in the inspection, as well as a statement from the developer that all categories of improvements in the request have, to the best of their knowledge, been constructed and installed according to plan. The inspection process will proceed according to the following steps: 
a.  Step 1. After the inspection has been conducted, the department will notify the developer and/or other requested third parties of any deficiencies through a written inspection report ("inspection report"). 
b.  Step 2. Within 60 days of receiving the inspection report, the developer shall correct all deficiencies noted on the inspection report and request in writing that a re-inspection be conducted. If no deficiencies are found during the initial inspection or the first re-inspection the process will proceed immediately to step 4 below. If the noted deficiencies are not corrected within 60 days, the city shall have the option to conduct a new inspection listing any additional deficiencies or correct all the identified deficiencies itself and draw on the established deposit to reimburse or defray all costs. 
c.  Step 3. The city shall conduct an initial re-inspection at no charge within 20 business days of receiving a written request. If any or all deficiencies have not been corrected, the city will again notify the developer of those deficiencies through a written inspection report. Any subsequent inspections conducted by the city will require the payment of a $100.00 re-inspection fee and may include the identification of other deficiencies as deemed necessary by the city. 
d.  Step 4. After an inspection has been completed, where all noted deficiencies have been addressed, a written notice approving the inspection will be sent to the developer, the developer's financial institution or surety, and/or other requested third parties. As the inspection is only a single component of improvement completion, all other completion items as noted above must be addressed prior to any deposit reduction or release. 
Nothing herein shall preclude the public works department from conducting additional inspections at its discretion or as a courtesy to the developer. 
(g)  Deposits use and release. 
(1)  Construction deposit. A developer shall establish a deposit, through the options described in subsection (c) of this section, pertaining to deposit options, under a deposit agreement to guarantee the construction of all improvements. 
a.  Construction deposit use. The construction deposit shall be required by the city to guarantee the developer's completion of the required improvements within the completion period or to defray or fund any costs incurred by the city to complete those improvements or remedy deficiencies if the developer is absent or for any reason is unable to properly complete the work. 
b.  Construction deposit release. The amount held for any category of improvement for an entire subdivision or any previously defined and approved portion of a subdivision such as a phase shall be released within 30 days of completion of said category as defined above, minus retention of five percent. The final five percent shall be released only upon (1) completion of all categories of improvements, and (2) dedication of all improvements by the board of alderman through an ordinance: 
1.  All categories of improvements, as described in the engineer's approved cost estimate and the deposit agreement, have been completed per subsection (f) of this section and approved by the director of public works; and 
2.  An improvement maintenance deposit and water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee have been established and accepted by the director of public works. 
After approval of the resolution an executed copy will be forwarded to the developer and the developer's financial institution or surety along with a notice authorizing the release of the remaining five percent. 
(2)  Maintenance deposit. Upon commencement of installation of the required improvements within the subject subdivision, the developer shall be responsible for the maintenance of those improvements, including undeveloped lots, streets, sidewalks, utilities, subdivision amenities, common areas, and storm and drainage facilities, until the sooner of: (1) 12 months after dedication of all improvements by the board of alderman through an ordinance, or (2) 90 percent of all homes have been constructed and the corresponding final occupancy permits have been issued. To cover ongoing obligations during building construction, the developer may choose to retain the maintenance deposit with the city until 100 percent build-out or instead use the individual lot deposit described below for the final ten percent of homes constructed or those constructed more than 12 months after dedication. The developer shall establish a maintenance deposit, through the options described in subsection (c) of this section, pertaining to deposit options, under a deposit agreement to guarantee that any and all repairs are made to improvements that may be damaged during the construction of homes or buildings within the subject subdivision. 
a.  Maintenance deposit use. During the maintenance period the developer shall be responsible for the replacement or repair of any deficient or defective improvements including, but not limited to, broken, failing, displaced, or settling street slabs, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, leaking water mains, or other failures of constructed improvements as well as any broken, failing, and or damaged subdivision amenities. This maintenance shall also include, but is not limited to, repairs or replacements to address damage to streets, street signs, fire hydrants, manholes, subdivision amenities or other public improvements that may occur due to vehicular traffic, construction equipment, or other construction activities as well as abatement of nuisances caused by or related to such improvements, such as removal of mud and debris from streets, erosion control, grass cutting, removal of construction materials (except materials to be used for construction or as otherwise permitted). The developer must provide a minimum of 24 hours' notice prior to beginning any maintenance work during this maintenance period so that a city representative may be present to verify that all work is completed in accordance with the approved improvement plans and all city standards. The deposit will be subject to withdrawal by the city to reimburse or defray the cost of maintenance that may be assumed by the department. However, except in emergency circumstances or when action is required before written notice can be provided, the director of public works shall provide the developer with a written notice and the opportunity to complete the work prior to any work being completed by the department. 
b.  Maintenance deposit release. After the construction of all homes is complete and issuance of final occupancy permits the director of public works will cause a final inspection to be made of the required public improvements and subdivision amenities. If there are no outstanding maintenance items or other deficiencies found and all other obligations are shown to be satisfied on inspection thereof, or at such time thereafter as any maintenance, defects or deficiencies are corrected with the permission of, and within the time allowed by, the director of public works, then the maintenance deposit and obligations shall then be released. This release shall in no way be construed to release any person from any civil liability that may exist for or waive any right of the city to pursue a remedy for any defects or damages caused by any construction, improvement or development for which any deposit has been released. 
(3)  Individual lot deposit. Prior to issuance of a building permit, the public improvements on or adjacent to each individual lot must be covered by a deposit applicable subdivision or as an alternative the developer/builder may select the ten percent of homes constructed or those constructed more than 12 months after as described in subsection (c) of this section pertaining to deposit options, under a deposit agreement to guarantee construction of homes or buildings within the subject lot. Prior to the issuance of a builder shall be responsible for the documentation of the existing site conditions. With city concurrence the builder shall not be held responsible for pre-existing conditions, however the builder will be held responsible for maintenance/repair of sewer utilities, subdivision amenities, common areas, sediment and erosion control and storm and drainage facilities. 
a.  Individual lot deposit use. During home/building construction the builder shall be responsible for repairing any damaged improvements including not limited to, repairs or replacements to address damage to streets, street signs, fire hydrants, manholes, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, water lines, subdivision amenities or other public improvements that may occur due to vehicular traffic, construction equipment, or other construction activities as well as abatement/remediation of nuisances caused by grading or related to such improvements, such as removal of mud and debris from streets, adjacent properties, erosion control, grass cutting, removal of construction materials (except materials to be used for construction or as otherwise permitted). The builder must provide a minimum of 24 hours' notice prior to beginning any repair work during this period so that a city representative may be present to verify that all work is completed in accordance with the approved improvement plans and all city standards. The deposit will be subject to withdrawal by the city to reimburse or defray the cost of repairs that may be assumed by the city. However, except in emergency circumstances or when action is required before written notice can be provided, the director of public works shall provide the builder with a written notice and the opportunity to complete the work prior to any work being completed by the city. If a $10,000.00 citywide lot deposit is in place for a lot and the city is forced to utilize a portion of those funds to correct deficiencies the full value of the deposit must be replenished prior to issuance of any new building permits to that builder. 
b.  Individual lot deposit release.
