After construction of the home/building is complete the public works department, in coordination with the community development department final occupancy inspection, will conduct a final inspection of the public improvements associated with that individual lot. With a passing inspection verifying that all repairs have been satisfactorily completed the final occupancy permit will be issued and the $1,000.00 individual lot deposit will be released. If the $10,000.00 citywide lot deposit is in place the final occupancy permit will be issued however no release will take place and the full $10,000.00 will remain in effect for future building permits. This release shall in no way be construed to release any person from any civil liability that may exist for or waive any right of the city to pursue a remedy for any defects or damages caused by any construction, improvement or development for which any deposit has been released. 
(4)  Grading/sediment erosion protection deposit. The requirements of this guarantee and its released are set forth in section 515.020. 
(5)  Water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee deposit. A developer shall also establish a separate deposit, through the options described in subsection (c) of this section, pertaining to deposit options, under a deposit agreement to guarantee the construction of the water quality improvements. The developer shall be responsible for the installation of the water quality improvements upon completion of the build-out of a minimum of 90 percent of lots in the subdivision's watershed that are tributary to each water quality improvement or as approved by the director of public works. The developer shall submit to the public works department for its review and approval of current cost estimates of required water quality improvements. 
a.  Water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee deposit use. The water quality deposit shall be required by the city to guarantee the completion of the required water quality features including, but not limited, to plantings, filters and forebays. 
b.  Water quality/stormwater post-construction guarantee deposit release. Upon the developer's request, the director of public works shall cause a final inspection to be made of the required water quality improvements. Funds shall then be released when BMP and drainage area vegetation are stabilized and there are no defects or deficiencies found and all other obligations are shown to be satisfied upon inspection thereof, or at such time thereafter as any defects or deficiencies are cured under the supervision of, and within the time allowed by the director of public works and provided that the director of public works has received an acceptable maintenance agreement from the homeowner's association or property owner(s) ensuring the future maintenance of the water quality improvements. In no case will a water quality deposit release be granted prior to development of at least 90 percent of the subdivision's watershed that is tributary to each water quality improvement. 
(6)  Site plan performance guarantee. The requirements of this guarantee and its release are set forth in section 405.900. 
(h)  Successor developer/replacement deposit agreements. If a developer who has established a deposit with the city to guarantee completion of improvements, transfers title of the subdivision property prior to the city's acceptance of all improvements or the complete release of funds the successor developer must establish a new construction deposit to guarantee the completion of improvements under a new deposit agreement. This deposit must match the funds currently held under the original deposit agreement and will carry with it a two-year completion period from the approval date. Only upon approval of the successor developer's deposit agreement will the city release the deposit established by the original developer as well as release the original developer from all further obligations with respect to the subdivision improvements provided that the successor developer assumes all outstanding obligations under the successor developer deposit agreement. 
The successor developer or replacement deposit agreement process may also apply to the maintenance deposit. If a developer transfer's title of the subdivision property to an individual developer/builder prior to completion of the 12 month or 90 percent build-out period a successor builder may replace the maintenance agreement in full. Upon approval of the new maintenance agreement and confirmation of the deposit to fulfill the 12-month or 90 percent build-out obligation the original developers deposit will be released in full and all responsibility for maintenance transferred to the new developer/builder. 
(i)  Failure to complete improvements. The obligation of the developer to construct, complete, install, maintain and warrant the improvements indicated on the approved improvement plans and provide for maintenance of those improvements shall not cease until the developer shall be finally released by the director of public works, nor shall any deposit agreements or obligations hereunder be assignable by developer. If, after the initial improvement completion period, or after a later period as extended pursuant to this section, the improvements indicated on the approved improvement plans are not constructed, completed, installed, accepted and/or maintained as required, or if the developer shall violate any provision of the deposit agreement, the director of public works may notify the developer of the deficiencies and direct the developer to cure the deficiencies or to show cause within not less than ten days why the developer should not be declared in default. If the developer fails to cure any deficiencies or present compelling reason why no default should be declared, the director of public works shall declare the developer in default and may take any one or more of the following acts: 
(1)  Deem the remaining balance under the deposit agreement as forfeited to the city, to be then placed in an appropriate trust and account subject to the order of the director of public works for such purposes as letting contracts to bring about the completion or maintenance of the improvements indicated on the approved improvement plans, performance of any tasks required for the completion of improvements or other appropriate purposes in the interest of the public safety, health and welfare; 
(2)  Require the developer or lender to pay to the city the remaining balance of the letter of credit or surety bond or draw upon the funds held by the city pursuant to a cash deposit; and/or 
(3)  Require the developer to submit an additional cash sum sufficient to guarantee the completion or maintenance of the improvements indicated on the approved improvement plans after recalculation in order to allow for any inflated or increased costs of constructing or maintaining the improvements. 
Notwithstanding the above, the failure of the developer to complete the improvement obligations within the time provided by the deposit agreement (or any extension granted by the city), and including the payment of funds to the city due to such failure or an expiration of a letter of credit, shall be deemed an automatic act of default entitling the city to all remedies provided in this section and the deposit agreement without further or prior notice. It shall be the sole responsibility of the developer to timely request an extension of any deposit agreement if the improvements are not completed in the original time period provided by the deposit agreement and no right to any extension shall exist or be assumed. 
(j)  Other remedies for default. If the board of aldermen determine that the developer or surety has failed to comply with the director of public works requirements for payment as described above or has failed to complete the improvements as required or otherwise violates the deposit agreement provisions, and that there is a risk that development of the subdivision and/or individual lots therein will continue in the subdivision without the timely prior completion of improvements or compliance with deposit agreement provisions, the board of aldermen may, in addition or alternatively to other remedies: 
(1)  Direct that no building or other permit be issued to the developer in the subdivision during any period in which the developer is in violation of the deposit agreement or subdivision code relating to the subdivision. 
(2)  Suspend the right of anyone to build or construct on the undeveloped portion of the subdivision. For the purpose of this subsection (j), the term "undeveloped portion" of the subdivision means all lots other than lots which have been sold for personal use and occupancy or are under bona fide contract for sale to any person for personal use or occupancy. The city shall give the developer ten business days' written notice of an order under this subsection (j), with copies to all sureties, as appropriate, who have outstanding obligations for any undeveloped portion of the subdivision, and shall record an affidavit of such notice with the recorder of deeds. If, within the ten-day period after notice is given, the board is not convinced by compelling evidence that completion of the improvements is adequately assured and maintenance of streets assured as provided herein, the board shall order construction suspended on the undeveloped portion of the subdivision. The order shall be served upon the developer, with a copy to the issuer of the surety as appropriate, and a copy recorded with the recorder of deeds. Public notice of said order shall be conspicuously and prominently posted by the director of public works at the subdivisions or lots subject to said order. The notice shall contain the following minimum language, which may be supplemented at the discretion of the director of public works. 
a.  If said notice is for a subdivision: 
THIS SUBDIVISION, (name of subdivision), HAS BEEN DECLARED IN DEFAULT BY THE CITY OF WENTZVILLE BOARD OF ALDERMEN. NO DEVELOPMENT, CONSTRUCTION, BUILDING OR DEMOLITION IN ANY MANNER SHALL TAKE PLACE WITHIN THE LIMITS OF THIS SUBDIVISION UNTIL SUCH TIME AS THE CITY OF WENTZVILLE REMOVES THIS PROHIBITION. ANY DEVELOPMENT, CONSTRUCTION, BUILDING OR DEMOLITION IN ANY MANNER WHILE THIS PROHIBITION IS IN EFFECT IS ILLEGAL AND SHALL BE ENFORCED PURSUANT TO CHAPTER 410 OF THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF WENTZVILLE, AS AMENDED. 
b.  If said notice is for a lot: 
THIS LOT, (lot number), HAS BEEN DECLARED IN DEFAULT BY THE CITY OF WENTZVILLE BOARD OF ALDERMEN. NO DEVELOPMENT, CONSTRUCTION, BUILDING OR DEMOLITION IN ANY MANNER SHALL TAKE PLACE WITHIN THE LIMITS OF THIS LOT UNTIL SUCH TIME AS THE CITY OF WENTZVILLE REMOVES THIS PROHIBITION. ANY DEVELOPMENT, CONSTRUCTION, BUILDING OR DEMOLITION IN ANY MANNER WHILE THIS PROHIBITION IS IN EFFECT IS ILLEGAL AND SHALL BE ENFORCED PURSUANT TO CHAPTER 410 OF THE MUNICIPAL CODE OF WENTZVILLE, AS AMENDED. 
No department of the city shall thereafter authorize construction to take place contrary to the board of aldermen's order. The suspension shall be rescinded in whole or in part only when the board of aldermen, or their designee, determines that completion of the improvements is adequately assured in all or an appropriate part of the subdivision and a guarantee of public street maintenance provided; or 
(3)  Suspend the rights of the developer, or any related entity, to construct structures in any development platted after the effective date of such suspension throughout city and such incorporated areas as are under city jurisdiction. The developer shall be given ten business days' written notice of an order under this clause, with a copy to sureties known to the public works department to have obligations outstanding on behalf of the developer or related entities and shall record an affidavit of such notice with the recorder of deeds. If, within the ten-day period after notice is given, the board of aldermen is not convinced by compelling evidence that completion of the improvements is adequately assured and maintenance of streets assured as provided herein, the board shall order construction suspended. The order shall be served upon the developer, with a copy to the surety as appropriate, and a copy recorded with the recorder of deeds. No department of the city shall thereafter authorize construction to take place contrary to the board's order. The suspension shall be rescinded only when the board of aldermen is convinced that completion of the improvements is adequately assured and public street maintenance is assured. 
(k)  Suspension of development rights. In addition to subsection (j) of this section, from and after the effective date of this section if the developer, or any related entity, has a subdivision development improvement guarantee that is in default, as determined by the director of public works, including any escrow or bond under any prior version of this section, the rights of the developer, or any related entity, to receive development approval, which approval shall include, but not be limited to, approval of any plat or deposit agreement for new or further development in the city, shall be suspended. The suspension shall be rescinded only when the board of aldermen, or its designee, determines that completion and maintenance of the improvements is adequately assured. 
(l)  Additional remedies. If any party fails to comply with any obligation of this section, the director of public works may recommend that the city attorney take appropriate legal action and may also withhold any building or occupancy permits to this developer or related entities until such compliance is cured. The city shall also have the right to partially or wholly remedy a developer's deficiencies or breached obligations under this Code by set-off of any funds or assets otherwise held by the city of the developer to the maximum extent permitted by law. Such set-off shall occur upon written notice of such event by the director of public works to the developer after the developer has failed to timely cure the deficiencies. It shall be deemed a provision of every deposit agreement authorized under this chapter that the developer shall pay the city's costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, of enforcing such agreement in the event that the developer is judicially determined to have violated any provision herein or in such agreement. 
(m)  Deposit agreements; approval; filing. Deposit agreements substantially in the form of, and with terms no less favorable to the city than are contained in, the deposit agreement attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived are hereby approved and the mayor and/or director of public works, or their designee, are authorized to execute such deposit agreements on behalf of the city. Each subdivision deposit agreement shall be fully executed and on file with the director of public works prior to plat approval. Any plat recorded prior to execution of a deposit agreement and its placement on file with the director of public works shall be voidable by the city. 
(Code 2008, § 410.140; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3037, § 5, 11-18-2009; Ord. No. 3634, § 1, 8-10-2016) 
Sec. 410.150. - Record plat. 
(a)  Purpose. The record subdivision plat serves the following purposes: 
(1)  It is a plat of record containing such information as necessary for the public recording and transfer of land including lot lines, easements and restrictions. The record plat may also include construction details for streets, sidewalks, public utilities and lands. 
(2)  It assures that subdivision requirements and specifications have been met and those public utilities and other improvements have been or will be installed according to minimum standards. 
(3)  An approved record plat authorizes the subdivider to record the subdivision with the county recorder and offers lots for sale to the public. 
(b)  Application requirements and processing. 
(1)  The record plat shall substantially conform to the preliminary plat and shall be submitted after the approval of the preliminary plat. A record plat shall delineate all developed lots created by the plat except as follows: 
a.  In a single-family or multiple-family subdivision, no property may be omitted if a resulting tract is less than ten acres in area or any resulting side of an omitted tract is less than 300 feet in length, unless such a side is the original boundary of the original legally existing tract. Until subdivided, such omitted tract is not developable and does not constitute a lot of record for any purpose under the zoning regulations or until included in a record plat. 
b.  In a non-residential subdivision, omitted property is not developable and does not constitute a lot of record for any purpose under the zoning regulations or these regulations until included in a record plat. 
(2)  The record plat shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor or engineer at a scale of one inch equals 50 feet to one inch equals 100 feet in any increments of ten feet on one or more sheets whose maximum dimensions are 24 inches by 36 inches. In certain unusual instances where the subdivided area is of unusual size or shape, the community development director may permit a variation in the scale or size of the record plat. If more than one sheet is required, a key map on Sheet No. 1 showing the entire subdivision at reduced scale shall be provided. 
(3)  The applicant shall prepare and submit to the community development director seven copies of the record plat of the tract and a reduced copy of the plat measuring 11 inches by 17 inches. The submission shall be made in compliance with the submission schedule of deadlines established by the community development director. The community development director or his designee shall review the plat regarding standards of these regulations upon receipt of a complete application and provide any comments for revision to the applicant, directing the applicant to provide 25 copies and an electronic copy in a format suitable to the standards of the city to the planning division for inclusion on the next available agenda. 
(4)  The record plat shall show and be accompanied by the following information: 
a.  North arrow and graphic scale. 
b.  The boundary of the subdivision to state of state minimum surveying standards with bearings and distances tied to surveyed identification points, established section lines, fractional section lines or U.S. Survey lines and the boundary lines of municipalities, sewer districts, school districts and other legally established districts within the subdivision, as well as all adjoining lands and the right-of-way lines of adjacent streets and alleys including their widths and names. 
c.  The lines of all proposed streets and alleys with their pavement and right-of-way widths and names. 
d.  An accurate delineation of any property offered for dedication to public use. 
e.  Location, size and labeling of stormwater detention areas in common ground with feasible vehicular access a minimum of 20 feet in width. 
f.  The plat shall depict field surveyed limits of any natural watercourse and the associated riparian buffer to be left in their natural state or tree preservation areas subject to section 410.260 and shall provide a note to reference the surveyed limits stating: "There shall be no clearing, grading, construction or disturbance of vegetation except as permitted by, and in compliance with, applicable criteria in section 410.490 of the Wentzville Municipal Code." 
g.  All lot numbers in consecutive and logical order, lot lines and area of lots in square feet, including upon all lots utility easements providing minimum side yard easements at a width of five feet, front yard utility easements at a width of ten feet, rear yard utility easements at a width of five feet for internal lots in which a rear yard abuts another rear yard, and rear yard utility easements at a width of ten feet for exterior project lots. Additional easement width may be required by the city engineer. 
h.  Building lines, including notes to identify applicable front, side and rear yard setbacks on each lot, location and dimension of utility easements, rights-of-way provided for public or private use, centralized box unit mail receptacle easements, high pressure pipeline easements with respect to common ground area requirements imposed by section 405.440, pertaining to regulations for high pressure transmission pipelines. The city engineer shall require the common ground area to be dedicated as one blanket utility easement for all city-provided utilities. An additional 20-foot easement shall be provided for along all property lines in the common ground area for utility providers indicated upon the plat. 
i.  All dimensions and bearings, both linear and angular, radii and arcs, necessary for locating the boundaries of the subdivision, blocks, lots, streets, alleys, easements, building lines and of any other areas for public or private use. The linear dimensions are to be expressed in feet and decimals of a foot. 
j.  All survey monuments, together with their descriptions. 
k.  Use of private streets shall require disclosure within the owner's certificate for any new subdivision receiving record plat approval after the date of adoption, and the plat shall indicate the placement of a sign at the entrance to the development, within 50 feet of the centerline of the road, prior to the recording of the plat, which states "Private Streets, Maintained by the Property Owners." 
l.  Name of subdivision and legal description of property subdivided. 
m.  Certification by the land surveyor who performs the property survey to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him and that the locations of all required survey monuments, installed or to be installed, are correctly shown thereon. The month and year during which the survey was made shall also be shown. 
n.  Cul-de-sac islands and raised medians shall be located in public rights-of-way that are dedicated by the plat to the city. However, easements that encompass all portions of the cul-de-sac islands or medians but that are subordinated to the right-of-way dedication to the public by the plat shall be granted by the plat to the homeowners' association for maintaining vegetation, landscaping or subdivision monuments. Plats containing such easements for private subdivision improvements shall include script within the owner's certificate stating: 
"Maintenance of any landscaping, vegetation or subdivision monuments on cul-de-sac islands or medians within public rights-of-way shall be the responsibility of the subdivision homeowners' association. These improvements shall meet the requirements set forth in the engineering design manual and shall be reviewed and approved by the city engineer or his designee, and all improvements shall be compliant with the sight triangle provisions within the zoning regulations." 
o.  Zoning district and applicable primary structure zoning district setbacks. 
p.  Accurately note elevation referring to mean USGS datum for permanent bench mark. 
q.  All areas designated as areas for common use and enjoyment to subdivision lot owners shall be shown on the plat as common ground, that shall include all land within the plat that is subject to easements of record for pipelines and common ground imposed by section 405.440 under the jurisdiction of the federal department of transportation. No such plat shall be approved if it fails to include the pipeline within platted common ground. 
r.  Escrow guarantee of installation of all public improvements or other project improvements shall be established with the city engineering division as applicable and compliant with provisions of the engineering design criteria. 
s.  Verification of street names, subdivision name and street addresses from the county government. 
t.  Trust indenture compliant with the provisions of section 410.160. 
u.  Tax certificate or copy of paid tax bill from the office of the city and the county collector of revenue. 
v.  A digitized version of the plat that complies with city GIS mapping standards shall be submitted for city use and inclusion within the GIS. 
w.  A filing fee established by the city and set out in the city fee schedule. 
(5)  Commission action. If, after city staff review, the record plat is satisfactory under the requirements of this chapter, the community development director shall submit the record plat to the planning and zoning commission at their next regularly scheduled meeting. The planning and zoning commission shall then, within 60 days after submission of the plat to it, take action on the plat; otherwise the plat is deemed approved by the commission, except that the commission, with the consent of the applicant for approval, may extend the 60-day period. Unless postponed as set forth in subsection (b)(5)d of this section, the commission shall recommend that the board of aldermen take one of actions in subsection (b)(5)a-c of this section. 
a.  Approval. Approve the plat as submitted. 
b.  Conditional approval. Approve the plat conditionally or require amendments to the plat before granting full approval. 
c.  Disapproval. Disapprove the plat if the plat fails to comply with the applicable requirements of the city's zoning regulations, referencing reasons for disapproval. 
d.  Postponement. The planning and zoning commission may postpone its decision pending further study of the plat or for other good cause, but in no event shall its decision be postponed more than 60 days after submission of the plat, except that the commission, with the consent of the applicant for approval, may extend the 60-day period. 
(6)  Action by the board of aldermen. Upon receiving the commission's recommendation on the record plat, the plat shall be submitted to the board of aldermen for its final action. Action taken by the board of aldermen shall take one of the forms available to the planning and zoning commission in subsection (b)(5) of this section and shall be transmitted to the subdivider in writing. 
(7)  After approval of the record plat by the board of aldermen, the record plat shall be filed with the county recorder of deeds within six months from the date of approval. If any record plat is not filed within this period, the approval shall expire and a new application shall be required. 
(8)  Following recording of the record plat, one original copy of the subdivision plat bearing the county Recorder's signature, seal and notation as to plat book and page shall be returned to the city, along with similarly recorded copies of any covenants or deed restrictions accompanying the plat, before any building permits for any new construction will be issued. 
(9)  Any land dedicated to the city for park purposes in a subdivision shall be conveyed to the city free and clear of all encumbrances as approved in fee by the city at the same time the plat of subdivision is filed, the deeds to be without restrictions or covenants except requirement that the land be used for park purposes without reversion and with references to the subdivision, if any, on which the land is shown. 
(Code 2008, § 410.160; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 2011-3123, § 1, 1-26-2011; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011; Ord. No. 2017-3774, § 6, 9-27-2017) 
Sec. 410.160. - Trust indentures. 
(a)  In any case where the establishment of common land (including pedestrian walkways and cul-de-sac islands), private streets, upgraded/enhanced street lighting exceeding standard installation equipment, upgraded/enhanced street signage exceeding standard installation equipment, upgraded/enhanced pavement exceeding standard construction, United States Postal Service centralized box units (CBU) (mail receptacles and associated components and pavement in right-of-way or upon common land), stormwater drainage facilities, stormwater best management practices, such as detention structures or basins and drainage pipe and ditches, tree preservation areas or any other improvements that require continuous maintenance, a trust indenture shall be recorded simultaneously with the record plat. The indenture shall provide for proper maintenance and supervision by the trustees who are selected to act in accordance with the terms of such indenture and the applicable provisions of these regulations. For single lot developments and developments with no common ground, the city may accept script certifying the means of maintenance on the record plat. Common land shall be conveyed by the owner in fee simple absolute title by deed to the homeowners' association and the trust indentures shall provide that the common land and any permanent landscape easement be for the benefit, use and enjoyment of the lot owners present and future and shall be the maintenance responsibility of the homeowners' association of the subdivision and that no lot owner shall have the right to convey his/her interest in the common land except as an incident of the ownership of a regularly platted lot. 
(b)  Any trust indenture required to be recorded or recorded for compliance with provisions of these regulations or the zoning regulations shall provide for not less than the following representation of purchasers of developed lots among the trustees: one-third of the trustees shall be elected by purchasers of developed lots after 33 percent of the lots have been sold; two-thirds of the trustees shall be elected by purchasers of developed lots after 65 percent of the lots have been sold; and all of the trustees shall be elected by purchasers of developed lots after 90 percent of the lots have been sold. The trust indenture shall provide that within a timeframe not to exceed five years from the recording of the initial record plat for the subdivision, at least two-thirds of the trustees shall be elected by purchasers of developed lots irrespective of whether 65 percent or more of the developed lots of the subdivision have been sold. The trust indenture shall further state, "So long as the provision regarding selection of trustees exists in this Code, the corresponding provision of the trust indenture may not be amended without permission of the board of aldermen of the city." 
(c)  A trust indenture shall be required for a large lot subdivision only in the event that common land or other private improvement is contained within the subdivision. 
(d)  Term of indentures for all types of subdivisions, including planned districts, shall be for the duration of the subdivision. In the event the subdivision is vacated, fee simple title shall vest in then lot or unit owners as tenants in common. The rights of the tenants shall only be exercisable appurtenant to, and in conjunction with, their lot or unit ownership. Any conveyance or change of ownership of any lot or unit shall convey with it ownership in the common land and no interest in the common land shall be conveyed by a lot or unit owner except in conjunction with the sale of a lot or unit. The sale of any lot or unit shall carry with it all the incidents of ownership of the common land although such is not expressly mentioned in the deed; provided however, that no right or power conferred upon the trustees shall be abrogated. 
(e)  If a project provides for common property, a trust indenture shall provide for the payment of assessments by the property owners on no greater than a yearly basis beginning within one year of recording of the final plat; however, a payment schedule on less than a yearly basis may be included. For that period of time in which the developer appoints the majority of the trustees, the homeowners' association shall be responsible for the management of the assessment account. 
(f)  Subdivision indentures shall not prohibit builders of homes from maintaining signage on common ground and any private (non-public) right-of-way advertising the subdivision and homes for sale until the last home is sold in the subdivision. 
(g)  Any trust indenture required to be recorded for the purposes of compliance with the provisions of these regulations or the zoning regulations shall state, "Where the provisions of this trust indenture cannot be fulfilled by reason of unfilled vacancies among the directors or Trustees arising due to default or inaction by the developer, the board of aldermen of the city or its successors may, upon petition of any concerned resident or owner in the subdivision and upon providing advance written notice to such developer, appoint one or more directors or trustees to fill the vacancies until such time as directors or Trustees are elected or selected in the manner provided in this Indenture. So long as the provision regarding the city's appointment of directors and trustees to fill vacancies exists in this Code, the corresponding provision of the trust indenture may not be amended without permission of the board of aldermen." 
(Code 2008, § 410.170; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 2011-3124, § 1, 1-26-2011; Ord. No. 3536, § 3, 10-28-2015; Ord. No. 3563, § 2, 1-13-2016; Ord. No. 2017-3774, § 3, 9-27-2017) 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 410.170. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city is authorized under its police powers, RSMo 89.410 , to specify design requirements for streets, blocks, lots, utilities, recreation areas, other public facilities and hazardous areas, including land subject to flooding within the city. The city is also empowered to ensure that these standards are enforced as a condition of subdivision plat approval. 
(b)  These standards for public improvements shall be utilized to assure the conformance of new subdivisions to the city's comprehensive plan as well as the zoning regulations. Toward these goals, the commission is also given the authority to require the dedication, reservation or acquisition of lands and open spaces necessary for public uses indicated on the city plan so long as the required dedication is reasonably related to the subdivider's activity. 
(c)  The standards set forth in this article are minimum acceptable standards of design for safe, efficient and economical community development. The developer shall be responsible for providing the land and constructing those public improvements required to serve his development in conformance with the requirements of these regulations. 
(Code 2008, § 410.180; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.180. - Suitability of land for subdivision development. 
(a)  The following standards have been determined to be indispensable elements for desirable development. The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be designed to provide desirable building sites and logically related to topography, natural features, streets, parking areas, common land and adjacent land uses. If the planning commission finds that land proposed to be subdivided is unsuitable for subdivision development due to flooding, bad drainage, steep slopes, rock formations and other such natural features or conditions as may increase the danger of health, life or property, or aggravate erosion or flood hazards; and, if from adequate investigations conducted by all public agencies concerned, it has been determined that in the best interest of the public the land should not be platted and developed for the purpose proposed, the planning commission shall not approve the land for subdivision unless adequate methods are formulated by the subdivider for meeting the problems that will be created by the subdivision and the development of the land. 
(b)  The planning commission may deny scattered or premature subdivision of land which would involve danger or injury to the public health, safety or welfare by reason of lack of adequate water supply, schools, proper drainage, good roads and transportation facilities or other public services; or which would necessitate an excessive expenditure of public funds for supply of such services. 
(Code 2008, § 410.190; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.190. - Street standards. 
(a)  General standards. The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and proposed streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, roadway maintenance and access by emergency vehicles and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. In subdivision developments of more than 100 units, two or more access points to the city's street system shall be constructed. Streets shall be constructed in compliance with the requirements embodied within the engineering design criteria, latest edition and the construction specifications and standard detail documents as approved by the city engineer and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Easements and rights-of-way. The following requirements shall apply to all subdivisions except those demonstrating no attributable impact to the city's roadway system: 
(1)  Any subdivision platted along an existing street shall provide additional right-of-way conforming to the city transportation master plan and the classification, design criteria and standards of the engineering design criteria sections 7.03.01 through 7.03.03.01, as applicable. Dedicated rights-of-way shall be provided for proposed subdivisions that abut county roads or roads maintained by the state department of transportation (MoDOT). Additional right-of-way in excess of the standard dedication for widening may be required by the city engineer when the subdivision is located on the inside of a curved roadway or when conditions exist on the opposite side of the right-of-way that dictate right-of-way offset from the centerline. 
a.  When the subdivision is located on one side of an existing street, required right-of-way width shall be measured from the centerline of the right-of-way as originally established or as traveled. The centerline must meet requirements of the city engineer with regard to radius when located on a curved roadway. When the subdivision is located having more than one street frontage, right-of-way shall be provided along all road frontages, subject to preliminary plat review and approval. 
b.  Any subdivision platted along an existing street identified for widening and improvement conforming to the city transportation master plan shall provide a temporary construction easement/license not less than 20 feet in width granted to the city for future cuts, fills, grading, sloping embankments, construction drives or temporary roadways and utilities. The easement shall provide for its termination upon the completion of the roadway widening or improvement project. 
c.  Any subdivision platted that is located on property identified by an adopted corridor preservation plan by the city shall provide right-of-way to the city under the direction of the adopted corridor preservation plan. 
(2)  A subdivision plat involving new or existing streets crossing railroad tracks shall provide adequate rights-of-way, including approach rights-of-way and slope easements for construction of an underpass or overpass, unless otherwise specified by the planning and zoning commission. Approval of the state department of transportation and the city engineer must be received in connection with all railroad crossings. 
(3)  Where a cut or fill for a street extends beyond the limits of the right-of-way, the developer shall provide a slope easement or special escrow as determined by the city engineer to be of sufficient area and limits to permit the construction and maintenance of the slope. 
(c)  Construction and design. 
(1)  Streets in all zoning or land use categories shall be constructed to conform to the city engineering design criteria and the standard specifications and construction details as approved by the city engineer and recorded with the office of the city clerk. 
(2)  Private streets, including multiple-family access streets, shall have pavement thickness constructed to city standards. Maintenance of these streets shall be the sole responsibility of the property owners or trustees of the subdivision. 
(3)  All streets shall be graded and the roadway improved by surfacing. Roadway surfacing shall be in accordance with the city standard specifications and construction details as approved by the city engineer and recorded with the office of the city clerk. All grading and surfacing shall be done under observation and inspection of the city engineer and shall be subject to his approval. The treatment of the intersection of any new street with a state highway and any additional required widening of an adjoining state highway shall be subject to approval by the district engineer of this state department of transportation. 
(4)  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major street, the planning and zoning commission may require additional lot depth with landscape screen planting. Access to subdivided lots shall only be from internal project streets. 
(5)  In all developments, streets ending in a cul-de-sac turn-a-round shall not exceed 1,500 feet except as the community development director/city engineer deems necessary to secure the efficient use of land or desired features of street layout. A pavement radius of 55 feet shall be provided on streets ending at, or in excess of, 1,500 feet. 
(6)  All developments with lots solely fronting on arterial or collector streets shall provide a turnaround maneuvering area or provide side or rear entry garages as required in section 405.550(b) which eliminates having to back out onto streets. 
(Code 2008, § 410.200; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011; Ord. No. 3563, § 3, 1-13-2016) 
Sec. 410.200. - Street names and signs. 
(a)  Street names. 
(1)  Proposed through or collector streets that are continuations of, or are in general alignment with, existing named streets shall bear the names of such existing streets. 
(2)  The name of a proposed street that is not in alignment with an existing street shall not duplicate the name of any existing or platted street. 
(3)  All the names of streets proposed by the subdivider shall be approved by the county government prior to the approval of a record plat. 
(b)  Traffic signs. 
(1)  The subdivider shall bear all expense for the purchase and installation of traffic signs and signals as the result of his development. Installation size and height, type and location of all traffic signage shall comply with city engineering department standard construction details. 
(2)  If the subdivider proposed upgraded traffic signs exceeding standard installation equipment, the subdivider shall be responsible for the maintenance of upgraded/enhanced traffic signage, that shall be made a part of the homeowners' association responsibility for maintenance. Standard subdivision covenants and restrictions shall contain provisions to describe responsibility for maintenance. 
(c)  Street name change. Any proposed change to an existing street name shall be made in writing to the office of the community development director. The community development director shall accept the written request, if complete, indicating location and all necessary details for the city's review. The community development director shall notify the county government for name approval correspondence, the city administrator, public works director and other staff as applicable for review of the request. The planning division shall prepare a resolution to be presented to the board of aldermen at a regularly scheduled meeting. If the board deems it necessary to change the name of any street or avenue, the resolution shall be published for at least one week in a newspaper published within the city and notices shall be sent to all resident owners along the line of such street. The public advertisement shall be made in sufficient time to allow resident owners along such street to file with the city clerk written protests against the name change. If written protests from a majority of resident owners along the line of the street are not received after four weeks, the board of aldermen may have the power to change, by ordinance, the name of a street or avenue. The city clerk shall file with the county recorder of deeds a certified copy of such ordinance. The community development director shall send a written notification of the street name change, including a copy of the ordinance, to all resident owners along the line of the street, including local agencies and utilities as applicable. 
(Code 2008, § 410.210; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.210. - Disclosure of street maintenance responsibility. 
    Any developer, development corporation, lender, real estate broker, agent or management corporation selling or offering for sale or assisting in the sale of a lot in a subdivision with private streets shall inform in writing each prospective purchaser or tenant of the associated private street maintenance and repair responsibility. Roadways designated to be private shall be constructed to public roadway specifications as required by the engineering design criteria. These roadways shall remain private forever. Maintenance of private roadways will be the responsibility of the property owners or trustees forever. Use of private streets shall require disclosure upon the record plat under the requirements of section 410.150. 
(Code 2008, § 410.230; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.220. - Sidewalks and pedestrian ways. 
(a)  Sidewalk and pedestrian ways shall be constructed along all streets and within the city under the standards adopted within the engineering design criteria. 
(b)  The planning and zoning commission may require the construction of additional walkways not within the public right-of-way as pedestrian ways at a minimum width of not less than six feet, constructed of a minimum of three inches of asphalt or four inches of concrete on a prepared subgrade for access to parks, schools, shopping areas, public transportation facilities, common land or similar facilities or where otherwise required. 
(c)  Sidewalk variance procedure. A petitioner may apply for an alternate sidewalk plan through the utilization of the variance procedure in accordance with these regulations. The city engineer shall provide the board of aldermen with recommendations concerning conditions within road rights-of-way involved with a request for variance or alternate sidewalk plans. The board of aldermen may grant approval in the following cases: 
(1)  Where sidewalks are not deemed necessary for the public safety or where topographical or other conditions make their installation and use impractical. 
(2)  Where tracts of land are created having at least 300 feet of frontage which could be resubdivided into smaller lots at a future time. 
(3)  Where the subdivision designer has submitted for review a proposed sidewalk plan that provides for more direct and safer movement of pedestrian traffic. 
(4)  Where justifiable conditions can be shown that the strict application of the requirements contained in this section or the engineering design criteria would: 
a.  Impose practical difficulties or particular hardship or cause additional walks that would not be in the public interest; and 
b.  Public safety could be adequately accommodated without the sidewalks. 
(Code 2008, § 410.240; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.230. - Stormwater standards; storm sewers. 
    Adequate provisions shall be made for the conveyance and handling of stormwater in accordance with the city engineering design criteria. Installation of storm sewers shall conform to the city standard specifications and construction details. 
(Code 2008, § 410.250; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.240. - Sanitary sewers. 
(a)  Sanitary sewers available. Where an approved public sanitary sewer system is located within 200 feet of a property line and meets the requirements of the state department of natural resources and the city engineer, the developer/owner shall connect with such sanitary sewer and provide an adequate service connection to each lot. Sewer connections and subdivision sewer systems shall comply with the regulations of the state department of natural resources and engineering design criteria satisfactory to the city engineer and shall be constructed under the observation and inspection of the city engineer. Extension of the city sanitary sewer service to residents or businesses or industries not in the city shall require prior annexation into the city for use and benefit of this city utility, unless waived by the board of aldermen pursuant to section 715.070. 
(b)  Sanitary sewers not accessible or planned. Where no sewers are accessible and no plans for same have been prepared, individual sewage disposal systems shall not be used except in large lot subdivisions. A developer may install an individual sewage disposal system for each lot, if the following criteria are met: 
(1)  Each lot shall contain the area determined as adequate by the city engineer to meet current health standards but shall in no case be smaller than three acres in size. 
(2)  The individual sewage disposal system shall comply with the regulations and requirements of the state department of natural resources. 
(3)  Each disposal system shall be constructed under the observation, inspection and approval by the city engineer. 
(4)  The applicant/owner shall provide written authorization from the county government. 
(c)  Sanitary sewer extensions. Where city utilities are extended to access new or existing property, the city shall require extension sewer infrastructure through the development property as directed by the city engineer for future connection, growth and development, that shall also include city's participation in upsizing sanitary sewer infrastructure as set forth in chapter 3, utilities, of the city wastewater collection and treatment plan. 
(Code 2008, § 410.260; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.250. - Water mains. 
(a)  Potable water available. An approved public water supply shall be made available to each lot within the subdivided area in conformance with the current city standard construction specifications and engineering design criteria of the city. Extension of the city water service to residents or businesses or industries not in the city shall require prior annexation into the city for use and benefit of this city utility, unless waived by the board of aldermen pursuant to section 715.070. 
(b)  Potable water extensions. Where city utilities are extended to access new or existing property, the city shall require extension water infrastructure through the development property as directed by the city engineer for future connection, growth and development, that shall also include city's participation in upsizing water infrastructure as set forth in chapter 3, utilities, of the city water supply and distribution plan. 
(Code 2008, § 410.270; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.260. - Tree preservation requirements. 
(a)  Purpose. In furtherance of the goals of the comprehensive plan and the zoning regulations of the city, it is the purpose of this section to promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the preservation of trees within the city. These standards are designed to enhance the quality and appearance of developed properties, protect existing natural resources, buffer differing land uses and conserve the value of land and buildings throughout the city. These standards will also buffer noise and wind, increase energy efficiency through shading and cooling, filter air pollution, assist in the management of stormwater and provide wildlife habitat as well as pleasant visual relief. 
(b)  Applicability. These standards apply to all residential subdivisions within the city except the following: 
(1)  Individual single-family residences not in a proposed or existing subdivision. 
(2)  Individual two-family residences not in a proposed or existing subdivision. 
(3)  Individual multi-family residences not in a proposed or existing subdivision. 
(4)  Subdivisions within the "A," "PD-R" and "PD-MXD" zoning districts. 
(5)  Subdivisions which meet the criteria of "lot splits" as found within section 410.410. 
(6)  The proposed site has less than or equal to five percent of the proposed subdivision in woodlands as depicted on an aerial photo of at least three years prior to submittal. In developments which meet this criterion, an inventory of all landmark trees on the site shall be submitted in association with and depicted upon the preliminary plat. 
(c)  Plan requirements. 
(1)  All residential preliminary subdivision plats shall delineate the anticipated tree preservation limits to be known as the tree preservation plan. Tree preservation information supplied on the preliminary plat shall be as follows: 
a.  The approximate limit of all tree preservation areas. 
b.  Approximate areas where trees are to be removed. Areas showing removal shall be hatched or color coded. 
c.  Estimated acreage calculations for the preservation areas. 
d.  Aerial photo showing the area of trees as they existed three years prior to submittal. Tree preservation areas shall be determined from this aerial photo as a base line for compliance with this section. 
e.  Identification of all landmark trees on the site prior to development in areas that are planned to be disturbed or graded, excluding riparian buffer areas as defined in this chapter. 
(2)  The final tree preservation plan shall be included with the grading plan prior to any land disturbance for a site and have the following: 
a.  Property boundary including north arrow and scale. 
b.  The proposed layout of all lots and public and private rights-of-way. 
c.  Existing and proposed topographic data for the site. 
d.  The location of all known and proposed easements and utility infrastructure. 
e.  The limits of all tree preservation areas to the edge of the canopy drip line, excluding riparian buffer areas as defined in this chapter. 
(d)  Tree preservation requirements. 
(1)  All non-exempt subdivisions shall meet the following standards: 
a.  Subdivisions with between 15 percent and less than 50 percent of the total site in woodlands must preserve a minimum of 15 percent of the total site in woodlands. 
b.  Subdivisions equal to or greater than 50 percent of the total site in woodlands must preserve 25 percent of the total site in woodlands. 
c.  Subdivisions greater than five percent and less than 15 percent of total site in woodlands shall submit a report to the planning and zoning commission requesting to waive or amend tree preservation requirements of this section listing reasons, including, but not limited to: 
1.  Percentage of existing woodlands on site. 
2.  Percentage of woodlands that shall be preserved in lieu of the required 15 percent. 
3.  A tree inventory of the existing woodlands prior to development. A tree inventory shall include, but not be limited to, the location and species of all landmark trees within the proposed subdivision and quality of existing trees on site (cedars, underbrush, dead trees, location of trees/woodlands, etc.). 
Upon review of this information, the planning and zoning commission shall make a recommendation to the board of aldermen associated with a preliminary plat on the merits of waiving or amending the tree preservation requirement. No credit will be given to a tree or any portion of a tree canopy that is not located on the subject property. 
(2)  Tree preservation areas shall be located within the following: 
a.  Within common ground; or 
b.  Tree preservation areas may be located within proposed lots, however, shall be protected with a tree preservation easement. 
1.  Tree preservation easements shall be delineated on all record plats, with the plat containing script which dedicates the tree preservation areas to the homeowners' association for the preservation of trees. 
2.  All tree preservation areas shall be noted on the grading plans, improvement plans and all record plats with the following text: "There shall be no clearing, grading, construction or disturbance of trees except as permitted by section 410.260 of the Wentzville Municipal Code." 
3.  If tree preservation areas lay within a designated natural watercourse as defined in section 410.530, no additional script referring to the tree preservation area is required. 
(e)  Protective methods. To maintain compliance with this section, trees to be preserved must be protected from direct and indirect root damage and trunk and crown disturbance. No areas for tree preservation will be allowed for any dead tree and tree in poor health or any tree subject to grade alterations. The following standards shall apply: 
(1)  The protection area around trees shall include all land within the canopy drip line. This area shall remain free from all grading and filling activities. 
(2)  Construction site activities such as, but not limited to, parking, material storage, soil stock piling and concrete washout shall not be permitted within tree protection areas. 
(3)  Tree protection areas should be clearly identified prior to any land disturbance, compliant with a method declared upon the final tree preservation plan. Methods that may be used include snow fence and other fencing or construction stakes. 
(4)  Signs shall be used to designate tree protection areas to be installed and maintained in good condition by the developer. Signs are to be posted visibly on all sides of the preservation area and must be visible throughout the development process. Minimum size for the signs is 24 inches by 36 inches and should state the following: "TREE PROTECTION AREA-Machinery access, dumping or storage of materials and equipment or removal of trees is prohibited." 
(f)  Permitted structures within tree preservation areas. No structures (attached or detached) are allowed within tree preservation areas. Fencing is allowed within tree preservation areas subject to section 405.490. 
(g)  Waiver. The public works director or his designee may grant a waiver after final approval allowing tree preservation areas to be disturbed only in cases of public purpose and necessity or only upon the director's approval of designed site development erosion control measures. 
(h)  Enforcement and penalties. The public works director is hereby charged with the responsibility of administering and enforcing the provisions of the tree preservation program. Removal of trees destroyed or substantially damaged as a result of an act of God shall be exempt from this section. Violations are subject to the general penalty provision of section 410.580. If the tree preservation area drops below the required preservation requirements as set forth in the tree preservation plan for a subdivision approved pursuant to this section, except for canopy removed for distribution of public utilities or as waived/amended by the board of aldermen, the subdivision developer, homeowners' association or other responsible person or persons shall provide the city with a tree assessment prepared by a professional arborist which includes a replanting plan based on the area of woodland canopy removed. The replacement plan shall document a replacement ratio of two hardwood trees to each tree destroyed, damaged or removed within a designated tree preservation area at a size of 21/2 inches in caliper is required to be planted in the subdivision. For purposes of calculating the number of trees to be replaced under a replacement plan, the replacement plan shall assess 200 square feet for each tree within designated woodland. For example, where a subdivision falls 2,000 square feet below the requirement, the following formula would be used: 2,000 square feet divided by 200 square feet equals ten trees removed. Therefore, at the replacement ratio of 2:1, 20 trees would need to be replaced. 
(i)  Performance guarantee. A performance guarantee in accordance with section 410.140 shall be established by the developer prior to construction with surety and other reasonable conditions providing for and securing tree preservation and the viability of plantings in full compliance with the final tree preservation plan. 
(j)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    DBH means the diameter of a tree measured at 41/2 feet above ground; diameter breast height (DBH). 
    Drip line means the outermost perimeter of the crown of a plant as projected vertically to the ground. 
    Tree canopy means the area in square feet of a tree's spread. Existing tree canopy is determined by measuring the ground's surface area that is covered by the branch spread of a single tree. 
    Tree, landmark, means a tree that is in fair or better condition (as defined by standards developed by International Society of Arboriculture) and that equals or exceeds the diameter sizes as follows: 
(1)  Large hardwood (oaks, hickories, etc.): 24 inches DBH. 
(2)  Large softwoods (pines, spruces, etc.): 20 inches DBH. 
A tree in "fair or better" condition is defined as a tree having a normal life expectancy, a relatively sound and solid trunk with no extensive decay, no more than one major and several minor dead limbs (hardwoods only) and no major insect or disease problems. A lesser-sized tree can be considered a landmark tree if it is a rare or unusual species, of exceptional quality or historically significance. Landmark trees may be designated by the board of aldermen after recommendation by the city tree board. 
    Tree preservation area means all land within the canopy drip line of a tree as depicted on the approved tree preservation plan or other plans. 
    Woodland means deciduous hardwood tree varieties with a canopy over 5,000 square feet having at least 30 percent of the trees with a caliper of at least 21/2 inches. 
    Woodland canopy means the total area of canopy within woodland. 
(Code 2008, § 410.275; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.270. - Grading. 
(a)  Where the preliminary plat indicates that extensive grading and compaction are probable, the city engineer may require the submission of additional information and modifications in the proposed plat before the developer may grade any land to be subdivided. 
(b)  Prior to any grading on the site, a grading permit or construction permit is required in accordance with provisions of chapter 515 and the city engineering design criteria, as applicable. 
(c)  Proposed grading which creates a change in watersheds shall not be permitted. 
(Code 2008, § 410.280; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3582, § 1, 3-23-2016) 
Sec. 410.280. - Single-family residential lot design standards. 
(a)  Generally. The design standards set forth in this section are the minimum design standards to be used by the single-family residential subdivision and are standards for desirable development. Unless otherwise set forth below, the standards and procedures established elsewhere in these regulations as applicable to all subdivisions shall apply to residential subdivisions as well. 
(b)  Street frontage. Each proposed lot shall front upon a street accepted by, or improved to, the standards and specifications of the city. 
(c)  Double frontage parcels. 
(1)  Lots with double frontage should be avoided, except where necessary to provide separation of the subdivision from traffic arteries, or as otherwise required by topography or similar conditions. 
(2)  Solid fencing or other improvement (including walls, landscape plantings or earthen berms) may be required by the board of aldermen after recommendation from the planning and zoning commission for screening along the line of lots abutting such a collector or arterial street, subject to preliminary plat approval. Buffering improvements, if required, shall be within common ground or an easement to be maintained by the property owners or subdivision trustees. 
(3)  Lots with double frontage shall have driveway access to the internal subdivision street or minor street. 
(d)  Lot area calculations. 
(1)  The lot area shall meet the requirements of the zoning regulations. 
(2)  Where additional street widening is to be accomplished via right-of-way dedication along existing streets, calculations of the area of a lot shall not include the dedication area in determining the gross area of the lot. 
(e)  Minimum width of lots at required building line. Residential lots shall conform to the minimum lot width requirements within the zoning regulations at the required building line. Sufficient width shall be provided to permit compliance with existing zoning district standards. The minimum width at the right-of-way line for lots fronting on a curved or cul-de-sac street shall be not less than 36 feet tangent to the right-of-way. 
(f)  Side lot lines. Side lot lines shall be right angles to straight streets and radial to curved streets except when radial lot lines detract from the desirability of the lot. 
(g)  Corner lots. 
(1)  Corner lots for residential use shall have adequate width to permit appropriate building lines from both streets. 
(2)  Corner lots located at the intersection of major and minor roadways shall have driveway access from the minor roadway. 
(3)  Driveways shall be located as far from the street intersection as practicable and will not under any circumstances be permitted within the sight distance triangle serving the intersection as described in the zoning regulations. 
(h)  Exceptional development conditions. Where there is a question as to the suitability of a lot or lots for their intended use due to factors such as rock formations, soil conditions, steepness of terrain, flood conditions or other adverse natural physical conditions, the planning and zoning commission may, after adequate investigation, withhold a recommendation for approval of such lots until engineering studies are presented to the planning and zoning commission which establish that the method proposed to meet any such condition is adequate to avoid any danger to public safety, health and welfare, or lot improvement. 
(Code 2008, § 410.290; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.290. - Multiple-family subdivision design standards. 
(a)  Generally. The design standards as set forth in this section are the minimum standards for the multiple-family residential subdivision. Unless otherwise set forth below, the standards and procedures established elsewhere in these regulations as applicable to all subdivisions shall apply to multiple-family subdivisions as well. 
(b)  Multiple-family parcels. A multiple-family residential subdivision may consist of only one parcel of land or may include separate lots for one or more multi-family buildings. 
(c)  Street frontage. Each proposed lot shall front on a street accepted by, or improved to, the standards and specifications of the city. 
(d)  Multiple-family access streets. Notwithstanding any other provision of these regulations, private roadways primarily intended to service parking areas as determined by the community development director shall not be considered streets for sidewalks. However, pedestrian access must be provided from the interior of the development to the public right-of-way sidewalks. 
(e)  Landscaping. Landscaping and screening shall follow the standards in section 405.190, "R-3B" multi-family zoning district. Additional landscape standards are provided in section 405.560, which may be used as a guide for minimum type, size and location criteria. The landscape plan shall be reviewed by the planning and zoning commission as a part of the plat review process. The planning and zoning commission shall review the landscape plan and provide a recommendation to the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen shall review and approve of a landscape plan associated with all multi-family residential subdivision development. 
(f)  Parking areas. Covered parking bays on multiple-family access streets may be accepted by the community development director to satisfy off-street parking space requirements in multiple-family subdivisions. Parking space dimensions and isle width dimensions shall comply with sections 405.550(h) and 405.600. 
(Code 2008, § 410.300; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.300. - Large lot, cluster subdivision design standards. 
(a)  Generally. The design standards, as set forth in this section, are minimum standards for desirable development of lots and building sites logically related to topography, natural features, watercourses, streets, adjacent uses and similar assets the preservation of which will add to the attractiveness and value of the subdivision. These standards are applicable upon the application and approval of subdivision developments in the "A" agricultural, "R-1A" single-family residential and planned development zoning district related to cluster development in section 405.270(e)(3). Unless otherwise set forth below, the standards and procedures established elsewhere in these regulations as applicable to all subdivisions shall apply to large lot subdivisions. 
(b)  Street frontage: Each proposed lot shall front upon a street accepted by and improved to the standards and specifications of the city, except for planned developments where clustering is proposed under the requirements of section 405.270(e)(3) in which the ordinance and associated development plan shall allow a right-of-way width not less than 30 feet and pavement width of 24 feet. 
(c)  Lot design standards. In addition to the standards of section 410.280, the following requirements shall apply, provided that for planned developments where clustering is proposed under the requirements of section 405.270(e)(3), the ordinance and the associated development plan shall allow certain exceptions related to lot area, layout and design for planned developments: 
(1)  Access for proposed lots may be provided by private roadway easements. Lots with double frontage shall have driveway access to the internal private roadway or minor street. Alternative access shall only be approved by the board of aldermen after recommendation by the planning and zoning commission, associated with a cluster development under the requirements of section 405.270(e)(3). 
(2)  Building setbacks of the zoning district shall be observed from designated private roadway easement lines and public right-of-way, with the exception of subdivision development in a planned development zoning district, in which lot standards shall be established by the ordinance and development plan for each individual subdivision. 
(3)  Where there is a question as to the feasibility of access to a desirable building site from the proposed roadway due to factors such as creeks, steepness of terrain, appropriate sight distance or other adverse natural physical conditions, the planning and zoning commission may withhold a recommendation for approval until engineering studies are presented to the planning and zoning commission which establish that the site is accessible. 
(d)  Improvements. 
(1)  Complete improvement plans shall be required for all large lot and cluster development subdivisions. 
(2)  All proposed improvements shall be constructed to current city standards and specifications or approved development standards within a planned development zoning district adopted via the ordinance and development plan associated with the subdivision. 
(e)  Streets. 
(1)  Private roadway easements shall have a minimum width of 50 feet. Minimum pavement requirements set forth in the street design criteria are applicable to roadway easements for servicing large lot subdivisions. 
(2)  When a large lot subdivision is proposed in the city adjacent to a street that is accepted and maintained by the city, right-of-way dedication may be required as necessary for the relocation or widening for the adjoining city road, as depicted within the transportation master plan. 
(f)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of all streets unless modified through the provisions of a cluster planned development zoning district ordinance and the associated development plan by the board of aldermen after recommendation by the planning and zoning commission. 
(g)  Water supply. An approved public water supply shall be made available to each lot within the subdivided area in conformance with the requirements of section 410.250. 
(h)  Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewer service shall be made available to each lot within the subdivided area in conformance with section 410.240. 
(i)  Landscaping. A landscape plan shall not be required for large lot subdivisions, with the exception that a landscape plan shall be required for cluster developments within the planned development zoning district under the standards in section 405.270(e)(3), as applicable. 
(j)  Storm water standards. Each project shall comply with city stormwater regulations as set forth in the engineering design criteria. 
(k)  Private agreements. A trust indenture shall be required for any subdivision in which private stormwater or recreational amenities/improvements are proposed that shall be maintained by the development's property owners. A trust indenture shall be reviewed by the city prior to the signing of the record plat for recording purposes and shall be referenced on the record plat. 
(Code 2008, § 410.310; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.310. - Non-residential subdivision design standards. 
(a)  Generally. The design standards as set forth in this section are the minimum design standards to be used by the non-residential subdivider. Unless otherwise set forth below, the standards and procedures established elsewhere in these regulations as applicable to all subdivisions shall apply to non-residential subdivisions as well. 
(b)  Lots. 
(1)  The lot size, width and depth shall be appropriate for the location and type of development contemplated and shall conform to the requirements of the zoning regulations for the district in which the non-residential subdivision is proposed. 
(2)  A minimum road frontage as required by the zoning regulations or direct access by a minimum 50-foot road easement or right-of-way or recorded cross easement shall be required for non-residential lots. 
(3)  Off-street loading shall be arranged to eliminate use of the adjacent street for maneuvering of vehicles using loading facilities. 
(c)  Blocks. There shall be no restriction of maximum block length in a non-residential subdivision. 
(d)  Sidewalks and pedestrian ways. Sidewalks shall not be required in a non-residential subdivision developed in an "I-1" or "I-2" industrial zoning district unless required by the planning and zoning commission and board of aldermen via subdivision plat review where it is determined that paved pedestrian trail access or sidewalks to schools, parks, institutional uses, shopping areas or similar facilities is necessary to ensure the public safety or as required by the trail master plan or the city comprehensive plan. 
(e)  Lighting; purpose and intent. It is the intent of this section to establish measures of lighting by which the negative aspects of excessive or careless light use can be minimized while preserving safety, security and the nighttime use and enjoyment of property. 
(1)  Parking area lighting. 
a.  Parking area lighting shall be required for all new public parking lots used by patrons of the property associated with the primary use of the property, designed and installed so as to achieve the illumination levels set forth below. Lighting shall be maintained so as to achieve not less than 80 percent of the minimum illumination levels set forth by the following table. 
b.  The planning and zoning commission may accept and recommend to the board of aldermen lighting arrangements exceeding the maximum initial level set forth below to allow lighting designs for specific land uses which substantially exceed the required illumination levels. 
ILLUMINATION STANDARDS IN FOOTCANDLES 
FOR STRUCTURES AND THEIR PARKING AREAS 
Residential Commercial/Industrial Other Minimum initial at any point on the parking area 0.07 0.5 0.3 Maximum initial level 5.0 12.0 8.0 Maximum initial level at the exterior property line 0.5 0.5 0.5  
c.  The source of pole standard illumination shall not be lower than ten feet above grade except as approved by the community development director. 
(2)  For the purpose of this subsection, the term "residential" refers to areas that are zoned "R-1A" through "R-1E," "R-2" or "R-3B" zoning districts, and the term "commercial/industrial" refers to parking areas for any land use, regardless of zoning designation, in which goods or services are offered on the premises, or office warehouse, wholesale operations are present. 
(3)  Lighting of recreational facilities for public parks and publicly owned facility such as a public school or city recreational sports complex shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. Shielding and lighting installations shall be designed to achieve no greater luminance levels for activity as recommended by the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America (IESNA) or similar association/organization. 
(4)  The use of laser source light or any similar high intensity light for outdoor advertising or entertainment, including the operation of searchlights for advertising purposes, is prohibited, unless permitted by the planning and zoning commission under an application pursuant to the requirements of section 405.1270(b)(1)c. 
(5)  The applicant for all new development shall indicate compliance with this section. The city may require documents to be certified by a lighting certified designer. Initial readings as required by this section shall be provided with a light loss factor of one (1.0). 
(6)  Light standards shall be maintained in compliance with the initial installation. Leaning, rusting or damaged poles/fixtures shall be repaired, removed or replaced. 
(7)  Alternative lighting applications/arrangements, used to illuminate on-site features, fixtures or amenities, shall be accomplished in compliance with standards of this section. 
(Code 2008, § 410.320; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.320. - Residential lot landscape requirements. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Optimal planting means trees shall be planted during the months of April through October for optimal survival. Exception: During winter months (November through March), trees may be guaranteed to be planted in accordance with the rules established for the tree deposit fund. 
    Residential lot means a lot in a single-family detached and single-family attached residential subdivision.
