    Required tree means a tree of one inch caliper in size of the following species: Softwood varieties and all hardwoods identified in section 405.290(f)(3)e, or as otherwise approved by the community development director. 
    Tree board means the board established pursuant to chapter 245. 
    Tree deposit guarantee means a form supplied by the city to be filled out by builder to ensure the planting of a tree upon any second failure of the final occupancy inspection due to lack of a required tree. 
    Tree deposit fund means a fund established hereunder to ensure the installation of a required tree within the corporate limits of the city. The tree deposit fund shall be monitored and maintained by the community development department and finance department. 
(b)  Required trees. For each residential lot developed pursuant to these subdivision regulations, the developer or homebuilder shall provide and plant a minimum of one tree for every lot or unit prior to inspection by the city to verify completion and compliance with this section upon builder's application for occupancy permit (the "yard inspection") and may be included as a condition upon a temporary occupancy permit. 
(c)  Planting. 
(1)  Because the success of the planting hinges greatly on the climate during tree planting, required trees shall be planted only during optimal planting times. When a builder seeks an occupancy permit during non-optimal planting times, the builder shall be issued a temporary occupancy permit for the required tree. The temporary occupancy shall be for the time period between the application for occupancy permit and the next period of optimal planting. A re-inspection date shall be set for May 15 or as soon thereafter as can be scheduled. Trees not installed within 30 days of their re-inspection date (after May 15 shall require the builder to make a deposit of $150.00 times the required number of trees based upon the number of lots or units for which occupancy permits are requested (the "tree deposit") and enter into a tree deposit guarantee. The tree deposit amount is hereby determined to be the estimated cost to provide the required tree and shall be deposited exclusively in the tree deposit fund. 
(2)  Exception: Where a lot owner declines to have a required tree planted on their lot for any reason, the builder and owner may request that builder either: 
a.  Plant, subject to the city's approval of location, the required tree elsewhere in the development in which the lot is situated; or 
b.  Make a deposit into the tree fund for a planting elsewhere in the city. 
Builder and owner must notify the community development department of this desire on a form provided by the city prior to the final occupancy inspection. 
(d)  Failure to establish tree deposit or plant trees. Any builder who fails to timely establish the tree deposit pursuant to a tree deposit guarantee shall be in violation of this section. Any builder who has established a tree deposit but fails to plant the required trees (either on the subject lot or elsewhere pursuant to subsection (c)(1) of this section) by the second inspection date shall forfeit the tree deposit funds to the city to be used by the tree board in conjunction with the community development department to ensure planting of the required tree on the subject lot or within the development site where possible. The tree board shall utilize the tree deposit funds within one calendar year from the date of receipt of the funds to install trees within the city during optimal planting times. 
(e)  Coordination of inspections/verification. 
(1)  Inspections and verification of tree plantings will be administered by the department of building safety in conjunction with the verification of yard installations at the final and occupancy permit inspection. 
(2)  During the months of November through May, temporary occupancy permits will be issued due to inclement weather. 
(3)  During the months of May through October, all yards and trees planted shall be installed per this section. The building official may grant extensions of time during the summer due to rain or drought conditions. 
(f)  Further authority. In addition to the above, the community development department is hereby authorized and directed to establish reasonable rules and policies to carry out the intent of this section and to supervise the tree deposit fund and tree planting including: 
(1)  Providing for, upon city verification of completion of the required tree installation, the city finance department to return the tree deposit; and 
(2)  Providing for the tree board to use any forfeited tree deposit funds for the purchase and planting of trees in city parks, rights-of-way, or other public places; and 
(3)  Development of forms for the tree deposit guarantee, owner's declination of acceptance of required tree, and such other necessary forms; and 
(4)  Providing for issuance of occupancy permits upon establishment of a tree deposit guarantee and tree deposit; and 
(5)  Providing that second inspections be subject to administrative fees as with all other occupancy inspections. 
(g)  Tree location. Location of new trees upon a lot or other area within a subdivision shall not be allowed within the following areas: 
(1)  Street rights-of-way; 
(2)  25 feet of street lights; 
(3)  At street intersections or within the required 30 feet sight triangle; and 
(4)  Ten feet of street inlets or manholes. 
(h)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a fine in accordance with section 100.190. 
(Code 2008, § 410.330; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3028, § 1, 9-23-2009; Ord. No. 2012-3203, § 1, 1-25-2012) 
Sec. 410.330. - Survey monuments. 
(a)  Location. Where none are currently existing, permanent survey monuments shall be placed by a registered land surveyor compliant with the following: 
(1)  At all points of deflection in the subdivision out-boundary. 
(2)  At rear property lot corners. 
(3)  At front property corners by cutting a cross in the adjacent curbing or in the street centerline or other acceptable practice. 
(b)  Offsets. Should conditions prohibit the placing of any monuments at the above locations, offsetting of the permanent marker is permitted; provided however, that the exact offset courses and distances are shown on the letter of certification when monuments are set as well as upon the subdivision record plat. If a monument would be in a driveway, a cross would be permitted in concrete or steel pin or iron pipe. 
(c)  Benchmarks. An existing permanent benchmark, or new permanent benchmark as may be required by the city engineer, shall be accessibly established and accurately noted upon the subdivision record plat. 
(Code 2008, § 410.340; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.340. - Underground wiring. 
    All electric, cable television and telephone distribution lines shall be installed underground, except those overhead distribution utility poles and feeder lines necessary to serve that subdivision and in locations as approved by the city engineer/community development director. Cable switching enclosures, pad-mounted transformers and service pedestals may also be installed above ground and located out of applicable sight triangles and may be installed as a part of the street lighting standards where approved by the city engineer. The city engineer/community development director may accept a request for above ground installations in whole or part for non-residential subdivisions only when a request is submitted by the developer with documentation that supports the impracticability of installing such utility lines underground. Facilities subject to this section shall also comply with the regulations established in section 405.450. 
(Code 2008, § 410.350; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
ARTICLE IV. - ACCEPTANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 410.350. - Administration and inspection. 
(a)  The construction of all improvements shall be inspected for conformance with the approved improvement plans by the city engineer or his designee, as well as any other agency, such as the state highways and transportation department (MoDOT), as the development impacts their jurisdiction. 
(b)  Prior to commencing construction of any improvements, the developer shall apply for and pay the requested fees for a construction permit in accordance with the city engineering design criteria. Fees have been determined by the board of aldermen to be the amount needed to defray the city's costs of administration, review, and inspections of the plans and development. In addition to any permit fees paid, the public works director shall be authorized to assess additional fees deemed necessary for the inspection work performed outside of normal business hours of the city. 
(c)  If the city engineer finds, upon inspection, that any of the required improvements have not been constructed in accordance with the city's construction standards and specifications, as well as the approved improvement plan, the developer shall be responsible for completing the improvements. Until such improvements are satisfactorily completed, no improvement guarantee, building or occupancy permit shall be granted. 
(Code 2008, § 410.370; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3582, § 2, 3-23-2016) 
Sec. 410.360. - Soils report. 
    The city engineer may require evidence as to the subsurface soil, rock and water conditions of the tract to be developed, both within the boundaries of the subdivision generally as well as within the specific locations of subdivision streets or other improvements. 
(Code 2008, § 410.375; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 2011-3125, § 1, 1-26-2011) 
Sec. 410.370. - As-built drawings. 
    After the sanitary sewers, storm sewers, water lines, sidewalks and pavement have been constructed and installed, but before the inspecting agencies recommend final approval or acceptance of the improvements, the developer shall submit the required number of as-built drawings conforming to the requirement as outlined in the city engineering design criteria. 
(Code 2008, § 410.380; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.380. - Acceptance of improvements. 
(a)  The board of aldermen will not accept dedication of the improvements until the following steps have occurred: 
(1)  All required improvements have been constructed. 
(2)  As-built plans of the constructed improvements have been submitted to the city engineer. 
(3)  The city engineer acknowledges that all external inspecting agencies (state highways, county highways, etc.) have accepted those improvements that fall under their jurisdiction. 
(4)  The city engineer certifies that those improvements which fall under the city's jurisdiction have been constructed in conformance with the city's construction standards and specifications. 
(5)  An affidavit, the form having been approved by the city attorney, shall be furnished, indicating that the improvements have been completed, are ready for dedication to the city, and that they are free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. 
(6)  Compliance with release of guarantee requirements in section 410.140. 
(b)  Once the requirements of this section have been met, the board of aldermen shall adopt an ordinance accepting the improvement for maintenance. Such ordinance or resolution may also incorporate final or partial release of the improvement guarantee securing the construction of all subdivision improvements. 
(Code 2008, § 410.400; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3016, § 1, 8-26-2009) 
Sec. 410.390. - Maintenance and repair of the improvements. 
    The developer shall be responsible for the maintenance, repair and upkeep of the improvements as well as snow plowing of the streets until final acceptance for maintenance by the city. The developer shall be responsible for all damage done to the improvements by construction traffic, local traffic or by any other means regardless of any causation or fault by the developer and shall ensure the accessibility to all occupied lots until final acceptance for maintenance by the city. Upon completion of work and before public acceptance, the developer shall clean up all ground occupied or affected in connection with the work. Failure to maintain or repair improvements may result in withholding approval of subsequent units of the subdivision or the billing of the developer for such service performed by the city. Payment shall be guaranteed by the performance bond. 
(Code 2008, § 410.410; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
ARTICLE V. - SPECIAL PROCEDURES 

Sec. 410.400. - Dwelling unit display plat procedure. 
(a)  Purpose. This section provides a procedure whereby the construction of a display house or multiple-family display unit can begin prior to the recording of the record subdivision plat. 
(b)  Procedure. After receiving a recommendation from the planning and zoning commission and approval from the board of aldermen of a preliminary plat of a proposed subdivision, the developer may submit three copies of a display plat to the community development director for review and approval. There may be two display houses or units for subdivisions proposing less than ten lots or units. Developments containing at least ten lots or units and not more than 60 lots or units proposed shall be allowed three display houses. For developments containing greater than 60 lots or units one additional display house or unit for every 20 houses or units proposed beyond 60 will be permitted, not to exceed ten display houses or units. 
(c)  Display plat. The display plat shall include a complete outboundary survey of the proposed subdivision or portion of the subdivision for construction of the display homes and the location of each display in relation to proposed lots. The plat shall comply with the requirements of the city, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The display plat shall indicate the manner of parking for the display units. Off-street parking spaces shall be paved with temporary asphalt pavement and the pavement shall be removed upon the cessation of its use as a display home and prior to sale by the display homeowner to the ultimate purchaser. The plat shall contain general notes in information including the property zoning, applicable zoning district setbacks, driveway locations and planned easements for the development. 
(2)  The display plat shall become null and void upon the recording of a record plat which establishes that each display is on an approved lot of record. 
(3)  No part of the proposed subdivision may be conveyed, nor an occupancy permit issued, for any structure therein until the display house or units have been located on an approved lot of record in the office of the county recorder of deeds. 
(4)  If initial construction of a display has not commenced within 60 days, the community development director approval shall lapse and the display plat shall be null and void. 
(5)  Lots shall be on an approved lot of record within one year of the display plat's recording or such longer period as may be permitted by the planning and zoning commission. 
(6)  The display plat shall be executed by the owner. 
(d)  Condominium display house plat. The same procedure as used for detached display homes shall be used for condominium development. 
(e)  Improvement guarantee. All subdivision improvements shown on a display plat or corresponding improvement plans that are necessary to place the display plat into service shall be guaranteed in the same manner that subdivision improvements are guaranteed under the provisions of section 410.140, prior to the issuance of a building permit for any display. 
(Code 2008, § 410.430; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.410. - Lot split procedure. 
(a)  No lot split shall be recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds unless and until approved by the planning and zoning commission in compliance with this section. 
(b)  Whenever there is a previously subdivided parcel under single ownership that is to be subdivided into two lots and which exists as a legal lot of record, such a division shall be exempt from provisions of article IV of this chapter and shall be designated as a lot split if the community development director determines that the following criteria are met: 
(1)  No additional improvements are required that would necessitate the posting of an escrow or bond, including concrete sidewalks, sewer mains, water mains or landscaping. Establishment of a right-of-way only shall not be construed as an improvement in this section. 
(2)  No provisions for common land or recreational facilities or subdivision amenities are included in the proposal. 
(3)  The use of the lot split procedure does not adversely affect the subject parcel or any adjoining properties. 
(4)  The proposed lot split is not in conflict with any provisions of the zoning regulations, of any special procedure permit or of these regulations. 
(5)  No variances are required from these regulations. 
(c)  The procedure for approval of a lot split shall be as follows: 
(1)  Seven initial copies of a certified survey prepared by a land surveyor registered in this state on paper not less than 81/2 inches by 11 inches in size showing the following shall be submitted: 
a.  A legal description of both the original lot and each of the proposed lots, if the project is not a part of an established subdivision plat of record. This must be surveyed and performed by a registered land surveyor. 
b.  North arrow and graphic scale. 
c.  Location of proposed and existing streets and adjoining property. 
d.  Location of all existing buildings, as determined by the community development director to verify compliance with any adopted zoning standards. 
e.  Approval of any utility companies, other than the city, serving the lot, as determined by the community development director. 
f.  Name, address and telephone number of the owner of record and a copy of the deed of record. 
g.  Zoning district and applicable district setbacks shown for all structures. 
h.  Right-of-way dedication as provided within the transportation master plan, comprehensive plan or trail master plan. 
i.  Easements of record and required easements as required by the city engineer. 
j.  Other requirements of section 410.110 as applicable to the lots petitioned to be subdivided. 
(2)  The following items shall accompany the required survey: 
a.  Record plat filing fee as established by the board of aldermen. 
b.  Certificate from the office of the county collector showing that there are no delinquent taxes outstanding. 
c.  Verification of fire hydrants and adequacy of water supply from applicable fire protection district. 
d.  Proper placement of survey monuments from the city engineer or an escrow agreement or land subdivision bond to guarantee installation of survey monuments in accordance with section 410.330 of these regulations. 
(3)  Fifteen copies of the revised plat, including a digital version that complies with the city GIS requirements, addressing comments provided by the community development director shall be submitted. The planning and zoning commission shall review the proposed lot split to insure compliance with all design and improvement requirements of these regulations and the zoning regulations. Lot splits found to be in compliance with the above requirements shall be recorded with the recorder of deeds of the county. 
(Code 2008, § 410.440; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.420. - Condominium plat. 
    Unless otherwise required by law, the platting requirements and procedures contained in this section shall apply to condominium plats. 
(1)  Approval process. Prior to application, persons seeking condominium plat approval shall comply with the pre-application meeting procedure set forth in section 410.100. After the pre-application meeting, the applicant may submit a final condominium plat to the planning and zoning commission for review. If the planning and zoning commission determines that the condominium plat meets the requirements of this section and other applicable requirements, it shall approve the plat. If the planning and zoning commission finds that the plat as submitted does not meet the requirements hereof, it shall deny approval or postpone its review until the applicant brings the plat into compliance as directed by the commission. Once approved by the planning and zoning commission, the city clerk or secretary of the planning commission is hereby authorized and directed to endorse upon the condominium plat the approval of the board of aldermen under the seal of the city. 
(2)  Compliance with the Uniform Condominium Act. All condominium plats proposed for approval shall comply with the Uniform Condominium Act, RSMo 448.1-101 et seq. , and must be prepared by a registered land surveyor or professional engineer. 
(3)  Condominium plat; submission requirements. The record condominium plat shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor or engineer at a scale of one inch equals 50 feet to one inch equals 100 feet in any increments of ten feet on one or more sheets whose maximum dimensions are 24 inches by 36 inches. In certain unusual instances where the subdivided area is of unusual size or shape, the community development director may permit a variation in the scale or size of the record plat. If more than one sheet is required, a key map on Sheet No. 1 showing the entire subdivision at reduced scale shall be provided. In addition, the applicant shall prepare and submit to the community development director seven copies of the record plat of the tract, a reduced copy of the plat measuring 11 inches by 17 inches and an electronic copy of the plat. The submission shall be made in compliance with the submission schedule of deadlines established by the community development director. The community development director or his designee shall review the plat regarding standards of these regulations upon receipt of a complete application and provide any comments for revision to the applicant, directing the applicant to provide 25 copies and an electronic copy in a format suitable to the standards of the city to the planning division for inclusion on the next available agenda. 
(4)  Condominium plat; minimum contents. The condominium plat must show the following: 
a.  The name of the condominium, that shall include the word "condominium" or be followed by the words "a condominium" and the association; 
b.  The name and survey or general layout of the entire condominium; 
c.  The location and dimension of all real estate not subject to development rights, or subject only to the development rights to withdraw, and the location and dimensions of all existing improvements within that real estate; 
d.  A description of any encroachments by or upon any portion of the condominium; 
e.  Indicate the location with reference to an established datum of any horizontal unit's boundaries and that unit's identifying number; 
f.  Indicate any real estate in which the unit owners will own only an estate for years, labeled as "leasehold real estate"; 
g.  Indicate the distance between non-contiguous parcels of real estate comprising the condominium; 
h.  Indicate the location and dimension of limited common elements, indicate porches, balconies and patios, other than parking spaces and other limited common elements; 
i.  The plat shall label any contemplated improvement shown as either "shall be built" or "need not be built." 
(5)  Declaration and bylaws to be submitted. Each application for a condominium plat shall be accompanied by the submission of the condominium declaration and bylaws that shall include a clear statement of the governing responsibilities for maintaining any common areas. 
(6)  Common areas and maintenance. All condominium associations shall be responsible for traffic and parking control, snow removal, sewers, water lines and lighting of the common areas. Non-residential condominiums shall be required to provide cross maintenance and parking agreements. The city shall have the right of easement to enter such common areas for emergency for fire, police and enforcement of its Code and the plat shall so provide. Such common areas shall remain the property of the condominium and the city shall not accept a dedication of these elements or the responsibility of maintenance. 
(Code 2008, § 410.445; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.430. - Boundary adjustment; exceptions. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to allow adjustments to be made to lot lines of platted lots or other lawful parcels for adjusting the sizes of building sites; however, it is not intended that extensive replatting be accomplished by use of this section. Three folded copies of the boundary adjustment plat shall be submitted to the community development director. In addition to the paper copies, a digital version of the plat shall be submitted, after the community development director has reviewed and provided review comments, compliant with the GIS requirements in the city. All boundary adjustment plats shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor or a state registered professional engineer and bear their signature and seal. There shall be no filing/review fee for a boundary adjustment plat. 
(b)  Criteria and data. Boundary adjustments must meet the following criteria and shall contain the following data: 
(1)  No additional lot shall be created by any boundary adjustment. 
(2)  The resulting lot or lots shall not be reduced below the minimum sizes and dimensions required by these regulations or the zoning regulations. 
(3)  North point and scale and the acreage of the original and adjusted lots. 
(4)  Location of existing structures as applicable to newly created lot lines for verification of zoning district regulation compliance. 
(5)  Front setback lines, location of easements and parcel address of record. 
(6)  The statement "This boundary adjustment plat is approved for recording this ____________ day of ____________ ." This statement shall also include a four-inch line with the title "community development director/director of the division of planning and zoning" directly below the line for his signature. 
(c)  Procedure. 
(1)  A boundary adjustment shall be accomplished by plat or by deed if not a part of an established subdivision plat, but must include a depiction of the boundaries of the original lots and of the adjusted lots. 
(2)  The boundary adjustment plat or deed shall be submitted to the community development director for review and approval prior to its recording with the recorder of deeds of the county. 
(d)  Lots in non-compliance. Boundary adjustments shall be allowed for lawful lots existing in non-compliance with minimum area, frontage and dimensional requirements of these regulations or the zoning regulations, provided that the resulting adjustment of lot lines does not increase the degree of non-compliance with the zoning regulations and these regulations. 
(Code 2008, § 410.450; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.440. - Vacation of subdivision. 
    The following procedure shall be followed for the vacation of subdivisions: 
(1)  Whenever any person may desire to vacate any subdivision or part thereof in which he shall be the legal owner of all of the lots, such person or corporation may petition the board of aldermen. Accompanying the petition shall be presented: 
a.  A legal description or exhibit description of the property to be vacated. 
b.  Proof of ownership of the property requested to be vacated. 
c.  A filing fee as established by the board of aldermen. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the petition, the public works department shall give notice of the petition in a public newspaper under the advertisement procedure established in section 405.1100. 
(3)  If no opposition is made to the petition, the board of aldermen may vacate the same with such restrictions as they may deem for the public good. If opposition is made, the petition shall be set down for public hearing before the board of aldermen. 
(4)  If the applicant fails to resolve all non-compliance with improvement requirements as reported to the board of aldermen by the city engineer, the board of aldermen may limit the requested vacation to the undeveloped portion of the subdivision. For the purpose of this section, the undeveloped portion of the subdivision does not include lots which have been sold or are under bona fide contract for sale to any person for personal use or occupancy. 
(5)  This provision for the vacation of subdivisions or parts thereof shall not apply to requests for the release of platted easement rights or rights-of-way. The board of aldermen may consider and grant such releases, provided that any and all parties that have or may have interests in such easement consent in writing to the requested release. Releases shall be recorded at the county recorder of deeds office. 
(Code 2008, § 410.460; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
ARTICLE VI. - PROTECTION OF NATURAL WATERCOURSES 

Sec. 410.450. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the regulations for the protection of natural watercourses set forth in this article is to implement the land use objectives of the city's master plan that recognizes the importance of protecting the city's natural attributes and the importance of utilizing these natural attributes to retain and absorb stormwater runoff and prevent development practices that destroy these natural functions and threaten the health, safety and general welfare of the city's residents. The specific purposes of these standards are to: 
(1)  Reduce flood impacts by absorbing peak flows, slowing the velocity of floodwaters and regulating base flow; 
(2)  Benefit the community in the following ways: economically, by minimizing encroachment on natural watercourses and the need for engineering solutions; by reducing property damage and threats to safety of watershed residents; by contributing to the scenic beauty and environment of the community and thereby preserving the character of the community; by improving the quality of life of its residents; and by increasing property values; 
(3)  Stabilize the banks of watercourses to reduce bank erosion and the downstream transport of sediments eroded from watercourses; 
(4)  Provide infiltration of stormwater and runoff and reducing impervious surfaces; 
(5)  Reduce pollutants in watercourses during periods of high flows by filtering, settling and transforming pollutants already present in watercourses; 
(6)  Restoring and maintaining the chemical, physical and biological integrity of the water resources; 
(7)  Provide quality watercourse habitats with shade and food to a wide array of wildlife by maintaining diverse and connected riparian vegetation; 
(8)  Furnish recreational opportunities; and 
(9)  Allow areas for natural watercourses to meander naturally, reducing infrastructure and property damage. 
(Code 2008, § 410.461; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.460. - Scope of application and requirements. 
(a)  Application. This article shall apply to: 
(1)  All property or lands for which application for subdivision is sought within the city limits of the city except for lots or developments for which a complete application for site plan approval or subdivision plat approval has been submitted to and accepted by the city as complete prior to the effective date of this article (April 23, 2008). However, this article shall apply to a resubmittal for any development for which approval has expired pursuant to the terms of section 405.880, 410.110 or 410.150. 
(2)  Land used primarily for agricultural or farming purposes where the owner or occupant proposes installation or removal of berms or dams across natural watercourses that are depicted on the most current United States Geological Survey 7.5 Minute Series (Topographic) Maps that cause the impoundment of stormwater. Such activity shall be permitted only with the approval of the board of aldermen. Installation or removal of berms or dams across natural watercourses that are not depicted on the most current United States Geological Survey 7.5 Minute (Topographic) Maps that cause the impoundment of stormwater shall be permitted only with the express written approval of the public works director. 
(b)  Requirements. 
(1)  All natural watercourses depicted on the most current United States Geological Survey 7.5 Minute Series (Topographic) Maps, the city's natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map shall be left in their natural state and shall be flanked by a riparian buffer meeting the requirements of this article. 
(2)  Within such riparian buffer, there shall be no land disturbance or other activity except as permitted by section 410.490. 
(3)  Development along natural watercourses that are left in their natural state shall have residential, commercial or industrial improvements, parking areas, driveways and in all subdivisions, lot lines set back from the top-of-bank of the existing stream bank or, where no established top-of-bank can be determined, the ten-year, 24-hour or 15-year, 20-minute water surface elevation, whichever is greater, except as permitted in this article. In the case of subdivision plats, except as permitted in this article, the watercourse and the riparian buffer area established by this article shall be preserved and made the responsibility of the subdivision trustees or property owner. In the case of a subdivision of land zoned "A," "R-1A," "C-O," "C-1," "C-2," "C-3," "I-1," "I-2," "PD-C" or "PD-I," the watercourse and the riparian buffer area shall be preserved by plat and made the responsibility of the property owner or trustees, except as permitted in this article. 
(4)  Slopes adjacent to the top-of-bank of a natural watercourse with significant grade shall be left undisturbed and included within the riparian buffer or permanent drainage easement. 
(Code 2008, § 410.462; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.470. - Plan requirements. 
(a)  A riparian buffer plan shall be submitted in conjunction with, or as part of, any grading plan or site plan for any development. The riparian buffer shall be clearly delineated on any grading plan or site plan. 
(b)  The riparian buffer plan shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A location or vicinity map; 
(2)  Field-surveyed natural watercourses and their associated riparian buffers that are left in their natural state; 
(3)  Proposed clearing or grading limits; 
(4)  Limits of the 100-year floodplain and floodway as identified on the official FIRM. 
(c)  Boundary markers locating the boundaries of riparian buffers and the limits of land disturbance shall be installed prior to final approval of the required clearing and grading plan. 
(Code 2008, § 410.463; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.480. - Minimum standards for riparian buffers. 
(a)  A riparian buffer for a natural watercourse that is left in its natural state shall consist of a vegetative strip of land extending landward along both sides of a natural watercourse. 
(b)  The riparian buffer shall begin at the top-of-bank of the natural watercourse. 
(c)  For those sites where vegetation does not exist, developers or property owners shall vegetate the riparian buffer with herbaceous plants. 
(d)  Owner shall grant access to the riparian buffer a minimum of a 20-foot-wide access strip to the public roadway network of a project to allow for management of the buffer and the stream. 
(e)  The widths of the riparian buffer shall be: 
(1)  100 feet landward along the main branch of the Peruque Creek, McCoy Creek, Little Dardenne Creek and Indian Camp Creek as identified by the city's Natural Watercourse and Riparian Buffer Protection Map. 
a.  In subdivisions zoned "A," "R-1A," "C-O," "C-1," "C-2," "C-3," "I-1," "I-2," "PD-C" and "PD-I," the buffer must be established as a permanent drainage easement or dedicated as common ground. Covenants and restrictions must be established for the drainage easement or common ground, which comply with this article to ensure the protection of the riparian buffer. 
b.  In subdivisions zoned "R-1B," "R-1C," "R-1D," "R-1E," "R-2," "R-3B," "PD-R," "PD-MXD" and "MHD," the entire 100-foot buffer must be dedicated as common ground. Covenants and restrictions must be established for the common ground which comply with this article to ensure the protection of the riparian buffer (refer to section 410.160). 
(2)  50 feet landward along the secondary tributaries of watercourses identified by the city's natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map. 
a.  In subdivisions zoned "A," "R-1A," "C-O," "C-1," "C-2," "C-3," "I-1," "I-2," "PD-C" and "PD-I," the buffer must be established as a permanent drainage easement or dedicated as common ground. Covenants and restrictions must be established for the drainage easement or common ground which comply with this article to ensure the protection of the riparian buffer. Such covenant and restrictions shall be contained in trust indentures submitted pursuant to section 410.160. 
b.  In subdivisions zoned "R-1B," "R-1C," "R-1D," "R-1E," "R-2," "R-3B," "PD-R," "PD-MXD" and "MHD," the entire 50-foot buffer must be dedicated as common ground. Covenants and restrictions must be established for the common ground which comply with this article to ensure the protection of the riparian buffer. Such covenant and restrictions shall be contained in trust indentures submitted pursuant to section 410.160. 
(3)  25 feet landward along any other watercourses that are not defined above and appear on the United States Geological Survey 7.5 Minute Series (Topographic) Map or identified on the city's natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map. 
a.  In subdivisions zoned "A," "R-1A," "C-O," "C-1," "C-2," "C-3," "I-1," "I-2" "PD-C," and "PD-I," the buffer must be established as a permanent drainage easement or dedicated as common ground. Covenants and restrictions must be established for the drainage easement or common ground which comply with this article to ensure the protection of the riparian buffer. Such covenant and restrictions shall be contained in trust indentures submitted pursuant to section 410.160. 
b.  In subdivisions zoned "R-1B," "R-1C," "R-1D," "R-1E," "R-2," "R-3B," "PD-R," "PD-MXD" and "MHD," the entire 25-foot buffer must be dedicated as common ground. Covenants and restrictions must be established for the common ground which comply with this article to ensure the protection of the riparian buffer. Such covenant and restrictions shall be contained in trust indentures submitted pursuant to section 410.160. 
(4)  Additional buffering will be required for pre-developed slopes with a significant grade adjacent to the top-of-bank of natural watercourses which appear on the United States Geological Survey 7.5 Minute Series (Topographic) Map or identified on the city's natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map. 
a.  The riparian buffer or drainage easement shall extend landward from the top-of-bank, including the entire distance of the sloped area exceeding 30 percent. 
b.  In cases where the required riparian buffer for the watercourse is more restrictive, the buffer setback shall take precedent. 
(Code 2008, § 410.464; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 3167, § 3, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 410.490. - Management and maintenance of riparian buffer. 
(a)  The riparian buffer shall be managed to enhance and maximize its value and effectiveness. Management includes specific limitations on altering the natural conditions of the buffer. The following practices and activities are permitted only with the express written approval of the public works director: 
(1)  Construction and maintenance of roads, bridges and utilities (including sanitary and storm sewers). The right-of-way shall be the minimum width needed to allow for maintenance access and installation. The angle of the right-of-way or utility crossing shall be perpendicular to the natural watercourse in order to minimize clearing requirements. Impacts within these areas are permissive upon application and preliminary and final plat or site plan approval for portions of residential lot development. 
(2)  Paths, including hard-surface trails. 
(3)  Buffer restoration projects. 
(4)  Water quality monitoring and stream gauging are permitted within the riparian buffer. 
(b)  Trash and debris and individual trees within the riparian buffer that are in danger of falling on structures, causing damage to dwellings or other structures may be removed. 
(c)  Material dredged or removed during development authorized under this section shall be stored outside the riparian buffer. 
(d)  All plats and all improvements plans shall clearly: 
(1)  Show the boundaries of any riparian buffer on the subject property; 
(2)  Provide a note to reference any riparian buffer stating: "There shall be no clearing, grading, construction or disturbance of vegetation except as permitted by section 410.490 of the city Municipal Code." 
(Code 2008, § 410.465; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.500. - Waiver. 
    The public works director or his designee may grant a waiver allowing the riparian buffer to be disturbed only in cases of public purpose and necessity or only upon the director's approval of designed stream bank or site development erosion control measures. 
(Code 2008, § 410.466; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.510. - Natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map. 
    This article hereby incorporates the official city natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map as though fully set forth herein. The official city natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map shall be kept by the public works director and shall be the most recently amended version of the map. A copy of the official map shall be kept on file with the city clerk. The public works director is hereby authorized to amend the city natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map from time to time. 
(Code 2008, § 410.467; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.520. - Violations and enforcement. 
    Violations of this article shall be enforced pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 2008, § 410.468; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.530. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    100-year flood. See Base flood. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    City's natural watercourse and riparian buffer protection map means the official map which delineates watercourses that are to be protected and their associated riparian buffers. 
    Drainage easement means land in which the public or the city has an easement devoted to, planned, proposed or required for use as a public drainage system. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community, issued by the administrator, where the boundaries of the flood areas having special hazard areas and the risk premium zones applicable to the community. 
    Floodplain means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source. 
    Floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than one foot. 
    Herbaceous means perennial plants which have stems and die at the end of the growing season. New growth forms from the roots, from underground stems or from crown tissue at the surface (i.e., grass). 
    Impervious surface means any surface that cannot effectively absorb or infiltrate water. This may include roads, streets, parking lots, rooftops, sidewalks and other areas not covered by vegetation. 
    Land disturbance means any land or vegetation change, including, but not limited to, clearing, grubbing, stripping, removal of vegetation, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting and filling of land, that do not involve construction, paving or any other installation of impervious cover. 
    Natural watercourse means a channel formed in the existing surface topography of the earth prior to changes made by unnatural conditions. 
    Riparian buffer means a vegetated buffer strip along and extending landward of a watercourse that filters stormwater and provides wildlife habitat. 
    Riparian vegetation means an association of plant species growing adjacent to freshwater courses, including perennial and intermittent streams, lakes and other bodies of fresh water. 
    Significant grade means grade that is in excess of 30 percent. 
    Top-of-bank means the highest elevation of land which confines water flowing in a stream to the channel as determined by city staff. 
    Topographic map means a map showing all principal physical features of an area, including elevations. 
    Topography means the physical land surface relief describing the terrain elevation and slope. 
    Watershed means an area of land that drains into a particular watercourse, usually divided by topography. 
(Code 2008, § 410.469; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
ARTICLE VII. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 410.540. - Variance. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission may accept a completed application to modify or authorize a variance to provisions of these regulations, for recommendation to the board of aldermen who may vary or modify a requirement of this chapter when the following circumstances apply: 
(1)  The tract to be subdivided is of such unusual size or shape, or is surrounded by such development, or contains such topographic conditions or characteristics, or is intended for the construction of improvements of such unusual design or arrangement, that the strict application of requirements in these regulations would impose practical difficulties or particular hardship. 
(2)  Any criteria for variances established elsewhere in these regulations or the engineering design criteria adopted hereunder for a specific requirement have been met. 
(3)  The granting of a variance will not be detrimental to the public interest and the general intent of the chapter is preserved. 
(4)  In granting variances, the planning and zoning commission and board of aldermen may require such conditions which in their judgment secure the objectives of these regulations. 
(b)  A petitioner's application shall be made in writing and state fully and clearly all facts necessary to support the request. All requests shall be accompanied by the processing fee established by the board of aldermen. The application shall be accompanied by maps, plans or additional data which may aid in the complete analysis of the request. The board of aldermen may affirm, reverse, modify or amend in whole or part a recommendation by the planning and zoning commission. It shall require the affirmative vote of five board of aldermen members to overturn a negative recommendation of the planning and zoning commission on any variance application. A majority of the board of aldermen shall be sufficient to affirm any determination of the planning and zoning commission. 
(c)  The development plan shall contain a note indicating the variance request and applicable application number for future user of the plat to be aware of any variance approval. 
(Code 2008, § 410.470; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.550. - Amendments. 
    Any provision of these regulations may be changed and amended from time to time by the board of aldermen, upon recommendation from the planning and zoning commission, in accordance with procedures for text amendments established by the city's zoning regulations and applicable state law. 
(Code 2008, § 410.480; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.560. - Execution of regulations. 
    Unless otherwise prohibited by law, the mayor, city administrator or public works director, in the administration and execution of the provisions of these subdivision regulations, are authorized and directed to issue notices, adopt forms, execute documents and agreements and implement procedures that are necessary and consistent with the express language of, as well as the intent and purpose of these subdivision regulations. 
(Code 2008, § 410.490; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.570. - Parcels of land created by court order. 
    Any court ordered division of a tract of land other than those resulting from condemnation proceedings must comply with the requirements of these regulations. 
(Code 2008, § 410.500; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
Sec. 410.580. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  No property description of any subdivision within the jurisdiction of these regulations, including any manual, specification or standards adopted pursuant to these regulations, shall be entitled to be recorded in the county office of the recorder of deeds or have any validity until it has been approved in a manner prescribed herein. In the event any such unapproved property description is recorded, it shall be considered invalid and the city attorney may cause proceedings to be instituted to have such plat or deed declared invalid. 
(b)  Any person, firm, association or corporation violating any provisions of these regulations, including any manual, specifications or standards adopted pursuant to these regulations, or any employee, assistant, agent or any other person participating or taking any part in, joining or aiding in a violation of any provision of these regulations may be prosecuted as provided by law for the violation of ordinances and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 for any one offense or imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day a violation continues after service of written notice to abate it shall constitute a separate offense, but no notice to abate is a prerequisite to prosecution of any single violation. 
(c)  In addition to the penalties hereinabove authorized and established, the city attorney may take such other actions at law or in equity as may be required to halt, terminate, remove or otherwise eliminate any violation of these regulations. Any person judicially determined to have violated any provision of these regulations, including any manual, specifications, standards or agreement adopted pursuant to these regulations, shall pay the city's costs, including reasonable attorneys' fees, of enforcing such regulations. 
(Code 2008, § 410.520; Ord. No. 3001, § 4, 6-24-2009) 
CHAPTER 415. - FLOODWAY AND FLOODWAY FRINGE DISTRICTS 

Sec. 415.010. - Statutory authorization, findings of fact and purposes. 
(a)  Statutory authorization. The legislature of this state has in RSMo 89.020 delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt floodplain management regulations designed to protect the health, safety and general welfare. Therefore, the city, ordains as follows. 
(b)  Findings of fact. 
(1)  Flood losses resulting from periodic inundation. The special flood hazard areas of the city are subject to inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  General causes of the flood losses. These flood losses are caused by: 
a.  The cumulative effect of development in any delineated floodplain causing increases in flood heights and velocities; and 
b.  The occupancy of flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods, hazardous to others, inadequately elevated or otherwise unprotected from flood damages. 
(3)  Methods used to analyze flood hazards. The flood insurance study (FIS) that is the basis of this chapter uses a standard engineering method of analyzing flood hazards which consist of a series of interrelated steps. 
a.  Selection of a base flood that is based upon engineering calculations which permit a consideration of such flood factors as its expected frequency of occurrence, the area inundated and the depth of inundation. The base flood selected for this chapter is representative of large floods that are characteristic of what can be expected to occur on the particular streams subject to this chapter. It is in the general order of a flood which could be expected to have a one percent chance of occurrence in any one year as delineated on the federal insurance administrator's FIS and illustrative materials dated January 20, 2016, and any future revisions thereto. 
b.  Calculation of water surface profiles is based on a standard hydraulic engineering analysis of the capacity of the stream channel and overbank areas to convey the regulatory flood. 
c.  Computation of a floodway required to convey this flood without increasing flood heights more than one foot at any point. 
d.  Delineation of floodway encroachment lines within which no development is permitted that would cause any increase in flood height. 
e.  Delineation of flood fringe, i.e., that area outside the floodway encroachment lines but still subject to inundation by the base flood. 
(c)  Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety and general welfare; to minimize those losses described in subsection (b)(1) of this section; to establish or maintain the community's eligibility for participation in the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) as defined in 44 CFR 59.22(a)(3); and to meet the requirements of 44 CFR 60.3(d) by applying the provisions of this chapter to: 
(1)  Restrict or prohibit uses that are dangerous to health, safety or property in times of flooding or cause undue increases in flood heights or velocities; 
(2)  Require uses vulnerable to floods, including public facilities that serve such uses, be provided with flood protection at the time of initial construction; 
(3)  Protect individuals from buying lands that are unsuited for the intended development purposes due to the flood hazard; and 
(4)  Assure that eligibility is maintained for property owners in the community to purchase flood insurance in the National Flood Insurance Program. 
(Code 2006, § 415.010; Code 2008, § 415.010; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004; Ord. No. 3562, § 1, 1-13-2016) 
Sec. 415.020. - General provisions. 
(a)  Lands to which chapter applies. This chapter shall apply to all lands within the jurisdiction of the city, identified as numbered and unnumbered A zones and AE zones, on the Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs) for the county on map panels 29183C0180G, 29183C0185G, 29183C0190G, 29183C0195G, 29183C0205G, 29183C0210G, 29183C0215G, and 29183C0220G dated January 20, 2016, and any future revisions thereto. In all areas covered by this chapter, no development shall be permitted except through the issuance of a floodplain development permit, granted by the city or its duly designated representative under such safeguards and restrictions as the city or the designated representative may reasonably impose for the promotion and maintenance of the general welfare, health of the inhabitants of the community, and as specifically noted in section 415.050. 
(b)  Floodplain administrator. The community development director is hereby designated as the floodplain administrator under this chapter. 
(c)  Rules for interpretation of district boundaries. The boundaries of the floodway and floodway fringe overlay districts shall be determined by scaling distances on the official zoning map or on the flood insurance rate map or floodway map. Where interpretation is needed to the exact location of the boundaries of the districts as shown on the official zoning map, as for example where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions, the Enforcement officer shall make the necessary interpretation. In such cases where the interpretation is contested, the board of adjustment will resolve the dispute. The regulatory flood elevation for the point in question shall be the governing factor in locating the district boundary on the land. The person contesting the location of the district boundary shall be given a reasonable opportunity to present his case to the board and to submit his own technical evidence, if he so desires. 
(d)  Compliance. No development located within the special flood hazard areas of this community shall be located, extended, converted or structurally altered without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. 
(e)  Abrogation and greater restrictions. It is not intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate or impair any existent easements, covenants or deed restrictions. However, where this chapter imposes greater restrictions, the provision of this chapter shall prevail. All other ordinances inconsistent with this chapter are hereby repealed to the extent of the inconsistency only. 
(f)  Interpretation. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements, shall be liberally construed in favor of the governing body and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other powers granted by state statutes. 
(g)  Warning and disclaimer of liability. The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur on rare occasions or the flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes, such as ice jams and bridge openings restricted by debris. This chapter does not imply that areas outside the floodway and flood fringe or land uses permitted with such areas will be free from flooding or flood damage. This chapter shall not create a liability on the part of the city or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that may result from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder. 
(h)  Severability. If any section, clause, provision or portion of this chapter is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of appropriate jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall not be affected thereby. 
(i)  Appeal. Where a request for a floodplain development permit to develop is denied by the community development director, the applicant may apply for a variance to the board of adjustment. 
(Code 2006, § 415.020; Code 2008, § 415.020; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011; Ord. No. 3562, § 2, 1-13-2016) 
Sec. 415.030. - Administration. 
(a)  Floodplain development permit (required). A floodplain development permit shall be required for all proposed construction or other development, including the placement of manufactured homes, in the areas described in section 415.020(a). No person, firm, corporation or unit of government shall initiate any development or substantial improvement or cause the same to be done without first obtaining a separate floodplain development permit for each structure or other development. 
(b)  Designation of floodplain administrator. The community development director is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities of floodplain administrator. Duties of the community development director shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Review of all applications for floodplain development permits to assure that sites are reasonably safe from flooding and that the floodplain development permit requirements of this chapter have been satisfied; 
(2)  Review of all applications for floodplain development permits for proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been obtained from federal, state or local governmental agencies from which prior approval is required by federal, state or local law; 
(3)  Review all subdivision proposals and other proposed new development, including manufactured home parks or subdivisions, to determine whether such proposals will be reasonably safe from flooding; 
(4)  Issue floodplain development permits for all approved applications; 
(5)  Notify adjacent communities and the state emergency management agency prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA); 
(6)  Ensure that the flood-carrying capacity is not diminished and shall be maintained within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse; 
(7)  Verify and maintain a record of actual elevation (in relation to mean sea level) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all new or substantially improved structures; 
(8)  Verify and maintain a record of actual elevation (in relation to mean sea level) that the new or substantially improved non-residential structures have been floodproofed; 
(9)  Require certification from a registered professional engineer or architect when floodproofing techniques are utilized for a particular non-residential structure. 
(d)  Application for floodplain development permit. To obtain a floodplain development permit, the applicant shall first file an application in writing on a form furnished for that purpose. Every floodplain development permit application shall: 
(1)  Describe the land on which the proposed work is to be done by lot, block and tract, house and street address or similar description that will readily identify and specifically locate the proposed structure or work; 
(2)  Identify and describe the work to be covered by the floodplain development permit; 
(3)  Indicate the use or occupancy for which the proposed work is intended; 
(4)  Indicate the assessed value of the structure and the fair market value of the improvement; 
(5)  Specify whether development is located in designated flood fringe or floodway; 
(6)  Identify the existing base flood elevation and the elevation of the proposed development; 
(7)  Give such other information as reasonably may be required by the community development director; 
(8)  Be accompanied by plans and specifications for proposed construction; and 
(9)  Be signed by the permittee or his authorized agent who may be required to submit evidence to indicate such authority. 
(Code 2006, § 415.030; Code 2008, § 415.030; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 415.040. - Establishment of zoning districts. 
    The mapped floodplain areas within the jurisdiction of this chapter are hereby divided into the two following districts: a floodway overlay district (FW) and a floodway fringe overlay district (FF) identified in the flood insurance study (and accompanying maps). Within these districts all uses not meeting the standards of this chapter and those standards of the underlying zoning district shall be prohibited. These zones shall be consistent with the numbered and unnumbered A Zones (including "AE," "AO" and "AH" Zones) as identified on the official FIRM and identified in the flood insurance study provided by the federal emergency management agency. 
(Code 2006, § 415.040; Code 2008, § 415.040; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004) 
Sec. 415.050. - Provisions for flood hazard reduction; general standards. 
(a)  No permit for floodplain development shall be granted for new construction, substantial improvements and other improvements, including the placement of manufactured homes, within any numbered or unnumbered A Zones and AE Zones, unless the conditions of this section are satisfied. 
(b)  All areas identified as unnumbered A Zones on the FIRM are subject to inundation of the 100-year flood; however, the base flood elevation is not provided. Development within unnumbered A Zones is subject to all provisions of this chapter. If flood insurance study data is not available, the community shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation or floodway data currently available from federal, state or other sources. 
(c)  Until a floodway is designated, no new construction, substantial improvements or other development, including fill, shall be permitted within any numbered A Zone or AE Zone on the FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one foot at any point within the community. 
(d)  All new construction, subdivision proposals, substantial improvements, prefabricated structures, placement of manufactured homes and other developments shall require: 
(1)  Design or adequate anchorage to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure resulting from hydrodynamic and hydrostatic loads, including the effects of buoyancy; 
(2)  Construction with materials resistant to flood damage; 
(3)  Utilization of methods and practices that minimize flood damages; 
(4)  All electrical, heating, ventilation, plumbing, air conditioning equipment and other service facilities be designed or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding; 
(5)  New or replacement water supply systems or sanitary sewage systems be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters and on-site waste disposal systems be located so as to avoid impairment or contamination; 
(6)  Subdivision proposals and other proposed new development, including manufactured home parks or subdivisions, located within special flood hazard areas are required to assure that: 
a.  All such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; 
b.  All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, are located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage; 
c.  Adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards; and 
d.  All proposals for development, including proposals for manufactured home parks and subdivisions, of five acres or 50 lots, whichever is lesser, include within such proposals base flood elevation data; 
(7)  Storage, material and equipment: 
a.  The storage or processing of materials within the special flood hazard area that are in time of flooding buoyant, flammable, explosive or could be injurious to human, animal or plant life is prohibited; 
b.  Storage of other material or equipment may be allowed if not subject to major damage by floods, if firmly anchored to prevent flotation or if readily removable from the area within the time available after a flood warning; and 
(8)  Accessory structures. Structures used solely for parking and limited storage purposes, not attached to any other structure on the site, of limited investment value and not larger than 400 square feet may be constructed at grade and wet-floodproofed provided there is no human habitation or occupancy of the structure; the structure is of single-wall design; a variance has been granted from the standard floodplain management requirements of this chapter; and a floodplain development permit has been issued. 
(Code 2006, § 415.050; Code 2008, § 415.050; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004) 
Sec. 415.060. - Specific standards. 
(a)  Generally. In all areas identified as numbered and unnumbered A Zones and AE Zones where base flood elevation data have been provided, as set forth in section 415.050(b), the following provisions are required: 
(1)  Residential construction. New construction or substantial improvement of any residential structures, including manufactured homes, shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to one foot above base flood elevation. 
(2)  Non-residential construction. New construction or substantial improvement of any commercial, industrial or other non-residential structures, including manufactured homes, shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to one foot above the base flood elevation or, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, be floodproofed so that below the base flood elevation the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the standards of this subsection are satisfied. Such certification shall be provided to the floodplain administrator as set forth in section 415.030(c)(9). 
(3)  New construction and substantial improvements. Require, for all new construction and substantial improvements, that fully enclosed areas below lowest floor used solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement and that are subject to flooding shall be designed to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the entry and exit of floodwaters. 
(b)  Minimum design criteria. Designs for meeting this requirement must either be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect or meet or exceed the following minimum criteria: 
(1)  A minimum of two openings having a total net area of not less than one square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding shall be provided; and 
(2)  The bottom of all opening shall be no higher than one foot above grade. Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices, provided that they permit the automatic entry and exit of floodwaters. 
(c)  Manufactured homes. 
(1)  All manufactured homes to be placed within all unnumbered and numbered A Zones and AE Zones on the community's FIRM shall be required to be installed using methods and practices that minimize flood damage. For the purposes of this requirement, manufactured homes must be elevated and anchored to resist flotation, collapse or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. 
(2)  Require manufactured homes that are placed or substantially improved within unnumbered or numbered A Zones and AE Zones on the community's FIRM on sites: 
a.  Outside of a manufactured home park or subdivision; 
b.  In a new manufactured home park or subdivision; 
c.  In an expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision; or 
d.  In an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred substantial damage as the result of a flood, be elevated on a permanent foundation such that the lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated to or above one foot above the base flood elevation and be securely attached to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. 
(3)  Require that manufactured homes to be placed or substantially improved on sites in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision within all unnumbered and numbered A Zones and AE Zones on the community's FIRM that are not subject to the provisions of subsection (b)(2) of this section, be elevated so that either: 
a.  The lowest floor of the manufactured home is at one foot above the base flood level; or 
b.  The manufactured home chassis is supported by reinforced piers or other foundation elements of at least equivalent strength that are no less than 36 inches in height above grade and be securely attached to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. 
(Code 2006, § 415.060; Code 2008, § 415.060; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004) 
Sec. 415.070. - Floodway. 
    Located within areas of special flood hazard established in section 415.020(a) are areas designated as floodways. Since the floodway is an extremely hazardous area due to the velocity of floodwaters that carry debris and potential projectiles, the following provisions shall apply. 
(1)  The community shall select and adopt a regulatory floodway based on the principle that the area chosen for the regulatory floodway must be designed to carry the waters of the base flood without increasing the water surface elevation of that flood more than one foot at any point. 
(2)  The community shall prohibit any encroachments, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements and other development, within the adopted regulatory floodway unless it has been demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the proposed encroachment would not result in any increase in flood levels within the community during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. 
(3)  All new construction and substantial improvements shall comply with all applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of section 415.050. 
(4)  In unnumbered A Zones, the community shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation or floodway data currently available from federal, state or other sources as set forth in section 415.050(b). 
(Code 2006, § 415.070; Code 2008, § 415.070; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004) 
Sec. 415.080. - Recreational vehicles. 
    Require that recreational vehicles placed on sites within all unnumbered and numbered A Zones and AE Zones on the community's FIRM either: 
(1)  Be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days; 
(2)  Be fully licensed and ready for highway use; or 
(3)  Meet the permitting, elevation and the anchoring requirements for manufactured homes of this chapter. 
(Code 2006, § 415.075; Code 2008, § 415.075; Ord. No. 2082, 2-18-2004) 
Sec. 415.090. - Floodplain management variance procedures. 
(a)  Establishment of appeal board. The board of adjustment as established by the city shall hear and decide appeals and requests for variances from the floodplain management requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  Responsibility of appeal board. 
(1)  Where an application for a floodplain development permit or request for a variance from the floodplain management regulations is denied by the community development director or designate, the applicant may apply for such floodplain development permit or variance directly to the board of adjustment. 
(2)  The board of adjustment shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged that there is an error in any requirement, decision or determination made by the community development director in the enforcement or administration of this chapter. 
(c)  Further appeals. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the board of adjustment or any taxpayer may appeal such decision to the circuit court of the county, state of state as provided in RSMo 89.110 . 
(d)  Floodplain management variance criteria. In passing upon such applications for variances, the board of adjustment shall consider all technical data and evaluations, all relevant factors, standards specified in other sections of this chapter and the following criteria: 
(1)  The danger to life and property due to flood damage; 
(2)  The danger that materials may be swept onto other lands to the injury of others; 
(3)  The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner; 
(4)  The importance of the services provided by the proposed facility to the community; 
(5)  The necessity to the facility of a waterfront location, where applicable; 
(6)  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to flood damage, for the proposed use; 
(7)  The compatibility of the proposed use with existing and anticipated development; 
(8)  The relationship of the proposed use to the comprehensive plan and floodplain management program for that area; 
(9)  The safety of access to the property in times of flood for ordinary and emergency vehicles; 
(10)  The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise and sediment transport of the floodwaters, if applicable, expected at the site; and 
(11)  The costs of providing governmental services during and after flood conditions, including maintenance and repair of public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, streets and bridges. 
(e)  Conditions for approving floodplain management variances. 
(1)  Generally, variances may be issued for new construction and substantial improvements to be erected on a lot of one-half acre or less in size contiguous to and surrounded by lots with existing structures constructed below the base flood level, provided that subsections (e)(2) through (6) of this section have been fully considered. As the lot size increases beyond the one-half acre, the technical justification required for issuing the variance increases. 
(2)  Variances may be issued for the reconstruction, rehabilitation or restoration of structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the state inventory of historic places or local inventory of historic places upon determination provided the proposed activity will not preclude the structures continued historic designation. 
(3)  Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. 
(4)  Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief. 
(5)  Variances shall only be issued upon: 
a.  A showing of good and sufficient cause; 
b.  A determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship to the applicant; and 
c.  A determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisances, cause fraud on or victimization of the public or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(6)  A community shall notify the applicant in writing over the signature of a community official that: 
a.  The issuance of a variance to construct a structure below base flood level will result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts as high as $25.00 for $100.00 of insurance coverage; and 
b.  Such construction below the base flood level increases risks to life and property. Such notification shall be maintained with the record of all variance actions as required by this chapter. 
(f)  Conditions for approving variances for accessory structures. 
(1)  Any variance granted for an accessory structure shall be decided individually based on a case-by-case analysis of the building's unique circumstances. Variances granted shall meet the following conditions as well as those criteria and conditions set forth in subsections (d) and (e) of this section. 
(2)  In order to minimize flood damages during the 100-year flood and the threat to public health and safety, the following conditions shall be included for any variance issued for accessory structures that are constructed at-grade and wet-floodproofed.
